HEADLINE: Rebuilding the Paths to Work When a Nest Egg Is Lost 

BYLINE:  By JULIA LAWLOR

 BODY:
EARLY retirement did not work out as planned for Janine Baron.
 For seven years, Ms. Baron, now 51, and her husband owned a boutique money management firm, starting out in Los Angeles and later moving to Manhattan. With the stock market booming, it prospered. Three years ago, her husband died, and she closed up shop, believing that she would never have to work again. 
 Most of her nest egg was in stocks, so she decided to play it safe and moved her high-technology investments into an Irish pharmaceutical company whose shares had risen steadily for 10 years. Unfortunately, they subsequently sank from $65 to $1, pulling down her portfolio by 75 percent. 
And so, last October, Ms. Baron joined the army of retired people in the New York metropolitan area who, having had their incomes hammered by the stock market bust, are looking for work.
It is going to be a tough slog for many of them. New York's economy has sunk deeper into recession even as business in the country as a whole shows signs of perking up. Unemployment in New York has climbed to 8.4 percent from 5.3 percent in less than two years, while the national jobless rate fell to 5.7 percent in January, from 6 percent the previous month. And of course, Wall Street is reeling and the city is planning extensive budget cuts.
Ms. Baron quickly discovered that all her old contacts on Wall Street had been laid off. She sent resumes to online job postings without success. To hedge her bets while she pursued a full-time job, she is also working toward a real estate license, and says she is thinking about starting a home-based business selling health and wellness products. She has given herself a year to start generating an income, though she says she dreads the thought "of having a 9-to-5 job that I hate."
For all the gloom in the air, though, workplace experts urge older people not to lose heart. Even today, some industries are experiencing labor shortages, they say. Deborah Russell, manager of economic security and work for AARP in Washington, says opportunities exist for retired people in health care, including nurses, home health care workers and medical assistants. The service industry needs retail and customer service workers, and there is a great demand for retired teachers.
The five occupations with the largest projected job growth between 2000 and 2010, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, are computer software engineers, computer support specialists, security guards, customer service representatives and food preparers and servers.
In the New York area, the job openings seem to be in the same sectors as in the rest of the country. At Adecco Employment Services, a placement agency in Melville, N.Y., there are openings for health care workers, call-center support workers and mortgage processors, according to Tom Lucas, senior vice president for human resources. Although many high-technology jobs have disappeared, there is still a demand for certain skilled positions like Oracle programmers, he said.
In most cases, older workers will have more luck finding jobs in small and midsize companies than in large corporations, said Richard Bayer, chief operating officer of the Five O'Clock Club, an outplacement and career coaching firm in New York. "They need people who don't require an investment in training, who can hit the ground running," he said.
What if you have just retired with a comfortable income? Plan for hard times anyway, the experts suggest. "People sever too many of their connections right at the beginning," said Jeri Sedlar, a New York executive recruiter who wrote "Don't Retire, Rewire!" (Alpha Books, 2002) with a co-author, Rick Miners. She urges retired people to keep attending industry association meetings, reading industry newsletters and maintaining contacts -- just in case.
If you do decide to rejoin the work force, she suggests, interview people working in the field that interests you. If possible, give the occupation a test drive. If you want to open a hot-dog stand, for example, go and work at one first.
Arnold Fleisher, a 67-year-old retired veterinarian from Long Beach, N.Y., found another way to get his foot in the door. Eight years ago, he sold his practice and began working about 10 hours a week for another veterinarian. He also did volunteer work at the Museum of Natural History in New York.
After taking a beating in the stock market and watching his income from certificates of deposit shrink, Mr. Fleisher jumped last June when the opportunity arose to turn a research project he was working on as a volunteer at the museum into a full-time paid position.
"It took being aggressive, pushing a little bit," he said. With his new museum job plus his part-time stint as a veterinarian, he puts in almost 50 hours a week.
Identifying the job you want is more than half the battle. But for the job interview itself, you should be careful to show enthusiasm, energy and the willingness to be a team player, no matter how lofty a position you held before retirement, specialists say.
"Leave your ego at home," said Robert K. Critchley, executive vice president of DBM, the New York human-resources consulting firm formerly called Drake Beam Morin, and author of "Rewired, Rehired or Retired" (Jossey-Bass, 2002). "Be positive, and don't live off past glories," he said. "No one wants to hear your war stories."
Mr. Bayer of the Five O'Clock Club advises clients to "overcome any prejudice you might encounter" by wearing stylish clothes, showing technical expertise and coming across as full of energy. "Mention any outdoor or indoor sports activities you enjoy," he said. "One of our clients, in his late 50's, would carry his briefcase and a small gym bag to the interview, and would mention it in passing. He was fit. It wasn't a bad tactic."
Most important, workplace specialists say, is to spend most of your job search time networking, rather than sending out hundreds of resumes or answering help-wanted ads. Mona Kreaden, a Manhattan resident who left her last job in June 2001 at the age of 60, says networking has always worked for her in the past. This time around, she is joining women's groups and associations, and contacting people in fields that interest her so that she can gather information.
After working as director of a program at New York University to help professors improve their teaching skills, Ms. Kreaden was ready to take it easy. In a long and varied career, she had been a teacher and an advertising executive, had run her family's trucking business and had run an international nonprofit organization. She imagined the next chapter of her life would involve a cause she truly believed in, perhaps working for a nonprofit agency or even as a volunteer.
But she lost half her savings in the bear market, and now, at 62, is compelled to find full-time work. She is considering becoming certified as an executive coach, but is keeping her options open. Not yet at the interview stage, she already has a plan for what she will say to counter any hesitation the interviewer might have about her age.
"I will say, 'If you hire a younger person, you will spend a lot of time and money getting that person up to the level you want,' " Ms. Kreaden said. "Whereas I have the experience."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Houston

BYLINE:  By KATHRYN JONES; KATHRYN JONES is a regular contributor to The Times.

 BODY:
From its soaring "Blade Runner" skyline to the scandals of its rich and famous and the stature of its hottest pro basketball star, Houston is a city that feels supersized. This is, after all, the center of the Texas oil business, where enormous fortunes have been made and lost in booms and busts, and egos tend to run -- well, extra large.
 It's no surprise, then, that when Houstonians celebrate they like to do it up big. This spring is no exception. Texas's largest city is host to a rodeo of epic proportions and is opening a busy season of art exhibitions, musical performances and theater productions. Downtown is bustling with renovations of historic buildings, with new hotels and loft apartments and a new aquarium. 
 Spring is also the time when Houston's mild climate and location near the balmy Gulf of Mexico are shown to best advantage before the weather turns hot and sticky. Azaleas and camellias are showy, and the city on Buffalo Bayou feels as if part of the Old South has been dropped into a shiny metropolis.

Events
Even urban cowboys pull on a pair of boots when the annual Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo gallops into town. The event, which runs through March 16, drew 1.5 million people last year and promises to be even bigger this year in the new, sprawling Reliant Park at Kirby Drive and South Loop 610. Cattle, horses, goats, llamas and alpacas will fill acres of pens at the livestock show, while the rodeo will feature championship bull riding, barrel racing, steer wrestling and other events. Among the scheduled musical acts at the rodeo are Bon Jovi (March 12 at 7 p.m.), Ray Charles and Ronnie Milsap (March 14 at 7 p.m.) and Alabama (March 16 at 4 p.m.). Tickets are $6 for the livestock show and $14 to $75 for the rodeo and concerts. Call (713) 629-3700 for tickets; for more information, (832) 667-1000 or www .hlsr.com. 
Anchoring Houston's museum district, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, 1001 Bissonnet Street, (713) 639-7300, www.mfah.org, presents several exhibitions this spring in its two buildings. Among them is "American Modern: 1920's and 30's Design," March 15 to July 20, which examines how the clean lines, graphics and industrial materials of furniture and decorative objects in those decades created a distinctive aesthetic. "Paris in the Age of Impressionism: Masterworks From the Musee d'Orsay," April 6 to June 29, includes more than 100 works from the Paris museum, including paintings by Cezanne, Degas and Manet. The enormous permanent collection features Renaissance, 18th-century, Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art. Open Tuesday and Wednesday 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Thursday to 9 p.m., Friday and Saturday to 7 p.m., and Sunday from 12:15 to 7 p.m. General admission is $7, free on Thursday, or $10 to $22 including the ticketed exhibitions.
On a quiet street in the Montrose neighborhood, the Menil Collection, 1515 Sul Ross Street, (713) 525-9400, www.menil.org, explores the early work of the Minimalist sculptor Donald Judd in an exhibition running through April 27. "Jasper Johns: Drawings," through May 4, travels through Johns's career. In the permanent collection, ranging over antiquity, tribal cultures and the 20th century, are paintings, sculptures, prints, drawings, photographs and rare books. Open Wednesday to Sunday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. No charge for admission.
Lush Hermann Park with its gardens and fountains is the backdrop for the Houston Museum of Natural Science, 1 Hermann Circle Drive, (713) 639-4629, www.hmns.mus.tx.us. "St. Peter and the Vatican: The Legacy of the Popes," through July 27, displays more than 350 artworks, artifacts, relics, historical documents and treasures, many never shown outside the Vatican, including a fourth-century fresco of San Siricio and a 13th-century mosaic bust of an angel. There is also a live butterfly exhibit, a gem and mineral collection, a planetarium, dinosaur skeletons and an IMAX theater. Open daily. General admission is $6, $17.50 for the Vatican exhibition. 
Houston has the Southwest's largest theater district. This spring's productions include the Tony-winning Broadway revival of Cole Porter's "Kiss Me, Kate," starring Glory Crampton and Paul Schoeffler, at Theater Under the Stars in the Hobby Center for the Performing Arts, 800 Bagby Street. Performances are March 20 to April 6, mostly at 8 p.m., but times vary. Tickets are $25 to $68; (888) 558-3882; www.tuts.com.
The Houston Ballet, (713) 227-2787, www.houstonballet.org, will perform "Cinderella," choreographed by its artistic director, Ben Stevenson, at the downtown Wortham Theater Center, Texas Avenue at Smith Street. Evening performances on March 13, 15, 21 and 22 are at 7:30 and matinees on March 16, 22 and 23 are at 2. Tickets are $11.50 to $109.50. 
The soprano Renee Fleming makes her debut as Violetta in the Houston Grand Opera production of Verdi's "Traviata." Performances at the Wortham Center, Texas Avenue at Smith Street, are at 7:30 p.m. on April 17, 23, 26, 29 and at 8 May 2, and matinees on April 20 and May 4 at 2 o'clock. Tickets range from $20 to $ 275: (800) 626-7372;www.houston grandopera.org.
Houston Rockets fans can cheer on Yao Ming, the celebrated 7-foot-5 center from China, and his teammates at home games, including New Jersey, March 8; Phoenix, March 16; and Los Angeles Lakers, March 26. Games are at 7:30, at Compaq Center, 10 Greenway Plaza East. Tickets are $10 to $112. Call the box office at (713) 627-3865; www .nba.com/rockets.

Sightseeing
The new Downtown Aquarium, Memorial at Bagby, created by Landry's Restaurants, opened last month in a six-acre entertainment and restaurant complex with dancing fountains, a carousel and a shark tank reached by a train through an acrylic tunnel. The enormous underwater tanks hold more than 200 species of marine life, among them seahorses, piranhas, octopuses, jellyfish, electric eels, live coral and stingrays. Theme areas include a Louisiana swamp, a South Seas shipwreck, an Amazon rain forest, a Caribbean reef, a sunken temple and an offshore oil derrick. The Aquarium Restaurant gives the illusion of dining at the bottom of the sea among fish and coral. Exhibits are open Sunday to Thursday 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., Friday and Saturday till 11. Admission, $7.50; (713) 223-3474; www.downtownaquarium.com.
Shopping is practically a blood sport in Houston, which may explain why the Galleria mall is a major attraction. The Galleria, west of downtown near Westheimer Road and West Loop 610, is home to more than 300 upscale retailers, including Neiman Marcus, Cartier and Tiffany. Monday to Saturday 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Sunday noon to 6 p.m.; (713) 622-0663; www.galleriahouston.com.
Many of Houston's oldest and richest families live in the River Oaks neighborhood on sprawling estates shaded by moss-draped oaks. For an inside view visit Rienzi, 1406 Kirby Drive, (713) 639-7800, www.mfah.org, a former private villa that is now the decorative arts wing of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Rienzi features 18th-century English furniture, a collection of Royal Worcester porcelain, paintings and other elegant furnishings. Open Monday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Sunday 1 to 5 p.m. Reservations are required for tours, which run on weekdays about every half hour from 1 to 4 p.m. Admission is $6.

Where to Stay
The Warwick Hotel, 5701 Main Street, (800) 298-6199, fax (713) 526-0359, www.warwickhotelhouston .com, dates from 1925 and has views of Hermann Park in the museum district. A recent renovation updated its 308 spacious, sumptuous rooms and preserved the European-style lobby with tapestries and art collected by the hotel's founder, the oilman John Mecom Sr. Amenities include multi-language voice mail, cable TV, and tile bathrooms. Doubles from $139.
A block from the Galleria, the Doubletree Hotel, 2001 Post Oak Boulevard, (713) 961-9300, fax (713) 961-1557, www.doubletree.com, has 449 comfortable, homey rooms with balconies and two-line phones with dataports. Doubles from $179.
Budget: La Quinta Inn Greenway Plaza, 4015 Southwest Freeway, (713) 623-4750, fax (713) 963-0599, www.lq.com, is conveniently situated on a major freeway south of downtown. Its 131 tastefully furnished rooms, with two doubles or a king-size bed, desk and chairs, are equipped with HBO and coffee makers. Doubles start at $77.
The 50-room EconoLodge North Freeway, 7447 I-45 North, (713) 699-3800, fax (713) 699-3349, www.econolodge.com, between George Bush International Airport and downtown, offers in-room coffee makers, cable TV and double or king beds. Doubles start at $55.
Luxury: It's a pleasant surprise to find a new boutique hotel tucked among the downtown skyscrapers. The 10-story brick Sam Houston Hotel, 1117 Prairie Street, (832) 200-8800; fax (832) 200-8833; www.sam houstonhotel.com, dates to 1924 and reopened in October after an extensive renovation. Its 100 rooms are luxuriously appointed in shades of taupe and brown with fine linens, king-sized beds, flat-panel TV's, marble bathrooms, high-speed Internet lines, DVD players and large desks. Rooms are $289 to $329 ($169 on weekends), suites $499 to $519.
The Houstonian Hotel, Club and Spa, 111 North Post Oak Lane, (800) 231-2759, fax (713) 680-2992, www .houstonian.com, is near the Galleria and at the edge of Memorial Park. Recently renovated, its 280 rooms have floor-to-ceiling windows with wooded views, oversize desks, plush robes and in-room safes. Standard rooms start at $295 (weekends $159).

Where to Eat
In November John Sheely moved his Riviera Grill to the Sam Houston Hotel, 1117 Prairie Street, (832) 200-8888, in a sophisticated space with walls upholstered in beige and taupe. His specialties include olive-oil-poached salmon, roast lamb, sauteed sea scallops with braised fennel. Dinner for two, with wine, is about $100. Breakfast and lunch weekdays, brunch on weekends, dinner nightly.
Cafe Annie, 1728 Post Oak Boulevard, (713) 840-1111, offers such regional cuisine as cocoa-roasted chicken and barbecued sweet potatoes and rabbit enchiladas with red chile mole. In the dramatic space, mahogany walls and ostrich-skin banquettes set off handsome floral arrangements. Dinner for two, with wine, is about $250. Lunch Monday to Friday, dinner Monday to Saturday. 
Hugo's, 1600 Westheimer Road, (713) 524-7744, serves Mexico City-style food (as opposed to Tex-Mex) in an airy space with exposed brick walls, a high pressed-tin ceiling and lots of windows. Specialties include tacos de carnitas (tender shredded pork in a soft corn tortilla), huachinango a la veracruzana (red snapper Veracruz-style) and duck mole. Dinner for two, with margaritas, is about $70. Lunch and dinner daily.
For beef, Fleming's Prime Steakhouse and Wine Bar, 2405 West Alabama Street, (713) 520-5959, is the newest Houston outpost of a chain that serves good steaks, chops, salads and seafood entrees. The setting is stylish, with amber lighting, burnished walls and cozy booths. The wine list includes 100 wines, mostly from the West Coast, available by the glass. Dinner for two with wine, about $80. Dinner daily.
Chacho's, a loud, festive place at 6006 Westheimer Road, (713) 975-9699, offers Tex-Mex combination plates like enchiladas with refried beans and Mexican rice, and entrees like fish tacos or fajitas. Dinner for two, with beer or margaritas, is about $25. Always open.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Renewal Plans in Norwalk Look Away From River

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: NORWALK 

 BODY:
IN the mid-1980's, the City of Norwalk and its Redevelopment Agency devised a plan to rescue South Norwalk from drug dealers, petty crime and burned-out buildings by restoring the 19th-century ship chandleries, stores and flats on and around Washington Street as condominiums, offices, boutiques and restaurants that would attract young professionals and tourists. The agency's concept is now expanding into the 70-acre Reed-Putnam redevelopment area and into traditional downtown Norwalk, areas that were not blighted but were largely ignored during the South Norwalk renaissance. 
 Developers have embarked on new housing, shops and offices, and the state has set aside $20 million for a major infrastructure overhaul that will join South Norwalk to the downtown, giving vehicles and pedestrians a more direct passage between the two districts. 
 These efforts are taking place in spite of a laggard economy and the possibility of war. Mayor Alexander Knopp, who took office in November after serving as a Democratic state representative and Norwalk City Council president, said, "These projects take advantage of the low-interest municipal bond market and private construction firms that are seeking municipal business because there isn't enough private construction to keep their crews together." 
Mountains of newly upturned earth along West Avenue are the first step in fulfilling the Fred F. French Company's commitment to finance and build a $250 million complex of four buildings with a total of 1.15 million square feet of offices, some ground-floor retail space and structured parking for 4,500 cars.
"We are working with the architects, Fox & Fowle," said Timon Malloy, president of Fred F. French Investing L.L.C. of Stamford, "and we are prepared to hold on until the market changes." Meanwhile, when a tenant needing 100,000 square feet or more comes along, he said, "we will start the first building, and if a tenant wanted to build and-or operate a building, we would be interested."
In view of Norwalk's office vacancy rate of 24.6 percent, higher than the rest of Fairfield County, prospects do not appear rosy, but James Fagan, a senior managing director of suburban real estate at CB Richard Ellis in Stamford, said, "That is one of the best located projectsin Fairfield County, at the confluence of I-95 and Route 7, to be built on a beautiful campuslike setting with water views, a few blocks from the South Norwalk train station. Companies that have to make relocation decisions are being cautious, but we've been through this before. Even though there is more space coming on the market, I believe most of the bad news is out there." 
The French company has been acquiring land parcel by parcel for almost a decade. Negotiations are under way for three more parcels that would bring the total to 13 acres, reaching from West Avenue to Interstate 95, at a cost so far of $12 million. The price of three parcels taken by eminent domain has not been determined. The acquisitions include the former Connecticut Limousine depot, which will become a marketing office for Fred F. French. The depot, providing transportation to airports around New York City, has moved to the South Norwalk train station. 
Widening Reed Street and creating an underpass beneath the Danbury branch of the Metro-North Railroad will create a path from West Avenue to Putnam Avenue at the Fred F. French site. An extension of Pine Street will connect West Avenue to River Street near a new housing complex planned by AvalonBay Communities, and widening West Avenue and creating turns will facilitate access to Exits 14 and 15 on I-95. 
In spite of a depressed apartment rental market, AvalonBay expects to build a $50 million complex of 312 units in two four-story buildings on Belden Avenue. The rental complex will replace a mall surrounded by paving and anchored by a Pathmark supermarket, which will be razed. AvalonBay is going through public hearings and reviews by various boards and commissions.
The developer is known for including affordable units in its projects but will not have such units here because, as Mayor Knopp noted, "Norwalk has 12 percent affordable housing -- more than the 10 percent the state wants."
He added, "Avalon residents will jump-start the Wall Street area, bringing people downtown for restaurants and shopping." Wall Street is one of the main business streets in the downtown area.
Units are to have one, two or three bedrooms. Rents are estimated at $1,500 to $2,600 a month and are to include use of an outdoor pool and indoor gym. There are center courtyards in each building, nine-foot ceilings, balconies or decks and lofts in the fourth-floor units. The buildings are to be separated by a mews through which people may stroll down to the river. The entire property will be landscaped, and a riverside walk with benches will be installed. City approval is expected within a year, and occupancy would follow 30 months later.
A third venture, financed by private and public money, is a garage under construction on North Water Street opposite Norwalk's premier tourist attraction, the Maritime Aquarium. Scheduled to open in November, the five-story structure accommodating 780 cars will have a skylight at the top, beaming daylight down through a central atrium and stairway. The first two or three stories of cars will be behind a new complex of shops, 10 condominiums and 3,000 square feet of office space on the North Water Street and Marshall Street sides. A street-level restaurant will face the aquarium. Cars on the upper floors will be behind an exterior wall. 
Beinfeld Wagner & Associates, Norwalk architects, designed the project in partnership with Desmond Associates of New York City and Hartford, specialists in parking structures. The residential units will have one or two bedrooms with sliding translucent fiberglass walls that would allow light through. Oversized windows, exposed steel structural members, stainless steel kitchen counters, stainless steel appliances and 10-foot-high ceilings of matte-finished steel are featured, along with high-tech lighting tracks mounted on steel beams. 
W E wanted to pick up the feeling of the industrial lofts in Lower Manhattan," said Bruce Beinfeld, a partner in the firm, "although these are flats." His company has worked on some 30 design and redesign projects in the city, including the restoration of the Lock Building, the South Norwalk station and the New England Brewing Company and Pub.
Norwalk floated $11 million in bonds for the parking portion of the garage, which it will own and operate. The Spinnaker Companies of Stamford, headed by Clay Fowler, will pay $3 million to build the project and will own the shops, condominiums, restaurant and office space. Spinnaker has an agreement to pay fair market value to purchase a city-owned three-acre parcel north of the aquarium in the future, and Mr. Fowler would build a hotel and several apartment buildings on the site. The city is expecting revenue of about $900,000 in its first year from visitor parking and from leasing garage space to the aquarium and the Lock Building across the street.
A study is under way at the Pinnacle Group in Boston on the feasibility of a 250-room full-service hotel with 20,000 square feet of conference space on the three-acre site. If not, Mr. Malloy said, interest has been shown by hoteliers in the Fred F. French development and in a property occupied by Maritime Motors on West Avenue. 
Beinfeld Wagner and Spinnaker are partners in another condominium project on on Ann Street, around the corner from the garage, offering 34 similarly designed units of 1,000 to 1,200 square feet with some retail space on the ground floor, including an expansion of the Barcelona Restaurant. Apartments in both locations are expected to sell for around $300,000.
State grants of $1.5 million have been used by Stanley M. Seligson Properties to plan for a hotel, offices, 500 rental units and shops on the east side of West Avenue from Orchard Street to Chapel Street. The company already owns some 650,000 square feet of retail, office and distribution space in the city, including Costco, Sports Authority and Toys "R" Us on Route 1, plus several storefronts and Loehmann's Plaza on West Avenue, where a Gap and Huffman Koos furniture store are located. 
Now Mr. Seligson awaits the state's approval of a municipal development plan in which the company asked for substantial city and state subsidies for construction. Timothy Sheehan, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, said, "In this economy subsidies not for public purposes may be hard to come by."
To date, improvements along the west side of the river have turned a neglected wasteland into a charming recreation area. Construction of a quarter-mile elevated pedestrian boardwalk along the river and a large deck jutting out over the water is more than half finished, extending from Heritage Park just north of the aquarium to the I-95 overpass spanning the river. Eventually, it will end at a West Avenue complex that includes the landmarked Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum and the Norwalk Children's Museum. Strollers along the way are already treated to congregations of swans, ducks, kayaks and sailboats.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 9, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in Connecticut and Westchester copies last Sunday about renewal plans for downtown Norwalk misstated the name of a children's museum in an area that will be reached by a riverside boardwalk now being built. It is the Stepping Stones Museum for Children, not the Norwalk Children's Museum.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Which European Stocks Would Hold Up in a War?

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
AS the possibility of war in Iraq unnerves the markets, Ben Funnell, a strategist at Morgan Stanley, has devised a "war basket" of European stocks that he contends will hold up well if shooting starts.
 Mr. Funnell's first advice to investors is to "expect the expected." He referred not just to a war but also to the stock market's path if one breaks out. He noted that the year began with a strong consensus that share prices would fall until war began, then leap as it progressed toward defeat for Iraq, just as in the 1991 Persian Gulf war. But amid the waiting, he said, investors have begun psyching themselves out, reasoning that if everyone is sure that a war will send stocks higher, then maybe it will not. 
 That "makes it all the more likely that expecting the expected might just turn out to be the most profitable, or least unprofitable, way to be invested over the next couple months," he said in a note to clients.
"Keeping it simple, we might well surmise that the most obvious move is the one to trade," he added.
In 1991, markets rallied around the world, with European ones outpacing those in the United States. Some industries in Europe rose much more than others after the land assault began, and Mr. Funnell highlighted four -- transportation, insurance, banking and basic materials -- that he sees as fair bets to beat the market if war occurs again.
To select companies in each sector, he used various growth and valuation criteria, like earnings growth for banks and dividend yield for materials producers, that have correlated most highly with returns over the last decade. That resulted in a list of 16 stocks, including three airlines, Air France and the budget operations Ryanair of Ireland and easyJet of Britain, and two other transportation companies, Copenhagen Airports and Autoroutes du Sud de France, which operates toll roads.
There are four banks -- the Anglo Irish Bank and the Bank of Ireland and two from Italy, Banca Popolare di Verona and UniCredito -- as well as the Swiss reinsurance company Converium and TPG, a Dutch provider of postal services. The remainder are in basic materials: the British paper producer Rexam; two German chemical companies, the Linde Group and BASF; and two suppliers of building materials, CRH of Ireland and Lafarge of France.
Dominic Wallington, a manager of European funds at Invesco, rejected the premise that a new war would amount to a rerun of the previous plot. "I'm slightly skeptical that those who feel the Western economies will be up and running after a short war are right." he said.
Still, he said Mr. Funnell's portfolio, intended for a sharp rally, is not that aggressive. "Funnily enough, quite a few of the stocks in there are quite defensive," Mr. Wallington said. "I'm happy with a relatively defensive stance. The vast majority are stocks we would be quite happy with."
He especially likes the four banks but would drop the airlines. Better choices if a war, even a quick one, doesn't prove to be an economic panacea, he said, include the British water utility Severn Trent and the Spanish tobacco producer Altadis.
GARY DUGAN, global strategist at the J. P. Morgan Private Bank, gave Mr. Funnell's portfolio mixed reviews. His chief objection is that many of the stocks are small and somewhat obscure. In a war rally, he argued, investors are likely to rush into marquee names first. While he agrees that bank stocks would attract buyers, he would favor blue chips like UBS and the Credit Suisse Group in Switzerland, ING in the Netherlands and Deutsche Bank. 
A rally's second wave might include "companies where you believe there will be upgrades to profit forecasts or where there is a restructuring story," Mr. Dugan said.
"You also could see money for names that have held up well in the last 12 months and still are on low valuations," he added. He mentioned Credit Suisse and UBS in this context, too -- Credit Suisse as a restructuring play and UBS as a model of resilience.
A rally's third phase would encompass midsize companies of the sort prominent on Mr. Funnell's list. Mr. Dugan likes the basic-materials sector, including three that Mr. Funnell named: BASF, Linde and Lafarge.
He then added two more materials stocks: Corus, formerly British Steel, and UPM-Kymmene, a Finnish paper company. "These are bigger-cap stocks which would lead their sectors in any rally," he said. He agreed with Mr. Wallington that it would be best to avoid transportation companies and that expecting the expected had limitations. While the situation is similar to the one in 1991, he said, there are important differences. "Then there weren't any other battles to be won," Mr. Dugan said. "There is still a big issue with North Korea and concern about the Middle East and what the U.S. will do next, so I would be hesitant to run in and buy an airline stock. The geopolitical situation won't clear up overnight."

HEADLINE: Financial Backup Sites: How Dispersed? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
UNDER the cobalt-blue glow of ceiling-mounted computer screens, 10 tiered trading pits -- for crude oil, heating oil, unleaded gasoline, natural gas, gold, silver, copper and other commodities -- stretch more than three-quarters of an acre across a windowless room. Snaking among the pits are clusters of traders' booths, nearly 700 of them, linked to the outside by 2,000 telephones.
 This is the New York Mercantile Exchange. But it is not in Battery Park City. It is not even in New York City. The $12 million trading floor sits anonymously on Long Island, ready for an event its builders hope will never come; a disaster great enough to close Lower Manhattan again. 
 "It's a pretty big insurance policy, but we felt we needed it," said Gary Rizzi, a member of the executive committee at the exchange, which was forced to suspend trading for four days after Sept. 11. 
Ever since the attack, financial institutions downtown have struggled with the question of how big a logistical insurance policy they need to guarantee continuity in case of another catastrophe. Naturally, that means diversifying locations where they do business. But then comes the hard part: how close to headquarters should backup and recovery centers be?
"There's a reason financial services tend to be congregated," said Neal L. Wolkoff, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the mercantile exchange. "There's a concentration of expertise, information and paper. Don't discount how much of that there still is."
Each mile of separation buys greater assurance of surviving even the most devastating event. But as distance grows, so do costs. Among the questions: Does the institution intend to recover operations within hours or within a day? Is thebackup site meant to be staffed by employees who normally work at headquarters, or by an entirely different crew? Is a synchronous database needed; that is, duplicate, up-to-the-minute computer records?
And against what calamity is one planning? A nuclear warhead? A radioactive bomb? Poison gas? Poisoned water? Has this hypothetical attack hit headquarters? Or two blocks away? Or across the river? Or at the backup centers, too? Have other institutions been affected? Are telecommunications links still open? And bridges? Tunnels? Subways? Highways?
As if the equation were not complex enough, federal regulators roiled the calculations last August with a draft white paper that asked, "Should some minimum distance from primary sites be specified for core clearing and settlement organizations and firms that play significant roles in critical markets (e.g., 200-300 miles between primary and backup sites)?"
The regulators are widely expected to answer their own question "no," and avoid specifying distances when they issue the final report in a month or so.
But this still leaves financial institutions with the daunting task of trying to plot a tangible response to an unknowable risk. Whether an institution is seeking to place its backup operation a "nuclear distance" from its primary site -- to use the words of Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange -- or is comfortable thinking in less apocalyptic dimensions, the notion of dispersion is on the table.
While such dispersion is widely seen as hurting the Manhattan real estate market, it may be a boon for the New York region. For example, when Morgan Stanley decided last year not to complete the three-building campus it was developing near Times Square, the alternate location it chose was the former Texaco headquarters in Harrison, N.Y.
"In many ways, we're uniquely positioned to take advantage of this trend," said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association in New York. "Alone among large metropolitan regions, we have this network of satellite employment centers that are all linked together -- and to the core -- by a modern transit system and highway system."
With the prospect of war in Iraq, the notion of keeping operations geographically contained may gain appeal. "During the Gulf War, we saw a near shutdown of international business travel," Mr. Yaro said. "At those times, Metro-North and the L.I.R.R. start looking pretty good."
Just how much dispersion is taking place is hard to chart. In the best of times, institutions are reluctant to discuss disaster-recovery plans too specifically in public. And these are not the best of times; especially after the Bush administration declared a "high" terror alert on Feb. 7.
Even general surveys are veiled behind security concerns. Without identifying the companies by location, the Securities Industry Association found last September that 27 of 59 large brokerages, investment banks, commercial banks and mutual funds already had backup data centers more than 30 miles from their primary sites and that 20 of 57 companies had relocation offices more than 30 miles from headquarters.
Taking a different tack, the General Accounting Office said in a report to Congress last month that 10 out of 15 organizations it had surveyed -- exchanges, clearing houses, electronic communication networks and payment system processors -- were at risk of disruption because their backup centers were less than 10 miles from primary sites, or they had no backup centers at all.
The issuance last August of the draft white paper by the Federal Reserve System, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Comptroller of the Currency and the New York State Banking Department created enormous concern that the government would mandate significant geographic dispersion to guarantee the continuity of "core clearing and settlement organizations" and "firms that play significant roles in critical financial markets" in case of a "wide-scale, regional disruption."
Kathryn S. Wylde, the president and chief executive of the Partnership for New York City, said: "This raised a huge issue across the financial-services industry. It started worrying the insurers."
To calm things down, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman; Harvey L. Pitt, who was then the S.E.C. chairman; and Comptroller John D. Hawke Jr. sent a letter in December to Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, who had called the draft white paper a "dagger pointed at the heart of New York."
The regulators denied the charge. "The draft white paper does not recommend as a sound practice that firms move out of center-city locations," they wrote. "Nor does it set specific minimum distance requirements for backup operations or mandate the size of the staff at such operations."
But it did suggest that "out-of-region backup locations should not be dependent on the same labor pool or infrastructure components used by the primary site, and their respective labor pools should not both be vulnerable to simultaneous evacuation or inaccessibility." In the final version of the report, the regulators are expected to ask institutions how they would deploy a single staff in case of a disruption.
After Sept. 11, the stock exchange built a second trading floor, at a cost of $25 million, outside Manhattan but within city limits. (Exchange officials will say no more about its location.) It is to serve only if the Big Board at 11 Wall Street is disabled.
Then the exchange began talking about a third trading floor that would serve as a backup but also function day to day. Mr. Grasso said last September that "to do it right, you have to do it at a nuclear distance" but added a few weeks later that the exchange would build outside New York City only as "a last of last resorts."
Although the exchange has said nothing publicly since then, the third trading floor is still under consideration, according to the General Accounting Office. The exchange has also built an independent telecommunications network with fiber-optic hubs around Boston, Chicago and New York, where the lines are separate from Verizon's widely used underground conduits.
One of the most important institutions downtown, despite its low public profile, is the Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation. Through its subsidiary, the National Securities Clearing Corporation, it processes nearly 14 million transactions a day, including most of the trading volume of the Big Board, Nasdaq, American Stock Exchange, regional stock exchanges and electronic trading networks.
Although it had backup centers before Sept. 11, it is planning to "further decentralizing both facilities and people," said a spokesman, Stuart Z. Goldstein. Without elaborating, he said the corporation would have no problem meeting a requirement for backup sites in other regions.
DEPOSITORY TRUST kept operating immediately after the attack but the Bank of New York, which is also an important clearing organization, was badly disrupted. On Sept. 11, 2001, it had more than 8,300 employees within 400 yards of the World Trade Center in headquarters at 1 Wall Street, a computer center at 101 Barclay Street, and space at 100 Church Street and 75 Park Place. The 25-story computer center was so heavily damaged that it did not reopen until July.
Yet in testifying to federal regulators against a 200-to-300-mile separation rule, Donald R. Monks, senior executive vice president of the bank, said, "The events of 9/11 taught us that in a regional disaster, especially one caused by a terrorist act, air transport may be unavailable for days, and geographic obstacles such as rivers may become impassable if the authorities order the closing of bridges and tunnels.
"Further, there is a human element to this equation," he said. "Employees will have natural concerns about the safety of their families and their homes, and may not be willing to relocate hundreds of miles away to staff a distant processing site when they are needed most at home.
"None of this is to suggest that distance is not desirable," Mr. Monks said. "Contingency sites should be miles, not city blocks or hundreds of yards, from the primary operations sites that they support. However, this means that the contingency site will have to be within something approximating 'normal commuting distance' of the primary site."
The bank has taken that step with its plan to move 1,500 employees from 100 Church Street to a new 14-story, 400,000-square-foot office building at Atlantic Terminal, a mixed-use complex at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues in Brooklyn that is being developed by Forest City Ratner Companies. The $240 million project is to be finished next year. The architects are Swanke Hayden Connell.
"The bulk of the labor force they focused on lived in Brooklyn," said Robert Stillman, senior managing director of Insignia/ESG, which represented the bank. He said the bank had to balance accommodating those workers with the need for greater distance between operations.
The project will adjoin the station at which the Long Island Rail Road intersects with the 2, 3, 4, 5 and Q subway lines -- a decided advantage, even at a time of general worry about the vulnerability of such transit hubs.
"The main concern of the Bank of New York was that they not be physically over the railroad," said Bruce C. Ratner, the president and chief executive of Forest City Ratner. He said the bank was assuaged because its building would stand on a portion of the site above solid ground.
Unlike a pure disaster-recovery center, the Brooklyn building is to operate as a back office in the normal course of business. But every other work station is wired for a second telephone and computer, Mr. Monks said, meaning that 750 employees could be added. The bank also has several hundred employees in upstate New York and Florida who could immediately assume critical responsibilities, in what Mr. Monks described as a pilot and co-pilot arrangement.
The Brooklyn deal underscored a point that city officials have been trying to make since the white paper was issued, said Andrew M. Alper, president of the Economic Development Corporation: that New York has a "geographic scale that allows you to separate operations but keep them close enough that you can get back and forth."
The New York Board of Trade, which lost its headquarters at 4 World Trade Center, has been operating for the last year and a half from a backup center in Long Island City, Queens. On Wednesday, it announced it would lease 45,000 square feet at the mercantile exchange in Battery Park City.
The mercantile exchange itself suffered no appreciable damage in the attack. But it learned that a backup site only a few blocks away -- 22 Cortlandt Street -- was useless under warlike conditions.
"Nobody -- obviously including ourselves -- thought of buildings being attacked like that," Mr. Wolkoff said. Though the exchange had generators, it lost its water supply. Without water, air-conditioning cannot be run and neither can computers.
After the attack, exchange officials regrouped at a Midtown hotel and then made a foray by boat to headquarters, where they retrieved computer tapes.
"We realized that while we could recover electronically," Mr. Wolkoff said, "we didn't want to be in a position where we couldn't recover open-outcry trading."
The exchange estimated that members and employees were fairly evenly distributed around Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester. It looked in all three areas before settling on Long Island. (As a condition for allowing a reporter and photographer to visit, the exchange asked that its specific location not be divulged.)
Construction began in April and the floor was ready in October. It is expected to cost nearly $1 million a year to rent, operate and keep at the ready. For example, the exchange is paying to keep a constant dial tone on 2,000 phones, with 1,000 more phone lines reserved for its use if needed.
"We could come in the next day and start trading," said Mitchell Steinhause, vice chairman. The exchange would expect 3,500 to 4,000 people at the alternate site.
At Battery Park City are two 25,000-square-foot trading floors, one for the Nymex division, which deals largely in petroleum products, and the other for Comex, which deals largely in precious metals, and the board of trade. There is only one floor in Long Island, but Nymex pits are on one side and Comex pits on another, arranged so that traders can keep watch on related activity. "It's a different address," Mr. Steinhause said, "but when you walk on the floor, it's the same."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Ad Business Outlook May Be Brightening

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IN 1917, Norman Douglas, a British author and diplomat, wrote, "You can tell the ideals of a nation by its advertisements." 
 The contemporary world might have altered his view. Last year, global advertising revenue was nearly $450 billion, according to Universal McCann, a division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Nearly half of that figure was spent in the United States. That's a lot of ideals. 
 Lauren Rich Fine, an advertising and marketing services analyst at Merrill Lynch, talked last week about the business of advertising. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

Q. Last year, conditions seemed to stabilize for advertising companies. Is the business turning up?

A. If it weren't for the prospect of war, I think that within the next three months to six months we would have a full-blown recovery. In the last six months of 2002, clients did increase media expenditures. Television stations reported double-digit numbers. Radio started to move higher, as did newspapers. The agencies had started to see a pickup. Now, people aren't cutting back, but they are postponing decisions until there is more clarity.

Q. How fast does advertising revenue tend to grow?

A. Over long periods of time, advertising revenue has grown in line with nominal increases in gross domestic product. But it clearly underperformed gross domestic product growth in 2001 and 2002, and we don't know what will happen this year. We think it will come close to nominal G.D.P. growth this year, and in 2004 will slightly outpace G.D.P. growth.

Q. Are the companies in this highly creative, competitive business just plodding along?

A. If an ad agency is gaining market share, it will outpace the cycle. Investors are trying to pick the sweet spot, those that will outpace the market.

Q. The business has consolidated. At the end of 2001, the top 10 ad organizations controlled nearly 70 percent of the global market, compared with almost 30 percent in 1989. Does that limit their ability to grow?

A. Because the companies have gotten so large, it will be harder and harder for them to sustain above-average growth.

Q. So what is the investor profile for these stocks?

A. The investor profile has changed quite a bit. For years, a company like Interpublic was considered a widows-and-orphans stock. Since last summer, it has become more controversial because of the suggestion of accounting irregularities. And Omnicom has a similar cloud over it. As a result of that, the whole group has been painted as more speculative than it was in the past.

Q. The stocks were highfliers back in the late 1990's, when they were riding the technology/dot-com wave. Have the advertising downturn and the worries about accounting turned them into value stocks?

A. Omnicom is currently trading at about an 11 to 12 percent discount to the Standard & Poor's 500 index. For a time in the late 1990's, it was trading at a premium of anywhere from 30 percent to 50 percent, partly due to the dot-com mania.

Q. Are the accounting issues a significant concern?

A. Investors are concerned about what might happen at Interpublic, which is the subject of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In my mind there isn't anything to resolve at Omnicom.

Q. Do you recommend any of the stocks?

A. Our analyst in Europe has a buy rating on WPP, which trades American depository receipts in this country.
Otherwise, we like Omnicom and Alliance Data, a marketing services company. 
We like Omnicom because they have the best advertising agencies in the world, BBDO, DDB and TBWA. As a result of that, they get to pitch the most new business, they win the most new business and they grow at the fastest rate. So, we like the quality of their assets, their strategic vision and the valuation of the stock, especially given their growth rate. 
Alliance Data does private-label transaction processing for companies like Limited and Ann Taylor. I like the fact they have posted really good growth numbers. Their long-term targets are 12 percent revenue growth, 15 percent earnings growth before interest, depreciation and amortization and 18 percent cash earnings per share growth. They have been hitting those numbers.

Q. The Interpublic board of directors demoted the company's chairman and chief executive last week. Would you stay away from the stock?

A. I can't advise anyone to buy Interpublic shares yet. This has been a company under pressure for a couple of years. It is in disarray, and has seen some large clients leave over the last couple of months.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
A NewHealth Plan Works, at Least for the Healthy

BYLINE:  By BETH KOBLINER 

 BODY:
AT this time last year, if Shalonda Welborn or a member of her family had to see a doctor, she would have had to chip in a $15 co-payment. But this year, she expects to pay no money out of pocket.
 Last fall, Mrs. Welborn, 32, a senior training specialist in corporate development, signed up for a new kind of health coverage, called a health reimbursement arrangement, or H.R.A. As part of the plan, her employer, CompuCom Systems, an information technology service provider in Dallas, has given her a $2,000 health care savings account that she can use to pay for medical care. 
 But Mrs. Welborn's new plan also comes with a hefty deductible of $3,400. That means that if she spends more than her allotted $2,000 in the account this year, she will be liable for the next $1,400 of expenses. After she reaches the deductible, the insurance plan kicks in; it will cover 80 percent of costs, if network doctors are used, and 60 percent if not. 
But if any of the $2,000 remains in her account at year-end, she can add it to the next $2,000 CompuCom will set aside for her in 2004.
Mrs. Welborn expects to do just that. She says she and the other members of her family -- her husband, Gary, and her daughter, Madisyn -- have no long-term health problems. "I like the idea that I may not have to pay any money this year except for my premiums, and I like having control over what I spend," she said. She said that the premiums for her plan were $136 a month, or about 40 percent lower than they would have been under her old coverage. 
Right now, only about 300,000 to 400,000 people -- less than half of 1 percent of all insured employees -- participate in H.R.A.'s. But this small group is being studied closely by benefits consultants, policy experts and insurance companies. Employers are awaiting evidence that H.R.A.'s, commonly marketed as consumer-driven plans, will help contain the cost of health care. The cost of employer-paid premiums rose 12.7 percent last year, the second consecutive year of double-digit increases, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, a nonprofit research group in Menlo Park, Calif.
Consumer-driven plans have gained momentum since the Internal Revenue Service issued regulations in June encouraging their use. A recent poll by Mercer Human Resource Consulting found that 7 percent of employers with 20,000 or more employees offer consumer-driven plans, and an additional 14 percent say that they are likely to have them in the next two years. Most offer these plans as an option among other types of coverage. 
Employer-sponsored health care is currently dominated by health maintenance organizations and preferred provider organizations. More than one in four employees are enrolled in H.M.O.'s, which limit workers to a network of doctors and tend to require preapproval for specialists. Employees pay a small co-payment, generally $10 to $20, for each doctor visit and prescription. An additional 52 percent of employees are enrolled in P.P.O.'s, which give them access to a wider choice of doctors but also impose a deductible for out-of-network care, currently averaging $275.
Consumer-driven plans are variations on P.P.O.'S and H.M.O.'s, but with two important differences: they carry considerably higher deductibles, often around $1,500 for individuals and $3,000 for families; and employers cushion these higher deductibles at the front end, by financing individual cash accounts ranging from a few hundred to several thousand dollars.
Employees can use these accounts to cover their medical spending, and in some cases treatments not usually covered by health insurance. Those who do not deplete their accounts may roll over the remaining money from year to year, generally up to limits that vary by company. Mrs. Welborn, for example, can have a maximum of $6,000 in her account.
Unlike participants in H.M.O.'s and P.P.O.'s, those with consumer-driven plans must pay the full fare for everything from doctor's visits to prescription drugs, until they meet their deductibles and the insurance coverage takes over.
The major purveyors of these plans are a handful of small companies that are not insurers but administrators, including Definity Health in St. Louis Park, Minn.; Lumenos in Alexandria, Va.; and Destiny Health in Bethesda, Md. Insurance companies like Aetna and Humana have recently begun offering consumer-driven plans alongside their other offerings.
Proponents of consumer-driven plans contend that they will cut costs for employers by giving employees a sense of ownership over the money they spend, and with it, an incentive to spend more wisely. The current system of small co-payments, they say, isolates consumers from the true costs of health care. To encourage employees to avoid unnecessarily expensive treatments and visits to emergency rooms, marketers of these plans offer features like Web sites, nurse help lines and detailed information on generic drugs. 
Many health care analysts say the newness of consumer-driven plans makes it hard to predict their effect on health care costs. "The hope is that people will view that $1,000 account as their own money and be more cost-conscious, but there's no hard data yet to tell you whether that is true or not," said Jon Gabel, vice president for health system studies at the Health Research and Educational Trust in Chicago and one of the leading experts on these plans. Mr. Gabel also wonders "whether employers will save by giving $1,000 to a healthy 25-year-old who up until now never spent anything on health care." 
Other analysts question whether consumer self-interest can significantly curb health care inflation. "In the long run, it's not at all clear that making people sensitive about taking their children to the doctor when they are only a little sick will affect the things that are really driving health care costs, like technology and new treatments," said Gary Claxton, a vice president at Kaiser.
Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a health care advocacy group in Washington, says employees may be hurt. "The concern is that these plans are part of the process of passing on more costs to the shoulder of workers," he said. 
Many agree, though, that cash accounts are an attractive option for people who spend little on health care in a given year. A 1998 study by the Employee Benefits Research Institute found that 50 percent of employees spent less than $600 a year on health care. 
Todd Barre, 35, director of budget and planning and information technology at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, chose a consumer-driven plan last July for himself; his wife, Donna, a 35-year-old preschool teacher; and their three children. The plan's cash account gives them $2,000, but he also has to pay monthly premiums of $293, slightly less than they would be under his old plan. Mr. Barre said he has spent about $1,000 so far and expects to roll over money to the next plan year. 
For employees whose expenditures exceed the cash account, consumer-driven plans may end up being more expensive than other options. For example, at Pharmacia, the pharmaceutical company based in Peapack, N.J., the out-of-pocket cost of having a baby can vary significantly, depending on the plan chosen. The same medical care would cost an employee $160 in the company's H.M.O., $835 in the P.P.O. and $1,300 in the consumer-driven plan, according to Pattie Duca, Pharmacia's executive director of global benefits. 
SOME people in consumer-driven plans may be startled by how much health care can actually cost. Out of 906 employees who enrolled last year in the consumer-driven health plan offered by Charter Communications, a cable television company based in St. Louis, 115 have moved back to the Blue Cross P.P.O. "I don't think some of the people in it were prepared for the research and understood that the full amount of a prescription would be deducted from their account," said Karen Bellm, manager of health and welfare benefits.
The risk of running through an account is one that many enrollees have said they are willing to bear. "Employees like the greater flexibility of these plans," Ms. Duca said. According to Definity Health, Lumenos and Destiny Health, the re-enrollment rate for their plans was at least 95 percent last year.
But Mr. Pollack of Families USA is still wary that the plans could skim off the healthiest employees, leaving the sicker ones in H.M.O.'s and P.P.O.'s, resulting in higher premiums.

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Belt-Loosening in the Work Force

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
DOES work make you fat?
 Some economists are suggesting that the answer is yes. The huge increase in the number of working women, they say, and a concomitant decrease in home-cooked meals, may be leading Americans to eat more fast food, with predictable consequences for waistlines. 
 The economists -- Shin-Yi Chou, Henry Saffer and Michael Grossman -- presented their findings in a working paper called "An Economic Analysis of Obesity" for the National Bureau of Economic Research. In the paper, the economists note that the number of fast-food restaurants per capita doubled in the United States from 1972 to 1997, a period in which obesity, well, ballooned. 
In analyzing the relationship of weight to incomes, food prices, restaurants, workforce participation and other variables, the economists concluded that the growth of fast food accounted for 68 percent of the rise in American obesity. Why all this fast food? 
As women devoted more time to paid work, the theory goes, they had less time for cooking, a burden that the men in their lives (who typically spend more time at their jobs) presumably had little time or interest in assuming. Fast-food restaurants -- offering cheap, convenient meals dense with fat and calories -- rushed in to fill the vacuum. 
If the economists are right, their findings have surprising implications about work and its rewards in the modern economy. Consider first that obesity is expensive; according to a study published in 1998 in Obesity Research, the medical costs alone were $99 billion in 1995. Obesity may well be the nation's biggest public health problem; a study by the RAND Corporation last year said it was more serious than smoking or heavy drinking. "Obesity appears to have a stronger association with the occurrence of chronic medical conditions, reduced physical health-related quality of life and increased health care and medication expenditures than smoking or problem drinking," said Roland Sturm, a RAND economist and author of the study.
Obesity might well be a hidden tax on work -- a regressive one, since it falls disproportionately on lower-income workers, who are more likely to be overweight yet less able to bear its costs. But as Dr. Chou, Dr. Grossman and Dr. Saffer point out, about half of all health care is paid for by federal, state and local governments. Obesity, it would seem, is a problem like air pollution; both are serious side effects of economic development. 
All these medical costs imply that the American workplace is less safe than it seems. Yes, unintentional workplace fatalities have fallen to 4 per 100,000 workers from 37 per 100,000 in 1933, according to the National Safety Council. But if working raises body weight, these numbers do not tell the whole story. Obesity kills just as surely as industrial accidents once did; an analysis published in 1999 in The Journal of the American Medical Association put the number of adult obesity deaths at 280,000 to 325,000 annually.
It's possible that by reducing traditional workplace hazards and making all work less strenuous, Americans have increased the risk from obesity, which is related to a sedentary life. About a year ago, the economists Darius Lakdawalla and Tomas Philipson, in a different paper for the economic research bureau, asserted that less strenuous work and cheaper food -- both products of technology -- are to blame for the rise of obesity in America. 
BOTH papers imply that the epidemic of fat -- three in five Americans are overweight -- is what Edward Tenner, author of "Why Things Bite Back: Technology and the Revenge of Unintended Consequences" (Vintage Books, 1997) might have called a "revenge effect." It is the kind of unintended consequence that often flows from new technologies and social change.
Obesity arising from more (and safer) work is a dispiriting manifestation of this syndrome, but Dr. Chou, Dr. Grossman and Dr. Saffer have come up with an even nastier one: the war on cigarettes, they observe, is making people fatter, too, simply because smoking, however harmful, causes people to eat less.
Harried workers may eventually become wise to hazards of fast food, just as many people have done with tobacco. Perhaps the idea that work contributes to obesity will help defeat stereotypes about overweight people. "An Economic Analysis of Obesity" can be read as strong evidence that they're not lazy. Just busy (at their desks).

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Joseph C. Williams III; 
Commerce Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
INVESTORS' tendency to overreact to news has worsened in the last six months or so, says Joseph C. Williams III, who runs the $180 million Commerce Growth fund.
 "Before, prices of individual stocks might drop 10 to 15 percent on bad news," he said from his office in Kansas City, Mo. "Now they can drop more than 30 percent within minutes, where it used to be days." 
 The extreme volatility gives money managers tremendous opportunity, he added, and throws into sharp focus one aspect of their jobs: to decipher whether a price decline is justified. 
His analysis has put him ahead of most of his peers lately, though the fund has still lost money. It declined 16.5 percent a year, on average, in the three years through Thursday, placing among the top 15 percent of funds that buy large growth stocks. That group lost 22.8 percent a year, on average, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 13.2 percent, annualized, according to Morningstar Inc. The fund has lost 23.1 percent in the last 12 months, versus losses of 25.8 percent for its group and 23.3 percent for the index.
Mr. Williams, 49, is a senior vice president for Commerce Investment Advisors, the fund's adviser and a subsidiary of Commerce Bancshares. The fund's "service shares," or retail shares, carry a 3.5 percent front-end load, or sales charge, but institutional shares are available without a load through mutual fund supermarkets.
To choose the 45 to 55 stocks in the fund, Mr. Williams ranks roughly 550 growth stocks with market capitalizations of at least $500 million, looking for potential price appreciation, earnings growth and attractive valuations.
In gauging a company, his computer model uses about 15 variables, including the quarterly and 12-month projected earnings growth rates, changes in earnings estimates from Wall Street analysts, and a rising stock price compared with others in its industry and the Russell 1000 Growth index.
From the resulting list of companies, he reviews the strongest 20 percent for how they might fit in the portfolio. He compares, for example, the sector weightings of the fund to those of the Russell index.
Mr. Williams sometimes gives individual industries up to six percentage points of extra weight, compared with the index. But these days, the portfolio's sector allocations essentially mirror those of the index. 
"It's very difficult to make big bets until the Iraq situation becomes clearer, which will drive what the economy does," he said.
He also reviews a company's historical price-to-earnings multiple, then checks the PEG ratio -- comparing a company's current P/E multiple to its estimated three-year earnings growth rate. While industries vary, he said, he is finding good companies that sell for one to one and a half times their projected earnings growth rate.
He never meets with companies' management. "When you deal with big companies," he said, "it's hard to find out something from management that's not already known on Wall Street."
Walgreens, the drugstore chain based in Deerfield, Ill., has been a steady long-term grower, Mr. Williams said, though its shares have been expensive, generally trading for 30 to 50 times earnings in the last five years or so. When that multiple dropped to about 27 in January, he began buying. The stock's PEG ratio is about 1.45, based on a three-year earnings growth rate of 16 percent.
He paid $30.91, on average, for the entire position. The shares are now at $28.14. 
Walgreens has had lackluster growth in same-store sales -- those for stores open at least a year -- but still looks good in comparison to its competitors, he said.
MR. WILLIAMS began buying shares of the Symantec Corporation, based in Cupertino, Calif., last May. Symantec, the Internet security technology company that produces Norton antivirus software, should continue growing steadily, he said, adding, "Sept. 11 spurred everyone's interest in security, even among personal computer owners."
He said that he expects the company's earnings growth to average about 19 percent a year over the next three years, versus 13.5 percent for Microsoft. But he said Symantec's shares are much cheaper, trading at a PEG ratio of 1.4 based on three-year earnings, versus 1.7 for Microsoft.
He paid $33.24 for his Symantec shares; they are now at $40.47.
More sophisticated genetic testing techniques should drive the growth of Quest Diagnostics, a provider of lab testing services that is based in Teterboro, N.J., Mr. Williams said. "Its costs are fixed," he said, "so it's a good long-term growth story." 
He said that he expects earnings growth of 26 percent a year in the next three to five years, but that the stock was inexpensive, with a PEG ratio of 0.48, because of investors' concerns that hospitals and doctor's offices will do more in-house testing. But he predicts that Quest will benefit from the aging of the population and from industry consolidation. He paid $61.06 for shares in August 2001; they now trade at $52.76.
