HEADLINE: Business; 
Brokers to Bankers: 'No Trespassing'

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT was just a few lines of dense legalese in a 3,000-page-plus spending bill, but the provision was a turning point in a bitter struggle between two of the most powerful business lobbies in the capital -- real estate and banking.
 The relevant words in Section 646 of the Treasury portion of the spending bill said: "None of the funds made available in this act may be used to finalize, implement, administer or enforce (1) the proposed rule relating to the determination that real estate brokerage is an activity that is financial in nature." 
 It meant this: Banks cannot get into the real-estate brokerage business.
In allowing that 11th-hour add-on to a $397 billion spending bill, Republican Congressional leaders handed the nation's real estate brokers an important symbolic victory -- if perhaps a temporary one -- in their concerted push to keep banks at bay.
The story of how this extraneous bit of policy wound up in a long-overdue appropriations measure is a classic example of how Washington works and how well-connected players can have their problems addressed even when the most logical legislative route is cut off. 
The maneuver was the latest episode in a two-year feud that has made rivals out of bankers and brokers who often work together to close property deals. It has also frayed relationships on Capitol Hill and forced lawmakers to choose between dependable deep-pocketed political allies.
"I'm very glad it is over," said Representative Anne M. Northup, Republican of Kentucky, who engineered the provision and earned the deep enmity of the banking industry in the process. "They are very angry."
Angry in part because real estate sales generated $54 billion in commissions last year, according to an estimate by Steve Murray, an editor of Real Trends, an industry newsletter in Littleton, Colo. A move into the real estate brokerage business also would be an efficient way for banks to increase their mortgage lending, as several joint ventures between banks and brokerages have demonstrated.
Because so much is at stake -- and despite Ms. Northup's exclamation -- this battle is almost certainly not over, according to many involved.
Under the spending bill, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve are prohibited through Sept. 30 from moving ahead with a new regulation that would enable nationally chartered banks to offer real estate sales services. The banking lobby says it still intends to seek that power in the future and will fight a pending measure that would permanently bar national banks from the real estate business.
"We feel pretty good about our chances," said Edward L. Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association.
The battle between banks and brokers dates back to the adoption of major changes in financial services law in 1999. At the time, Congress freed banks to engage in new kinds of services like selling insurance and financial securities and opened the door to further expansion into areas judged by Treasury and the Fed to be "financial in nature" or "incidental to a financial activity."
Seizing the moment, the nation's bankers in mid-2000 petitioned under the new law to make the leap into real estate. Later that year, the Clinton administration proposed a rule to allow it.
The National Association of Realtors, sensing a major competitive threat, quickly fought back. It marshaled hundreds of thousands of its 800,000 members across the country to register their objections and reached out to allies on Capitol Hill.
"This issue is all about who is going to control the real estate transaction," said Stephen Cook, a spokesman for the association, explaining why thwarting the banks quickly became the No. 1 legislative priority of the Realtors. 
The brokers argue that the change could lead to a nationwide consolidation in the industry, one that could ultimately cut competition, hurt service and drive up fees to consumers. The bankers say that large realty companies are already deep into mortgage financing and that banks need to be able to compete nationwide when half of the states already allow state-chartered banks to sell property.
A measure barring the banks was introduced and attracted significant support, but it stalled in the House and Senate committees with jurisdiction over banking. Those panels traditionally have strong political ties to the industry. Phil Gramm, then chairman of the Senate Banking Committee and an author of the measure that cleared the way for such expansions, was dead set against the restriction, one banking lobbyist said.
But there was still the Appropriations Committee, where Ms. Northup served on the subcommittee that allocates money for the Treasury Department. The holder of a bachelor's degree in economics, she was not happy about the bankers' push for new real estate business. At the time the financial services overhaul was passed in 1999, she said, no one was talking about such a big change.
But as one of the few incumbent House members in a highly competitive district, she was not eager to alienate a dependable ally and potential source of campaign financing. "When you win every election with 50 percent of the vote, you are not dying to pick a fight with anybody," she said.
Yet she said she was convinced that allowing banks to get into real estate was a bad idea. "Financial services and commercial services should stay separate," she said, contending that there are inherent conflicts in both selling property and financing the sale.
With backing from the Realtors as well as a coalition that included consumer advocates and small businesses, Ms. Northup persuaded the Appropriations Committee last July to adopt her moratorium as part of the Treasury spending bill.
The political repercussions for Ms. Northup were almost immediate. A state bankers group sponsored a fund-raiser for her Democratic opponent and blistered her in newsletters. But real estate interests donated almost $100,000 to her re-election campaign, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, and she won.
THE moratorium proposal, along with almost all spending legislation other than for the military, stalled amid partisan battles in Congress. But after the Congressional elections last year -- a last chance for Realtors and bankers to donate money to sympathetic candidates -- Republicans widened their lead in the House and regained control of the Senate.
Congress was still unable to pass a spending bill last year, but in January Republican leaders met behind closed doors to put together a final spending package.
Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio and chairman of the Financial Services Committee, was adamantly opposed to the Realtors' provision, and Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas and the majority leader, was inclined to resist it, a House aide said.
But in the Senate, Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, had just succeeded Mr. Gramm as chairman of the Banking Committee, and he wanted the provision in. He was an ally of the real estate groups in this fight and spoke at the association's meeting in New Orleans last November. More important, he was also a senior member of the Appropriations Committee, giving him a prime seat at the conference table in deciding what appeared in the final bill.
"If banks get into real estate, they might as well sell jewelry next and cars and batteries and clothes," said Mr. Shelby, who said he was also worried that banks might have to be bailed out if their real estate operations faltered. "Some of this could visit the taxpayer again."
As the final spending measure came together in mid-February, the fight between the bankers and Realtors was among the last to be decided. The leadership finally chose to include the provision as a concession to Realtors, calculating that the bankers would not be too irked because the moratorium would last only seven months. "It kind of puts it off for a while, but I don't think it has any practical effect," said one Republican aide in the House.
The Realtors celebrated nonetheless, saying Congressional approval of the temporary ban should be interpreted as a sign that lawmakers don't want banks in the real estate business.
"There is now a clear Congressional vote on this issue," said Mr. Cook, the spokesman for the brokers. "We are very encouraged." A new measure establishing a permanent ban on the banks is already drawing support, including Mr. Shelby's.
The bankers found reason for optimism as well. They believe that House Banking Committee members are now so angry over the back-door effort by the Realtors to use the appropriations process that they will be sympathetic.
"It is going to be a very, very hard fight," said Mr. Yingling, the bankers' lobbyist. "But assuming the moratorium at some point comes off, the reality is that the Realtors still have to get a bill through Congress. Passing a bill is much, much harder than defending a bill."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2040 words

HEADLINE: China: Partner, Rival or Both? 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
TO hear the alarmists tell it, the emergence of China as an economic superstar is bad news that is only growing worse. Their familiar cries -- China has an unlimited supply of cheap labor that threatens American workers, China stacks the deck against foreign companies that invest there, China will destroy American manufacturing -- were recently reinforced with a new one: last year, for the first time, China probably bested the United States as the world's top choice for foreign investment.
 China's economic firepower is real, and growing fast. It will inevitably affect the American economy. There is some truth in the alarmists' warnings, but they hardly tell the whole story. 
 China's influence takes many forms that are subtler than the loss of low-wage manufacturing jobs in theUnited States or the opening of a huge new consumer market in China. The costs and benefits of the trans-Pacific relationship are much more complex than simple gains and losses from trade. They extend to the bedrock of the American economy, including the productivity of the labor force and the stability of financial markets. 
"Our fates are becoming inextricably linked," said Paul A. Laudicina, vice president and managing director of the global business policy council at A. T. Kearney, a consulting firm. "China is as important to the U.S. as the U.S. is to China."
Recent figures on trade and investment can overshadow other important trends. Since 1997, the United States trade deficit in goods with China has doubled to more than $95 billion. The trade surplus with China in services, which make up more than half of the American economy, increased by more than 50 percent, but just to $2.2 billion in 2001.
The estimated totals for direct foreign investment are a trifle misleading. The American figure declined mainly because of a drop in mergers and acquisitions involving foreign companies, which have accounted for 90 percent of investment flows in recent years.
Even when these figures are interpreted correctly, however, they are only excerpts from a story with much wider consequences. China's growth has been reinforcing one of the most prominent trends in America's recent economic history: its transition from a manufacturing to a service economy. In the last two years alone, the economy has shed two million manufacturing jobs. Now, only about 16 million Americans work in manufacturing, the same as in the early 1950's. Since then, though, the number of Americans in service professions has risen to 107 million from about 30 million.
China is "accelerating the structural change" taking place in the United States, said Daniel J. Meckstroth, chief economist of the Manufacturers Alliance/MAPI. "We're moving the high-labor-cost jobs, the low-technology jobs and the low-capital-intensive jobs abroad."
The manufacturing sector was doomed to shrink, he said, because its productivity has grown faster than the overall economy. But the acceleration of the process has come at a bad time for many workers.
"What makes it so painful is that it's occurring in a period where the U.S. economy is weak," Mr. Meckstroth said. "This recovery is abysmally slow, particularly in the manufacturing sector." Because China maintains a fixed exchange rate with the dollar, he added, that economic weakness does not help American companies pump up their exports.
SOME types of manufacturing have already deserted the United States entirely. For Mattel, the toy maker, all production is now done overseas, said Thomas A. Debrowski, its executive vice president for operations. His options for production include China and other developing countries, not the United States, he said.
Robert C. Feenstra, an economics professor at the University of California at Davis, defended Mattel's model. "Some people would object to having U.S. firms locate abroad and leave us," he said. "I, on the contrary, would say, 'That's what they've got to do to stay competitive.' " Profits garnered as a result of foreign activities, he noted, still flow back to American investors.
American manufacturing may feel China's influence doubly, Professor Feenstra added, because its labor force could enhance the manufacturing power of more advanced economies on the Pacific Rim. "We're going to be competing with these other countries -- Japan, Taiwan, Korea -- who are using China as a source of cheap labor," he said. He added that any labor-cost advantage that American companies might have reaped through Nafta, by moving operations to Mexico or Canada, might therefore be neutralized.
There is little doubt that Asian nations are taking advantage of China's production base. In Korea, more than half of companies responding to a recent survey by the Federation of Small and Medium Business said they planned to invest in China in the next five years.
Mattel has been producing miniature cars in China for years. But it makes jungle gyms and tricycles in Mexico, because freight makes up a bigger share of the cost for such "large cube" items.
"If you take a look at some of our competition, they're using very much the same model that we are," Mr. Debrowski said. "They have to. If you want to be competitive with large-cube product, and you want to source it in China, you're going to go bankrupt pretty quick." In Mexico, he said, "our competitors are right across the street from us."
The same pattern holds in other industries, like consumer electronics. Sony, Samsung, Philips and Thomson (which makes RCA products) are all based in different countries, and they all assemble televisions in Mexico.
Despite China's influence and the general trend, manufacturing still has a future, if a smaller one, in the United States.
"There are some advantages to being in this country," said Roger W. Chastain, the chief executive of Mount Vernon Mills, a textile maker in Greenville, S.C. Big clients like Wal-Mart, he said, often need to restock their inventories on a few days' notice, with many different products packed in the same container. "There's always going to be some need" for manufacturing in the United States, "so you can have the quick turns; it can't come from China," Mr. Chastain said. 
Though most sewing of garments is done overseas, he explained, the fact that Mount Vernon makes the raw textiles in the United States gives it an edge in filling just-in-time orders. Eventually, he said, "the only difference may become transportation costs, more so than labor."
New labor markets have started to become a consideration for American service businesses, though, even as manufacturers take them for granted. Some white-collar jobs that would traditionally have resided in the United States are moving to China. Five years ago, both Intel and Microsoft announced the opening of major research centers there. In 1999, Motorola decided to make Beijing its global center for research and development, with a target work force of 5,000 within five years. Motorola also has large manufacturing plants in Tianjin and Hangzhou.
Motorola and Mattel, like many other American companies, are looking to China's consumer market, as well as its production base, as potential help for the bottom line. China's entry into the World Trade Organization 14 months ago coincided with the economic downturn in the United States, causing even the biggest companies to look abroad for profits.
"The U.S. auto manufacturers had a fantastic year in China, and a relatively lackluster year elsewhere in terms of profitability," Mr. Laudicina of A. T. Kearney said.
Motorola sees China as a profit leader. "China remains a critical part of our global sales and sourcing operations," said Jennifer Weyrauch, a spokeswoman for Motorola. "As of 2001, China was 13 percent of Motorola's overall sales."
China has not yet provided a vast market for every American product. Last fall, Sigma-Aldrich, a conglomerate based in St. Louis that sells small batches of complex chemicals, opened a four-employee sales office in Shanghai. Nonetheless, said Michael R. Hogan, the company's chief financial officer and chief administrative officer, "it would be quite a while before we'd be setting up a manufacturing facility in China."
"We tend to serve research markets for pharmaceutical and biotech companies," he said. "China does not have that kind of infrastructure, even among their academic institutions." As China becomes wealthier, Mr. Hogan predicted, its demand for research materials will increase.
Profits can also come from China's cheaper raw materials -- something that Sigma-Aldrich might soon consider. "Historically, people did not source from China because the prices were dirt cheap but their quality was not certain," Mr. Hogan said. Now, however, "their quality is getting better, and their pricing is certainly a lot lower than in other places we could source."
At the extreme, in terms of China-based profits, are American companies that would not exist without the Chinese market. Chindex, of Bethesda, Md., has been selling top-of-the-line medical equipment to China since 1981. "Particularly in the urban markets, on the east coast of China, there are many, many well-off Chinese who can afford these types of products," said Lawrence Pemble, Chindex's executive vice president for finance and business development. "The hospital system has been able to afford high-end Western technologies for many years now."
Chindex opened a hospital in Beijing in 1997 and plans to open one in Shanghai this year. The company employs about 50 Americans and 450 Chinese. "What we're proving now is that there's a market for very sophisticated high-end health care services in China as well," Mr. Pemble said.
CHINA has added another source of profitability to American companies by acting as a spur for productivity improvements. Besides proximity to customers and the ability to manufacture advanced technology, productivity has become American manufacturing's main advantage in its fight for survival.
The focus on productivity has led to another benefit, said Mr. Meckstroth, the economist, as cheap imports have forced American companies to pass along some of the savings to consumers. "We're actually seeing deflation in the manufacturing sector," he said, "as opposed to inflation elsewhere."
Not everyone agrees, though, on the benefits to Americans. "I don't think very much of it is passed on to the consumer," Mr. Chastain said. He warned that companies might use low labor costs in China to subsidize higher costs elsewhere, with little change in the price of their products.
If the true impact on prices is hard to quantify, the Chinese economy's most important positive effects on the United States may be even harder to gauge. China's fast growth helped Southeast Asia recover from its financial crises in the late 1990's, muting the ill effects on the United States, Mr. Laudicina said. In addition, China's intensified economic links to the rest of the world reduce strategic worries. "The U.S. is going to have increasing leverage over China because of our economic relationship, and vice versa," he said.
Yet the most impressive benefits and costs, contrary to the cries of China's boosters and alarmists alike, could still be a long way off.
First, China's membership in the World Trade Organization might not make it as friendly a business environment as, say, Canada. "At least as far into the future as I can see, China will not become a routine place for business," Mr. Pemble said.
Second, China is pushing foreigners to invest inland, Mr. Laudicina said, ratherthan on its wealthy eastern coastline. Though investors could continue to find low wages there, the workers might lack the skills needed to expand China's export offerings.
And third, even with fast economic growth (which Professor Feenstra says may be overstated by the government's statistics), broad economic changes take time. 
"There's long-term potential, but China remains a very poor country with relatively low human capital," said Robert E. Lipsey, an emeritus professor at the City University of New York and an expert in foreign investment. "Ten years from now, it will still be a very poor country. It will be better off -- they've been growing rapidly -- but dominate the United States? That's hysteria."

HEADLINE: No Worry, Even Now, At MorganStanley 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN and LANDON THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
STRETCHING back in a swivel chair in a conference room high above Times Square, Philip J. Purcell appears not at all frazzled by all the financial, legal and regulatory troubles that are plaguing Morgan Stanley, the giant securities firm he runs, and the rest of Wall Street.
 Though clearly annoyed by the regulators and plaintiffs' lawyers who are pecking at Morgan Stanley and soiling its once-sterling reputation, Mr. Purcell simply says, "It has been a very, very bad two and a half years." 
 Indeed, in an interview at the firm's Manhattan headquarters on Wednesday, Mr. Purcell spoke optimistically about Morgan Stanley's prospects -- a view not supported by the firm's lagging stock price. Most industry analysts are bleak about the investment banking and brokerage businesses and the legal liabilities of Wall Street's big firms -- especially Morgan Stanley. 
Mr. Purcell, who has been chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley since 1997, shrugged off questions about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the firm's handling of public offerings of sought-after technology stocks during the market boom. He said Morgan Stanley had not yet received official notification from the commission that it intends to bring charges against the firm, although the firm's lawyers expect one.
The investigation centers on whether Morgan Stanley prearranged sales of new stocks at prices higher than the offering price before they started trading. Any such charge would imply that one of the standard-bearers of Wall Street had willfully manipulated the market for stocks. (The S.E.C. has already notified two other big firms, the Goldman Sachs Group and J. P. Morgan Chase, that they might face charges from the same investigation, people inside those firms said.)
Mr. Purcell said that Morgan Stanley had done nothing wrong and that it had used "sound practice" to measure demand for stock in companies it took public, a process known on Wall Street as building a book of orders.
"Everything I know about our practices tells me that they were in the best interests of the issuer and the buyer," he said, dismissing the latest assault on Morgan Stanley's character. 
Still, the investigation has only added to the pressures on Mr. Purcell, for whom almost everything seemed to go right during the first 32 years of his career. Lately, his fortunes have reversed.
For the last nine quarters, Morgan Stanley has reported earnings that were below those of the period a year earlier. Its stock price has dropped 66.5 percent from its peak in September 2000, a steeper decline than those of its competitors. In the most lucrative financing businesses, its standing slipped last year, and competitors say Morgan Stanley is less formidable than it once was.
In fact, the firm's participation in the few corporate financing and merger deals that have taken place has slid so much that some senior investment bankers at Morgan Stanley expect the firm, which eliminated 2,200 jobs in the fourth quarter, to start another round of layoffs soon. 
Meanwhile, the legal proceedings section of the firm's recently published 2002 annual report takes up more than five pages. Much of that discussion involves various investigations and lawsuits involving the firm's sales of dozens of new Internet stocks in the late 1990's.
Many of those companies have struggled despite strong support from Morgan Stanley, which often benefited directly from the issues. The firm's own venture capital funds already owned stakes in some companies it took public, including Homestore.com and Transmeta; they sold their shares for substantial profit.
Mr. Purcell, though, asserted that things were getting better, not worse. He said that the firm had been unfairly lumped in with competitors whose standards fell short of its own. He displays little interest in how things have traditionally been done on Wall Street or how others think he should run his firm.
"There is obviously no nostalgia for the old partnership model," said Roy C. Smith, a professor at New York University's business school who was a partner at Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley's No. 1 rival. "I've been impressed that Morgan Stanley has become this cold-eyed publicly owned corporation now."
MR. PURCELL remains something of an enigma on Wall Street. Though his office has been in New York for more than 20 years -- he worked high up in the World Trade Center when he ran Dean Witter from 1982 to 1997 -- his family home has long been in Wilmette, Ill., north of Chicago. Most weeks, he flies home for the weekend, sometimes leaving on Thursday night and working on Fridays from the offices of Morgan Stanley's Discover credit card unit in Riverwoods, Ill.
Unlike most Wall Street bosses, Mr. Purcell never was a trader, broker or investment banker. He had been a partner in the McKinsey & Company consulting firm in Chicago when Sears, Roebuck hired him to run Dean Witter, then a subsidiary of Sears. Some Morgan Stanley traders complain that they can't recall seeing him on any of the firm's trading floors, in contrast to John J. Mack, the former president of Morgan Stanley, who had been a bond salesman at the firm.
"Phil is different," said James F. Higgins, who ran the Dean Witter brokerage operation under Mr. Purcell before retiring last year. "He didn't claw his way up the Wall Street ladder."
Investment bankers at the firm say Mr. Purcell has kept his distance from them as well, contributing to their sense that they no longer command the traditional respect from Morgan Stanley's management. A result, these employees say, has been a drop in morale among the firm's bankers and traders.
Many of these complaints have dogged Mr. Purcell for years, of course, as has speculation that he would engineer a merger as big, or bigger, than the one that forged Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter in 1997. Since 1993, Mr. Purcell has maintained an internal strategic planning staff composed of analysts and former bankers that analyzes possible acquisition targets or merger partners. The team has studied American Express, Bank One and the American International Group, among others.
"He is always trying to figure out the next step," said Thomas C. Schneider, a former senior Morgan Stanley executive. "But he will only make a change if it makes strategic economic sense."
If Mr. Purcell feels pressure from his board to save his job, he does not show it. (Last month, he even spent a few days playing golf in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am tournament.) But some critics say he seems so secure because Morgan Stanley's board has become too cozy.
A former managing director of the firm said Mr. Purcell once told him, "the most important thing I have to do is to keep my board happy."
The board is chock full of current and former chief executives, some with long ties to Mr. Purcell. C. Robert Kidder, the chairman of Borden Chemical, and Miles L. Marsh, who once ran the Fort James Corporation, were, like Mr. Purcell, consultants at McKinsey in the 1970's.
Then there is the Sears connection: Edward A. Brennan, the former chairman and chief executive of Sears, is Mr. Purcell's former boss and tapped him in the early 1980's to run Dean Witter. Charles F. Knight is the chairman and former chief of Emerson Electric, which has been a supplier for Sears.
One example of Mr. Purcell's courting of his board involved the corporate jet: several former Morgan Stanley executives said that he has allowed directors to use it for personal purposes as long as they pay what the same trip would have cost in first class on a commercial airline. It is unclear whether directors took him up on the offer.
Morgan Stanley denies that there was any such offer and says that since 2001 it has had a policy limiting director use of the plane to travel to board meetings and emergencies. In any case, Mr. Purcell countered that several directors would not hesitate to challenge him in the boardroom.
MORGAN STANLEY is one of 12 securities firms that have agreed to pay a total of $1.4 billion to end investigations by federal and state regulators into conflicts of interest among analysts. It agreed to pay a $50 million fine, as did six other big firms. But in some sense it has been less tainted.
While regulators plan to use the word fraud to describe the investment advice published by some firms, including Citigroup, Credit Suisse First Boston and Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley will face lesser charges, people involved in the settlement talks said.
"There's not a shred of evidence," Mr. Purcell said, that Morgan Stanley analysts privately disparaged companies they were recommending to investors. Some competitors said that is because Morgan Stanley apparently destroyed the evidence. E-mail messages written by analysts and their co-workers have served as the smoking guns used by Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, and other regulators to incriminate firms. But when investigators tried to gather up Morgan Stanley e-mail messages, they found that it had erased many of the messages it was required to preserve.
Morgan Stanley paid a fine of $1.65 million for failing to keep those records, and Mr. Purcell dismisses that admitted violation as a technicality. He said the suggestion that the firm selectively deleted e-mail messages or impeded the investigation was "totally false."
The investigation went beyond reading e-mail messages. Investigators deposed Mary Meeker, Morgan Stanley's influential technology analyst who shepherded dozens of Internet companies to market, but so far Ms. Meeker remains the one survivor among the superstars of the technology boom on Wall Street.
Henry Blodget, Ms. Meeker's counterpart at Merrill Lynch, resigned in late 2001, a few months before Mr. Spitzer released e-mail messages that Mr. Blodget had written disparaging companies whose stocks he was recommending. Jack B. Grubman, the senior telecommunications analyst at the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup, resigned last summer amid an investigation into whether he raised his rating on AT&T's stock to appease Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's chairman and chief executive. And Frank P. Quattrone, an investment banker who built Credit Suisse First Boston into a leading underwriter of technology companies, was suspended last month after First Boston discovered an e-mail message in which he encouraged employees to throw out documents while the firm was under investigation. All three firms paid higher fines than Morgan Stanley.
Mr. Purcell's pronouncements about reform contrast with those of some peers. Since last fall, Mr. Weill has fashioned himself as a champion of good corporate governance, resigning as a director of two companies whose chairmen serve on his board and declining a bonus for last year. The chairman and the chief executive of Merrill Lynch have apologized in public for the behavior of some of the firm's analysts.
Mr. Purcell has issued no mea culpas. He has been the most vocal among his peers in opposing some of the reforms proposed or put into effect by regulators and lawmakers.
Morgan Stanley agreed to make the same changes that are being imposed on other firms to insulate analysts from the influence of investment bankers. But Mr. Purcell said no other changes were needed in the firm's investment banking practices. Mr. Purcell does, however, cast himself as a longtime proponent of strong corporate governance, praising some changes that have been mandated. He said it was helpful to have the corporate code of ethics and the charters for his board's committees spelled out for shareholders on the company's Web site. But he said Morgan Stanley already had a tougher code of conduct and a stricter definition of independence for its directors than is now required.
As an example, he cited the rule that independent directors cannot be related to company executives. Morgan Stanley bans directors' family members from working at the firm in any capacity, he said. So, two of his seven sons work at competing firms.
If Morgan Stanley has fared so much better in the investigations and avoided entanglements with troubled companies like Enron and WorldCom, it is curious that its stock has performed as poorly as Merrill's over the last year and so much worse than other competitors.
ANALYSTS said that much of the answer lies in Morgan Stanley's unprofitable brokerage operation. As individual investors have withdrawn from the stock market, analysts said, big investors have abandoned stocks like Morgan Stanley, Merrill and Charles Schwab, which depend on trading activity.
There is also, of course, the persistent fear of big legal judgments against Morgan Stanley from the raft of lawsuits investors have filed over stocks the firm underwrote and recommended during the boom. Ms. Meeker and the firm's investment bankers were among the biggest backers of dot-com stocks, financing them with investors' money and sometimes with their own.
Filings by one of the firm's venture capital funds, Morgan Stanley Venture Partners III, show that in June 2000 it sold shares of Homestore that it had acquired before the company went public less than a year earlier. The fund, about 10 percent of which was owned by Morgan Stanley employees, gained about $7 million, a firm spokesman said. Morgan Stanley had underwritten two stock offerings by Homestore, one for $110 a share. It now trades at 76 cents. 
Another private investment fund, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Equity Funding, made about $5 million in May 2001 from selling shares of Transmeta it had acquired in a private placement. Morgan Stanley had taken the company public in November 2000 at $21 a share. The stock now trades at $1.32. A spokesman for the firm said that no employees invested in that fund. He said that neither Morgan Stanley nor its employees could have benefited immediately from the public offerings of those stocks because they were not allowed to sell their shares for the first six months.
Mr. Purcell remains unfazed, despite the investigations, all the pending lawsuits and the poor prospects for a rebound in Morgan Stanley's main businesses. He flatly rejected the notion that he might make an early exit. Leaning back and grinning, he said investors should expect him to be around until he turns 65, which won't happen until 2008.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Earnings News Hurts a Nervous Market

BYLINE:  By JEFF SOMMER 

 BODY:
Unimpressive earnings forecasts and worries about a possible war with Iraq drove down the main market averages last week, despite a strong economic report on Friday.
 Symantec, which makes anti-virus computer software, fell 15 percent for the week, one of the biggest losses on Nasdaq, after the company's earnings forecast disappointed analysts. 
Hewlett-Packard fell 13 percent for the week, the biggest fall in the Dow Jones industrials. It missed its quarterly revenue target and said many companies were reluctant to buy equipment because of the war outlook. 
 A Commerce Department report that gross domestic product grew at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, double the rate reported a month earlier, briefly buoyed the markets.
 For the week, the Dow fell 127.03 points, to close at 7,891.08, a loss of 1.6 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.02 points, to 841.15, a decline of 0.8 percent. The Nasdaq composite index fell 11.50 points to 1,337.52, down 0.9 percent. 
 The benchmark 10-year Treasury note ended the week yielding 3.69 percent, down from 3.89 percent the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES/EMBEDDING; 
You Need Outerwear to Go 'Over There'

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WILSON

 BODY:
CONSIDER the word embedded: It calls to mind a piece of jewelry you can't afford, or an embarrassing, unpleasant medical procedure you're not even sure your health plan covers. 
 It's the verb of the moment in New York news media circles. As the conflict unfolds in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon, for the first time since World War II, is allowing reporters and photographers to travel with troops. In the event of a war, they will be able to report from closer to the action. The journalists are "embedded" with, say, a Marine Expeditionary Unit, eating their food, sleeping where they sleep, swapping stories around the ol' tent, winning cigarettes at poker games. ("Boys, you call that a battle, you should have seen this legislative budget subcommittee hearing I covered, back in oh, hell, you jarheads were still garroting teddy bears.") 
 The assignments went out a couple weeks ago. And New York reporters, whose idea of roughing it is a bodega beer run in the snow, found themselves downloading, straight-faced, bizarre shopping lists of wildly exotic-sounding gear ("excavation tool," "polypropylene bottoms," "water purification tablets," "laundry detergent"), then hitting the streets with corporate credit cards and setting in motion a minor economic boom. 
The first stop on the road to a free Iraq is Paragon, a sprawling sporting goods and camping store in Union Square. Specifically, the outerwear section, a harrowing chamber for any city slicker. All that Gore-Tex, all those zippers and snaps and (shudder) hoods. 
Where to begin? You need something like desert camouflage, so you don't get picked off by a sniper, but not exactly desert camouflage, because this war, if it starts, will be over someday, and you'll come home, and you don't want to look like you know, that guy.
Dennis sells outerwear. Dennis understands. He suggests gray and tan marmot, whatever that is, waterproof, breathable, pockets all over the thing for secret parchment maps and throwing stars and smokes. On sale, even. Bing.
Next stop: a little turn-your-head-and-cough duty. Step on a rusty nail, and they'll be using that excavation tool for you, bub. Shots for tetanus, yellow fever, typhoid fever, the whole hypodermic platter, seven or eight shots in all.
It's funny. When the nurses wish you luck, you swear you can hear bugles sounding. Then you go to the bar, and your pals are talking about St. Patrick's Day, until they notice you and change the subject. Your studio is a wreck, all that stuff. Here's something that looks like an apron with a built-in cutting board: Turns out the bulletproof vest comes with a groin attachment. You've covered stories in some of the toughest neighborhoods in New York, but now, suddenly, everybody's worried about your groin. 
One more stop: Tent and Trails sort of sneaks up on you in Lower Manhattan, a narrow cavern of bungee cords and insect repellent and weird liquid soap you can use on your dishes, face, hair and teeth. 
Jamie Abish owns the store. She has been outfitting embedded reporters all week. When one asked about the availability of a field mirror, she frowned and said, "Have you told your mother you're doing this?" MICHAEL WILSON

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lightweight, waterproof and wind-proof. Just perfect this season for Iraq. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Riding the Bounding Rails 

BYLINE:  By WENDELL JAMIESON

 BODY:
HERE'S this little railroad on the Brooklyn waterfront with 1.5 miles of track, one locomotive and a three-man crew -- the engineer, the conductor and the brakeman. Trains like speed, but this one never goes faster than five miles an hour, on rails that run through Sunset Park, beneath the arched footbridges of the Brooklyn Army Terminal, and alongside and through old warehouses.
 The engineer is Charlie McClellend, 60, who has been doing this for 31 years. It shows: he can move a mammoth battleship-gray diesel-electric locomotive by the inch, backward and forward, gently easing his brake and throttle levers, as if he were manipulating a child's Lionel. The conductor is Jimmy Lada, 35. The brakeman is Jose Torres, 30, who grew up with Mr. Lada on 12th Street and Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, which is how he got the job. 
 The three represent the Brooklyn crew of the New York Cross Harbor Railroad, which provides direct rail service from the borough to the mainland of the United States, in this case, a particularly hellish stretch of the Jersey City waterfront. After the three men nudge their cars onto a float -- a barge with tracks on it -- it is pulled by tugboat for three miles, to a dusty plot of shoreline next to rusting mountains of scrap metal. There, another locomotive and crew take over, hitching the cars to trains that shoot across North America. 
 The railroad brings train cars carrying rice and lead pipes to customers in Sunset Park, and it floats cars filled with wood and cocoa -- which comes to Brooklyn from the Ivory Coast of Africa -- to Jersey City. The cocoa goes to Hershey, Pa., and comes back to Brooklyn as Hershey's Kisses.
 This is one of only two active shortline railroads in New York City; the other, the New York & Atlantic, has nearly 300 miles of track and mostly serves Long Island. The Cross Harbor is also one of the country's smallest. It is the only railroad that runs on New York's streets, and one of only a handful that still float rail cars.
 And it shouldn't even be alive.
 Filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission show years of losses. A publicly held company, it has stock that trades for pennies. The city will not give it more than a month-to-month lease at its base in the Bush Terminal, which is a spectacular dump, and is even trying to evict it.
 "We're not the little railroad that could," said Wayne Eastman, the company's president, sitting in his trailer office in Jersey City, the Statue of Liberty toylike in the distance. "We're the little railroad that wants to."
 But this little railroad keeps on rolling. Two years ago, a new management team took over; last year, roughly 3,200 rail cars crossed the harbor. That means roughly 25,000 trucks did not travel through Manhattan or Staten Island -- a little relief in a traffic-choked city.
 The economics do not matter much to Mr. McClellend and the rest of the crew, except when business is so good they make two round trips a day instead of one and get a bigger paycheck. They are more worried about tides, white caps, fog, wind, rain, freezing temperatures, freighters, sailboats, dock masters, broken or missing rails or rail cars, traffic, double-parked cars, faulty switches, bad drivers and stuff getting stolen.

Full Loads and Empty Lockers
Watching these men work on a frigid morning is like watching a choreographed ballet of wheels, rails and switches. At 8 a.m., it was 23 degrees outside Bush Terminal, but felt 20 degrees colder. The harbor was framed square by the terminal's red brick buildings, and the waves, every fourth or fifth one a whitecap, were blue-green and sharp, as if edged with Spackle.
 In the silent locker room, the three men pulled on their tan work clothes, yellow reflector belts and work boots. There were hints that not long ago this was a much bigger operation: dozens of lockers stood empty; vacant crew rooms were filled with computer parts, broken furniture, depth charts and maps. 
 Downstairs, three light blue locomotives with paintings of puffing tugboats and engines on their cabs sat in a dark machine shop. The engines are from the late 1940's and are no longer used. Two others sit forlornly in the yard outside the terminal, along with an old caboose. The one active locomotive is newer, from 1958, and leased.
 A few years back, the Cross Harbor owned and maintained not only its own locomotives but also its own tugboats. Now the tugboat work is contracted out.
 Mr. McClellend remembers 30 or 40 men working, filling the crew rooms, even making night runs, so many men that there were not always enough lockers to go around. Now it is just the three of them. When they leave to start the day's runs, they lock the door.
 He climbed into the locomotive and got the engine going while Mr. Torres rolled up the metal grating door. The three of them must have been wearing long underwear, and several other layers, because they were puffed up like balloons. "There's just nothing you can do about this, especially out here," Mr. Torres said of the cold, stamping his feet. "No matter how much you put on, it just goes right through you."
 Mr. Torres has been doing this for several years, but this will be his last. He has been studying computers at the Katharine Gibbs School. Computers are appealing: they are indoors. Here at the yard, it is not only brutally cold in winter but so hot in summer you can see the heat rising off the rails.

Rendezvous With the Rice Guy
 Mr. McClellend brought the locomotive about 50 feet, past the first switch. Mr. Torres threw an iron lever, and when the locomotive backed up, it went off on a tangent, on a different set of rails. Mr. Torres and Mr. Lada walked up ahead as they crossed 43rd Street and then 42nd Street. On 42nd Street, a man in an idling Cadillac was reading a newspaper, unaware that he was parked atop active railroad tracks. Then he saw the locomotive, with its four glowering headlights, and he was gone.
 The first stop: Interdynamics Incorporated, where an empty tank car that once held air-conditioning gas awaited. Mr. Lada gave second-by-second guidance from the ground on a radio hooked to his shoulder. The locomotive kissed the tank car with a bump. They were coupled, and Mr. McClellend backed them out.
 It is strange to see train tracks running into buildings, which look more like dead ends than destinations. The Cross Harbor tracks, which are also leased from the city, were cobbled together in 1984 from those belonging to two dying dock railroads. They run along First Avenue, and spread out into several warehouses. They go east on 41st Street to Second Avenue and then turn north again, literally cutting through the corner of one warehouse.
 There are other tracks like that around the city. In Dumbo in Brooklyn, old rusty rails show through the asphalt and cobblestones, and lead improbably into long-closed steel doors of converted warehouses. Same thing with the High Line in Chelsea, the only difference being that the High Line is above ground and people are arguing ferociously about its future. What sets the Sunset Park tracks apart is that they are shiny, which means that sometimes a train runs on them.
 Once every few weeks, the locomotive makes its farthest journey north, to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yards on 39th Street, where it delivers rails and ties for the subway system. Other days, it pushes a box car of uncooked rice to East Peak Trading, whom Mr. Lada calls "the rice guy." Each carload will become part of untold thousands of Chinese dinners served to untold thousands of New Yorkers.
 After the coupling, Mr. McClellend brought the one-locomotive, one-car train back to the yard and hitched it to one that was filled; you could tell because the springs near the wheels were compressed. He pulled it back to Interdynamics, where it would be put into untold thousands of canisters to cool untold thousands of Brooklynites in their cars next summer.
 Throughout the Interdynamics excursion, the float bobbed at the foot of 51st Street. Then the main event began. Ten cars waited at Bush Terminal, brought there the previous day from the 65th Street yard of the New York & Atlantic, Cross Harbor's biggest customer in Brooklyn. Roughly a quarter of the New York & Atlantic's cars, about 150 a month, come from Jersey City via the harbor. Otherwise, rail cars coming from, say, Pennsylvania, would have to travel several hundred miles out of their way to cross the Hudson near Albany.
 This day there were three empty boxcars and seven low-slung, graffiti-covered gondolas filled with scrap metal. The locomotive got behind all 10 and pushed them onto the float, a few at a time. Mr. Torres ran around, putting blocks under the wheels.
 Then the red tugboat, the 200-ton Brian McAllister, arrived. The captain, Kenneth Hawrey, worked out of the upper pilot house so he could see over the boxcars. He backed out, gunning the engine. Everything vibrated. He started a turn to the right, then pulled off a particularly elegant maneuver: cutting the power, he let the momentum he had already created turn the float, silently, 180 degrees, until he was pointing at Jersey City.
 The view from the pilot house was surreal: a train was crossing the harbor. Captain Hawrey turned the float southwest, to deeper water, then headed northwest. In 45 minutes, he was easing the float into a gantry in Jersey City.
 Unlike the facility in Brooklyn, where the loading platform floated and bobbed up and down with the tide, Jersey City's is an oily, clanging, monstrous thing, with winches and chains that raise or lower the track bed. It was built around 1931 and is actually owned by Cross Harbor. A half-second after the front of the float touched land, the windows in the wheelhouse rattled.

Lousy Day for a Locomotive
 That was a good day; they are not all like that.
 On another cold morning, this one misty and drenched in rain, the locomotive set off from Bush Terminal down First Avenue like a ghostly apparition to collect 14 New York & Atlantic cars. Mr. Lada and Mr. Torres were soaked. After a few blocks, Mr. Lada radioed Mr. McClellend to stop. Down in the street, a switch point -- the moving section of rail in a switch -- had been dislodged, probably by the trucks pounding in and out of the Army Terminal during the night.
 Mr. Lada called the railroad's vice president, Howard Samelson, and Mr. Samelson started driving from the office in Jersey City. A railroad man with 30 years' experience, he joined Cross Harbor eight months ago. His wife calls it that "silly little railroad."
 Mr. Samelson has a beard and wears a hat like Indiana Jones. He may be the only person living in Manhattan who actually needs a Land Rover: It bounced and sloshed across the moonscape of the Bush Terminal yard, which was so flooded that many tracks were underwater. When he pulled up to the idling locomotive, he crouched down before assuring Mr. Lada that the train would not derail; the other track, the one that was still there, would hold it in place.
 As the crew continued on to 65th Street, Mr. Samelson found the missing piece of track by the side of First Avenue and got a forklift operator to drop it into the flooded opening in the roadbed with an iron-on-iron bang. The railroad vice president was showered with dirty street water.
 When the locomotive got to 65th Street, 32 cars were waiting, not 14. One, a tank car, was full, which means it was probably not supposed to go to Jersey City. No one was sure what was in it. The first dozen cars were hooked up and the train started back down First Avenue while Mr. Samelson called the New York & Atlantic, trying to figure out whose cars he had.
 Then, disaster. Sitting on 47th Street, on top of the tracks, was the crew's most persistent annoyance: a double-parked car, in this case a blue Ford Spirit. The train groaned to a stop.
 "Hey, you know you've got a train in the middle of the street?" one driver yelled. "Yeah, man, we know," Mr. Torres replied with a sigh.
 Mr. Eastman, Cross Harbor's president, called on his cellphone from Jersey City.
 "Are we railroading?" he asked hopefully.
 Mr. Samelson paused before replying: "Yes, Wayne, we're railroading."
 A half hour later a tow truck arrived and pulled the Spirit away. It did not matter: the fog had closed in. It would be hours before the float could head out. "Fog? Really?" asked Mr. Samelson, who despite his experience is still getting used to the idea of trains going on water. "I thought they had radar."

End of the Line?
 Perhaps the single biggest factor working against Cross Harbor is its troubled relationship with New York City. As a railroad, the company is regulated by the federal government. But the city wants to evict the company from Bush Terminal; under previous management in the mid-1990's, the city contends in a civil suit, the company illegally buried pesticides, petroleum waste and old railroad ties there. The city spent $750,000 to clean it up, and is suing the company to get the money back.
 At the same time, the city's Economic Development Corporation wants Cross Harbor to succeed, because more freight rail service to Brooklyn would help local businesses, strengthen the port and cut down on truck traffic in Manhattan. As the agency studies the viability of a multibillion-dollar rail tunnel connecting New Jersey and Brooklyn, floating more rail cars appears to be a short-term solution. Cross Harbor is the only company that does it.
 "We recognize that they are trying to improve rail freight; we are not here to second-guess them," said Seth Kaye, the development corporation's executive vice president. "It just makes it difficult for us to have them as a tenant at that site, given, up to this point, the failure of New York Cross Harbor to take responsibility for this situation."
 Just a few blocks away from Bush Terminal, at 65th Street, is a $20 million rail-float loading dock that the city finished three years ago. A rail car has yet to be floated off it. The men who run Cross Harbor look at the unused facility, with its straight-arrow tracks, raked gravel track beds and Erector setlike gantries, and imagine how much easier their lives could be. No more traveling down First Avenue to get New York & Atlantic rolling stock. No more double-parked cars.
 They believe that the city is holding the dock hostage until the lawsuit is settled. They argue that the accusations focus on the tenure of a previous company president, and note that nothing has yet been proved. Mr. Eastman points to his own background -- 32 years in the business, including 11 with Conrail -- as proof that professionals are now in charge.
 The city denies that the lawsuit and the 65th Street situation are linked. "We certainly want to come to an agreement with them whereby they could use the rail-float bridge at 65th Street," Mr. Kaye said.
 It's all very complicated, as are most things in railroads in the 21st century, especially those involving Brooklyn, Jersey City, the ground underneath and the water in between. But as the telephone calls go back and forth, and as the lawyers meet, Mr. McClellend, Mr. Lada and Mr. Torres will be out there, hitching that locomotive, moving rice, putting blocks under steel wheels, and waiting for the day when their little railroad is not quite so silly anymore.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK OBSERVED; 
Translating Poverty and Pain

BYLINE:  By SUKI KIM; Suki Kim's first novel, "The Interpreter," was published in January by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

 BODY:
ABOUT three years ago, I became an interpreter by accident. I was working on a novel in which the heroine floated from job to job. I wanted to give her something she could stick to, work that, at least on the surface, did not suggest a commitment. One day, while flipping through a newspaper, I saw this ad: "Freelance interpreter wanted. Flexible hours." Under the list of the desired languages was Korean, in which I and my heroine, Suzy Park, were fluent.
 After enduring a 40-minute-long mock trial at an employment agency near Wall Street that specializes in interpreters for depositions, I was hired. The woman at the agency told me that an interpreter must be willing to travel anywhere within the five boroughs. A deposition's location often depended on the immigrant group. Brighton Beach for Russians. Sunset Park for Mexicans. But I was lucky, she said. Koreans are everywhere. Queens mostly, but sometimes the Bronx, Brooklyn, even Staten Island. 
 I was immediately sent to serve in depositions, which usually took place in gloomy offices known as reporting services. Sometimes an entire building would be filled with them. They had names like Barrister Reporting or Diamond Reporting, and were often situated beside courts. The F train brought me to Sutphin Boulevard, where the Queens courts are lined up on one side. The No.5 was for River Avenue, right by Yankee Stadium and the Bronx courts. You could get on any of the green or red lines for the jobs on Court Street in Brooklyn.
 I had imagined gruesome murder trials involving love triangles and gangster intrigues. But, in fact, most cases were dull. Car accidents, slips and falls, medical malpractice. The personal injury lawyers always acted frantic, pacing back and forth, cellphones pressed to their ears. The stenographers, mostly women in their mid-20's and 30's with distinct Long Island or Brooklyn accents, often showed up late, pushing their own stenograph machines on wheels. In the corner sat the Korean-speaking witnesses, looking small and scared.
 The job of being an interpreter helped change my novel's character. I never imagined that it would change me.
 My research seemed to go smoothly until one day when I was summoned to the State Attorney General's office in Lower Manhattan for a routine case. When the witness entered, he looked vaguely familiar. Once I began interpreting his answers, I realized that his store was located on my block in the East Village. According to his testimony, he also worked as a truck deliveryman and was often absent from the store, which explained why we didn't recognize each other. 
 A good interpreter would have stopped the questioning right away, because of the conflict of interest. But I was a fiction writer, after all. I was curious. It was clear that he was in trouble for violating labor laws. He claimed to employ fewer workers than he actually did, and denied that the cashier from whom I boughtmy daily morning coffee was actually his wife. 
 I had no moral quandary about interpreting his lies. My job was to repeat verbatim what the witness said, in English. What bothered me was that I happened to know the other side of his story. 
 I had seen how hard his wife worked, 6 days a week, 12 hours a day. He had two jobs, running the store and working as a deliveryman. His employees, mostly from South Korea and Central America, spoke hardly any English and probably had no other way of making a living legally. All those people worked too many hours and never seemed to take any time off. 
 His store was open around the clock, seven days a week. But his was not a unique case. There were many such Korean markets around the city. I'd seen picketers boycotting some of them. Yet the secret to their success seemed entwined with the fact that they kept longer hours than anyone else and employed the cheapest labor around. Such a setup inherently teeters, at the least, on the brink of breaking labor laws.
 But customers, including me, rarely stop to question such situations. That's because we New Yorkers are addicted to Korean markets. We love being able get a pack of cigarettes or condoms or fresh salads at the wee hours of the morning. We trust their clean and shiny displays of fruit. In this city that never sleeps, we take comfort in their perpetual availability. 
 The guilty party was the witness, but somehow I was not persuaded that the problem was entirely his. The D.A.'s effort to shut down his store did not pose a real solution, either. By the end of his testimony, nothing seemed as simple as it had first appeared. I wanted to ask the Korean man what he thought about all of this, but I was not allowed to talk with him. It would seem that an interpreter worked for the witness, but she was, in fact, always retained by the opposing counsel. 
 Not until later, on my way home, did it dawn on me that I could no longer stop at his store. I now knew too much about his life and those of other immigrants. I had lived in Manhattan for over a decade. I had attended college uptown and had stayed downtown after that. Until recently, I'd associated Lefrak City only with hip-hop. 
 IT was a revelation, for example, that a Korean construction worker from Brooklyn, who specialized in removing asbestos, made less money in a day than I did in two hours; for each assignment, I was paid at least $150. It seemed that every other car accident victim billed his or her insurance company through this one chiropractor in Flushing. 
 I learned that at a certain hour of the day, the No.7 train was virtually filled with only Asians. I listened to the tribulations of women who toiled as manicurists at nail salons around the city. I became the voice of greengrocers, cabdrivers and dry cleaners. Upon being asked to state their current addresses, the witnesses listed various neighborhoods, including Jackson Heights, Astoria and Forest Hills, but almost never Manhattan. I took it as a given that almost no witness had health insurance or even proper weekends. 
 English, in some ways, struck me as a weapon, and not speaking it was the greatest economic handicap. And my role, as an interpreter, was not only to translate a witness's testimony but also to relieve this pain somehow. 
 With each case, I kept forgetting my mission as a novelist, my responsibility to my heroine, Suzy. After Sept.11, I ran to the family assistance center at the armory to volunteer as an interpreter. It became increasingly difficult to pass by a Korean market or a nail salon and watch some customers berate the workers, or condescend to them as though their lack of English suggested lower intelligence. I was often tempted to interrupt and act on behalf of the non-English-speaker. I was driven by a professional instinct. But it also signaled my shortcomings as an interpreter. An interpreter, of course, should never take sides.
 I stopped interpreting soon after. And I did finish the novel. But the city has changed for me. I keep noticing lines. Between a customer and a worker. Between a prosecutor and a witness. Between Manhattan and the other boroughs. Between one who speaks English, and one who doesn't.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
Americans Have a Cool Debate About a Hot-Button Topic

BYLINE:  By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
The debate about race-sensitive college admissions policies has been raging for more than 25 years, long enough for some of the most visible protagonists to switch sides. What started as a high-volume fistfight has evolved into a sophisticated discussion in which those who oppose affirmative action often do so by degrees -- viewing it as right for, say, the fire department or the state college but wrong for an elite university's law school.
 The added nuance lowers the volume and cools things down. The most striking development is that Americans have learned to talk about race without being racist. 
 Things have changed considerably since the heyday of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, who took race-baiting to a new level when he ran for re-election against a black opponent in 1990. A now-legendary attack ad showed a white man crumpling up a rejection letter as a voice-over said: "You needed that job, and you were the best qualified. But they had to give it to a minority because of a racial quota. Is that really fair?"
Mr. Helms encouraged white constituents who had experienced job loss or professional disappointment to blame affirmative action. The message was that antiwhite discrimination was the only possible explanation when a black applicant was chosen over a white person.
George Bush took a page from the Jesse Helms playbook when the administration filed a Supreme Court brief condemning affirmative action at the University of Michigan and tried to mislead Americans into believing that Michigan has a quota system that systematically discriminates against nonblack applicants. The Michigan program in no way resembles such a system. Indeed, the program differs only cosmetically from the one that transformed the American military from a profoundly segregated force on the verge of self-destruction into a model of interracial cohesiveness.
As recently as 10 years ago, quota-baiting by a president would have triggered echoes around the country. Politicians would have jumped on the bandwagon. But the debate about the Michigan case has been surprisingly calm and reflective, partly because many Americans now understand how affirmative action works. Even hard-core conservatives were shaken to see black and Hispanic students disappear from California's elite campuses after Proposition 209 outlawed race-sensitive admissions policies there in 1996. They do not wish to see the phenomenon repeated across the country. 
The new tone also reflects a growing realization that a majority of special admissions cases involve white students who are athletes or V.I.P.'s, or wealthy applicants who get into elite colleges because their families write big checks. The growing realization that money and privilege play a role in the admissions process has transformed what began as a debate about race into a discussion about the meaning of academic merit and what constitutes fair access for the rich, white and famous.
The strongest challenge to the Bush position has come from the American military, which knows that killing off affirmative action would leave the country with a fighting force that would be weaker and more segregated than it is today. Senior officers still in uniform are unable to challenge the White House directly. But their views are reflected in an amicus brief filed last month and signed by several decorated former officers -- including three former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The brief discusses the Vietnam War period, when the military's ability to defend the country was compromised because it had gone into battle with a nearly all-white officer corps and a multiracial fighting force. Integrating the officer corps meant increasing the minority representation among those entering the Army, Navy and Air Force academies. This meant understanding that standardized test scores are not the final arbiters of ability and focusing on a broad range of factors -- including race -- in recruitment and admissions.
As the Wall Street Journal columnist Al Hunt noted recently, the military academies have grown in stature since these changes took place. Many cadets, both white and black, have been found to have leadership skills superior to fellow students with higher test scores. A similar pattern has emerged at elite civilian colleges, several of which hold SAT's in such low regard that they no longer require applicants to take them. 
The idea that "merit" can be defined solely in terms of test scores has been rejected by the American military and has lost credibility just about everywhere -- except in the White House. The voices that argued most forcefully for Mr. Bush to attack affirmative action at Michigan did so partly because they believe that the university puts too little weight on SAT scores and too much weight on race. This fixation on the link between SAT scores and race is peculiar, given a White House with so many people who relied on privilege and connections as they rose to high office. 
True, the university's admissions scheme -- which is based on a 150-point system -- awards a maximum of 12 points for the SAT score and 20 for membership in an underrepresented minority group. But to focus on that is misleading, given that 20 points can also be earned by white students who are economically disadvantaged or who attend predominantly nonwhite high schools. In addition, a full 110 of the 150 points are derived from academic factors.
Mr. Bush brandished the "quota" label to feed the far right. But the country is learning that special admissions, when taken as a whole, favor white students more than blacks -- and that class, not race, is the main determinant of who gets a boost into the most coveted colleges.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Where to Find the Cash For Everything Else?

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT is a choice that politicians hate to make: guns or butter.
 President Lyndon B. Johnson insisted, for a long time, that he could deliver both, that "we can continue the Great Society while we fight in Vietnam." President Franklin D. Roosevelt acknowledged the obvious in 1943: "old Dr. New Deal" had given way to "Dr. Win-the-War." 
 Now comes the Bush administration, with its ambitious proposals for new tax cuts, an overhaul of Medicare, the creation of new prescription drug benefits, continued improvements in education and other domestic needs. Administration officials and their allies say they can push ahead with these goals even while prosecuting a war with Iraq, if it comes to that, and a subsequent occupation. They argue, in essence, that they will not have to choose.
"Whether or not the president authorizes the use of force, the American people deserve to have jobs," Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said last week. "And whether or not the president authorizes a use of force, it still is important to get prescription drugs to our nation's seniors and to strengthen the Medicare program. I'm certain you would not suggest that if we go to war, seniors somehow don't deserve prescription drugs. There are still a series of initiatives that are important."
But the strains of trying to be bold on two fronts are already apparent. Administration officials are under increasing pressure to put a more specific price tag on a war, which was not in the budget they submitted this year. With deficits already projected at upward of $300 billion a year, Democrats say the case for the administration's $674 billion tax cut will grow ever weaker.
"Will the Republicans and the president push this tax bill when our deficits are soaring to $400 or $500 billion?" asked Representative Robert T. Matsui, the California Democrat and chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.
It is not simply a matter of money. Pushing legislation as complicated as a huge tax bill or a Medicare overhaul through Congress takes presidential focus and political capital. Already, the rollout of the Medicare plan suggested that an administration noted for its message control and internal discipline was stretched thin. An early draft was overwhelmingly criticized -- by members of both parties -- as politically unpalatable, forcing administration officials to scramble to adjust.
Some historians, like Robert Dallek, argue that the Bush administration is attempting the impossible. "If you go to war, there is no room for a significant domestic agenda and you can document that," Mr. Dallek said. "Imagine what it would take to put across a major health reform program, a major drug program. Where is the political energy when you get into a war?"
No one was more bitterly aware of that trade-off than Johnson, who told the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin in 1970: "I knew from the start that I was bound to be crucified either way I moved. If I left the woman I really loved -- the Great Society -- in order to get involved with that . . . of a war on the other side of the world, then I would lose everything at home. All my programs."
Johnson, of course, tried to juggle a long, draining war and profoundly ambitious -- and expensive -- domestic social programs. Grover Norquist, the conservative strategist, asserted, "We can, in the next two months, liberate Iraq and pass the president's tax plan."
Moreover, for Mr. Bush, an exceedingly tight budget fits with his view of a limited federal government. Some liberals argue that Mr. Bush is not at all unhappy with a budget that favors guns over butter. Mr. Bush can also accomplish many of his domestic goals, in areas like environmental regulation, by administrative action alone.
But the Bush administration does have some grand ambitions on the domestic front, albeit very different from Johnson's. It could have chosen, for example, simply to add a modest drug benefit to Medicare and set aside its overhaul for a quieter time. It could have chosen smaller tax cuts.
It is hard not to read, in the scale of this administration's ambitions, an Oedipal subtext: the son, unlike the father, will never be accused of lacking a bold vision for domestic policy. The father ended the Persian Gulf war in 1991 with an approval rating of 88 percent, but did not heed, for many months, the pleas in his own party to spend some of that political capital on an aggressive domestic program.
Politically, this White House may feel it has no real alternative. For all the anxiety over terrorism and war, the nation is increasingly worried about the ailing economy. In a poll released last week by the Pew Research Center, 43 percent of those surveyed approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, while 48 percent disapproved. Andrew Kohut, who heads the Pew poll, said voters' fears about having enough money for retirement, for college, for the care of aged parents, have increased in recent years.
Governors are pleading for some federal assistance with programs like Medicaid, the federal-state health insurance for low-income anddisabled Americans. The number of uninsured Americans already stands at 41 million, and many policy makers worry that it will only grow because of continued unemployment, rising health costs and the prospect of cutbacks in Medicaid. "We are, in my view, closer to a health care implosion than most people realize," said Gov. Edward G. Rendell, the new Democratic governor of Pennsylvania.
The prospect of war is like a toothache for American voters, making it hard to focus on anything else, Mr. Kohut said. But once it is over, they will turn quickly to these underlying domestic concerns, he predicted, noting that they always have, a hard lesson for leaders from Churchill to the first President Bush.
There is a winning chain of events for the administration. As one House Democratic strategist put it, "It's all contingent on his numbers." If the war is quick and considered a victory, the president's popularity will rise, his fellow Republicans on Capitol Hill will be eager to move his domestic program "and he'll just roll through a lot of this stuff," the Democratic strategist said. "The idea that a lot of Republicans would break with him in that context, if his numbers are getting back to toward the 80's, is unlikely."
White House officials, presumably, would shift gears quickly. Their domestic agenda would be ready to go. Their moderates in the Senate would hold the line. It would depend, in short, on a lot of variables breaking their way. But nothing seems riskier, perhaps, than letting domestic policy slide.
