HEADLINE: The World; 
Can Oil Pay for Iraq's Rebuilding? The U.S. Hopes So.

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
AMONG the arguments the Bush administration has offered to allay concerns about the cost of war in Iraq is that the United States would not have to pay for rebuilding the country after the shooting stops. The Iraqis themselves could manage that, the thinking goes, because they sit atop the world's second-largest oil reserves, after Saudi Arabia's.
 "Detailed planning is underway for resumption of oil production as quickly as possible to meet the Iraqi people's basic needs," said Douglas J. Feith, under secretary of defense for policy, at a recent Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing. "The oil sector is Iraq's primary source of funding." 
 But over the last few months, a growing chorus of experts, including oil industry and regional analysts, has questioned whether Iraq could count on that money anytime in the near future.
"It's simply a fantasy that Iraq has lots of oil, so therefore it will have lots of money," said James A. Placke, senior associate with Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm, who spent 27 years as a United States diplomat, mainly in the Middle East. 
Over the next 10 years, Iraqis may need about $250 billion to rebuild everything from power plants to social service programs, said Raad Alkadiri, a director at PFC Energy, a Washington consulting group. That does not include an estimated $50 billion over the same period to restore and expand the oil industry, he said. 
Despite such concerns, the government still thinks oil will be the engine for Iraq's economic revival. "The Iraqi economy is driven by oil," said Gregg W. Sullivan, a spokesman for the Near Eastern bureau of the State Department. "We don't expect it to be an impoverished country for long."
Twenty five years ago, before the Iran-Iraq war, Iraq could produce a maximum of about 3.5 million barrels a day. Today, its maximum capacity is about 2.8 million barrels a day, which still makes it the third largest producer in the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Iraq's oil industry has atrophied for several reasons. Two wars in two decades badly damaged its fields, and United Nations sanctions have reduced the flow of spare parts and technology. 
"The oil sector in some ways is being held togetherby string and chewing gum," Mr. Alkadiri said. "It's a testament to the skills of the technocrats that they managed to keep the oil pumping, but they have paid a tremendous cost as far the state of the oil fields."
Mr. Placke estimated that revenues to Iraq from oil exports, legal and otherwise, were about $12 billion to $14 billion last year, but a war would likely further depress its production. And the possibility remains, despite Saddam Hussein's recent denials, that he might sabotage the oil facilities rather than allow them to be captured.
Even if the industry survives a war intact, "many oil fields are in areas that are likely to be the biggest flash points, not just during the war, but as the United States tries to win the peace," Mr. Alkadiri said.
Kirkuk, a city in northern Iraq with rich oil fields around it, may turn into one of those flash points, regional experts fear. Long a Kurdish stronghold, Kirkuk has been resettled with growing numbers of Arabs sent from southern Iraq by Mr. Hussein. For 75 years, the Kurds have demanded control over Kirkuk's oil fields to have an independent source of money as the first step toward greater autonomy from Baghdad. In 1991, right after the gulf war, during an uprising, the Kurds wrecked the Kirkuk oil complex. 
How would an impoverished Iraq restore its oil fields without outside aid? Industry analysts have noted that oil field service companies like Halliburton (where Vice President Dick Cheney was the chief executive officer before his nomination as vice president) and Schlumberger would likely be the first companies that could benefit from an effort to rebuild the industry, though certainly all the major oil companies are eager to work in Iraq. 
Yet despite the lure of huge reserves, oil field service companies and others are unlikely to go in just because the United States desires a quick rebuilding of the industry. Oil executives have said that doing business in Iraq depends on whether they can be sure they can make money and whether the country affords them the legal protections to repatriate their profits -- guarantees that would take Iraq, coming out of war and decay, some time to develop.
"The oil companies more or less have the same structure of shareholders, which are 35 to 45 pension funds, and they need to be in line with what their shareholders think of investments around the world," a European oil executive said. "Companies, whoever they are, are not going to pour $5 billion or $10 billion into Iraq without a stable government, a constitution, a central bank. These things need to be clarified before anything goes."

HEADLINE: A Pivot Point for the Middle East 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 1 

 BODY:
Since last June, the Bush administration has premised its policy toward peace in the Middle East on what is apparently a paradox: it has sought an act of selfless statesmanship from a leader, Yasir Arafat, whom it regards as no statesman. 
 In Afghanistan and Iraq, the administration has intently worked toward what it calls regime change, but in the Palestinian Authority it has contented itself with periodic public gestures and demands. It has refused to send high-level envoys to Mr. Arafat, while demanding that he step aside as Palestinian leader in the interests of restarting peace negotiations and ultimately of achieving a state for his people. Mr. Arafat has not done so, contending that it is up to the Palestinians to pick their leaders. 
 While this impasse has endured, so has the essential dynamic of the conflict, despite all the suffering and violence by both Israelis and Palestinians in the last year. As the administration's attention shifted to other crises, Palestinian attacks continued, Israeli soldiers operated more and more freely in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, Israeli blockades of Palestinian cities tightened and Israeli settlements grew. 
The impasse over Mr. Arafat is also likely to muffle the immediate effects of two significant developments here this week, a renewed vow by President Bush to achieve peace between Israelis and Palestinians and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's formation of a new right-wing Israeli government.
In a speech in Washington, Mr. Bush envisioned peace here as he sought support for a war in Iraq, much as his administration once spoke of achieving Middle East peace as it sought support for the Afghan war. Mr. Bush predicted that new leadership in Iraq would better position Palestinians "to choose new leaders" and halt all violence.
That message has important implications for the second development. Mr. Sharon created his coalition with the participation of two parties that oppose any Palestinian state -- a declared goal of Mr. Bush and a declared concession of Mr. Sharon -- and that passionately support the settler movement, which the United States has traditionally considered an obstacle to peace. 
Mr. Bush appeared to be softening the demands on Israel in a draft for a "road map" to peace by the so-called diplomatic quartet of the United States, United Nations, the European Union and Russia. As drafted, the plan called for immediate concessions by both sides, including insisting that Israel dismantle settlement outposts built since March 2001. 
The Israeli government has proposed numerous modifications to the road map, and the Bush administration has repeatedly postponed its announcement of a final plan. 
As long as the Americans keep the pressure on Mr. Arafat and do not demand action against settlements or progress toward negotiations -- that is, as long as Mr. Sharon can continue functioning as he has been -- the far-right in the government and the hawks in Mr. Sharon's Likud Party are unlikely to become restive. They may not even urge Mr. Sharon to renegotiate his pledge to Mr. Bush two years ago not to harm Mr. Arafat, because as long as Mr. Arafat remains in the West Bank, their potential disagreements with Americans and each other over proceeding toward peace are moot, at least judging by Washington's present approach. Mr. Sharon has said that his pledge not to harm Mr. Arafat was all that kept him from trying to force him into exile last year.
Further, Mr. Sharon has set himself up to function as the chief moderating voice on security matters in his cabinet. If Mr. Arafat is the Bush administration's dispensable man, Mr. Sharon in the short term may seem even more indispensable to the administration than he has been, as it seeks to keep matters relatively calm here during an Iraqi campaign. 
Mr. Sharon has replaced as foreign minister his old rival, Benjamin Netanyahu, with a relative novice, Silvan Shalom, a change that puts Mr. Sharon firmly in control of his foreign policy. To some diplomats here, with the appointment of Mr. Netanyahu as finance minister instead, Mr. Sharon is preparing to face up to Israel's dire economic situation and yawning budget deficit. Israel is seeking a large aid package from the Bush administration, which in turn is seeking economic reforms. 
Further, by including the settlers' parties while excluding parties that represent ultra-Orthodox Jews, Mr. Sharon may be signaling where he plans to let the budget ax fall. Shinui, a secular, centrist party that has also joined the government, is a firm opponent of subsidies for the religious. In this analysis, it is Israel's economy, rather than resolving the conflict, that preoccupies Mr. Sharon. 
But to some political analysts, Mr. Sharon is not planning far ahead but merely maneuvering, clumsily at times, to stay a step or two ahead of his multiplying rivals and policy headaches. Itzhak Galnoor, a Hebrew University political scientist, said Mr. Sharon simply felt comfortable embracing the settlers' parties, the National Religious Party and National Union, which also served at times in his last coalition. 
"For him this is not far right," he said. "Those are people who believe in things that are not far from his heart." He noted that Mr. Sharon had awarded the Ministry of Construction and Housing to Effi Eitam, the leader of the National Religious Party. Mr. Sharon himself held that post, and used it to expand the settlements, in the early 1990's under Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. 
At bottom, leaders on both sides are seeking to keep their options open until the expected war in Iraq is under way, which they think will cause the White House to return its attention here and perhaps adjust its policy. "Once this operation starts, things will start moving again here," said Shmuel Sandler, a political scientist at Bar-Ilan University. 
If concessions are demanded, Mr. Sharon can argue that his right-wing coalition gives him little room to maneuver. Or, if he wishes to act on his stated desire for an agreement that yields a limited Palestinian state in less than half of the West Bank and Gaza, he can sustain a break with the right and seek support from other factions, including the left-of-center Labor Party.
For his part, Mr. Arafat has edged toward meeting the administration's demand, saying he will shortly appoint a prime minister, although he has not yet said who will it will be or what powers he will have. More than a year after being declared "irrelevant" by the Israeli government and shunned by the United States, Mr. Arafat remains at the pivot point of peace in the Middle East.

PERSON: Steve Carlin 

HEADLINE: Steve Carlin, 84, '$64,000 Question' Producer 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Steve Carlin, an ingenious and irrepressible producer of television game shows, including "The $64,000 Question" and others that proved to be rigged, died on Feb. 4 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 84.
 The cause was complications of Alzheimer's disease, said his wife, Peggy. 
 Mr. Carlin was executive producer of "The $64,000 Question," "The $64,000 Challenge" and other shows that were dropped in the late 1950's when the networks ended all game shows offering cash prizes. Though rigging game shows -- or "preplanning" outcomes, in the phrase favored by their producers -- was still legal, the public and sponsors would not tolerate them in their new, suddenly tainted context. 
To Mr. Carlin, the shows were simply great entertainment, following in the tradition of radio quiz shows, which, it turned out, had also been fixed. He saw the shows as less about money than about "a celebration of the working class."
The idea was to help contestants the sponsors liked by feeding them answers or big hints. Contestants would then return week after week as the prize escalated to $64,000. Less appealing contestants, of course, got no such help.
Mr. Carlin told a grand jury how and why the shows were rigged, according to Tim Yohn, who wrote a book on the quiz scandals with Joseph Stone, a former Manhattan prosecutor who investigated them. The book was "Prime Time and Misdemeanors: Investigating the 1950's TV Quiz Scandal" (Rutgers, 1992).
The only people charged with wrongdoing in the investigation were contestants who did not tell the truth to the grand jury. Fixing game shows did not become illegal until 1960.
After losing his shows, Mr. Carlin went to Europe, where he produced more than a half-dozen game shows, including the Italian hit "M'ama Non M'ama" ("Love Me, Love Me Not"). In this show, two contestants tried to win the most members of the opposite sex by determining whether the love and romance stories they were telling were true. This show was later produced on American television, for which Mr. Carlin worked regularly after memories of the scandal faded.
Another of his shows was a syndicated version of "The $64,000 Question," which began in the United States in 1976. It was called "The $128,000 Question," to reflect inflation.
Michael Dann, a broadcast consultant and the CBS executive who notified Mr. Carlin that his show was canceled in 1958, called Mr. Carlin a genius at quiz shows.
"He walked around with a game show in his head most of the time," said Mr. Dann, who hired Mr. Carlin to create shows in Britain, Sweden, Italy and other places in Europe after the death of quiz shows in the United States.
"Let's face it," Mr. Dann said, "he was a walking game show."
Steven R. Carlin was born and raised in Brooklyn, and was a graduate of the City College of New York. He started in the radio industry and moved on to TV and developed one of the most popular early children's shows, "Rootie Kazootie," a puppet series on NBC. He also wrote a comic strip, with the artist Myron Waldman, called "Happy the Humbug."
Mr. Carlin went to work for Louis G. Cowan, who owned the production company that developed the concept of "The $64,000 Question" and other game shows. Mr. Cowan's company was a packager that came up with ideas, found sponsors and sold the entire package to the networks. When Mr. Cowan took an executive job with CBS, he sold the company to other producers working there, principally Mr. Carlin.
Mr. Carlin testified before the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight in 1959 that as executive producer of the production company that he had named Entertainment Productions Inc., he was "willing to please the client" by rigging game shows. But he repeatedly denied that he was specifically told to rig anything by the principal sponsor, Revlon.
In addition to his wife, the former Peggy Sanford, Mr. Carlin is survived by his daughter, Melissa, and his brother, Morty.

HEADLINE: Jump in Price Of Oil Puts New Strains On Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The most common cause of recessions, a surge inoil prices, is again afflicting the global economy.
 Just as they have before every American downturn over the last 40 years, energy costs have risen significantly in the last year, capped by a sharp spike since December. With more money being spent on gasoline and heating fuel, economic growth has slowed in both the United States and Europe, and the uneven recovery that began in late 2001 is facing perhaps its biggest threat yet. 
 Most forecasters expect the United States economy to avoid a new recession this year, saying that only an unexpectedly protracted war in Iraq would keep oil at its current price or higher. But any war is an unknown, and the price increases for both oil and natural gas have already caused consumers to cut back on other spending. The increases have also created a new problem for businesses trying to emerge from the hangover of the late-1990's boom. 
"The economy is extremely fragile," said Mark M. Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a research company in West Chester, Pa. "We've got some real problems if this drags on for any length of time."
Energy costs began rising more than a year ago, when the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries cut production in response to the weak global economy. The potential war in the Persian Gulf, political chaos in Venezuela and a cold winter in the United States caused the price of a barrel of oil to soar to almost $40 on Thursday, the highest since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, before it retreated to $36.60 on Friday in New York. That is up about 69 percent from a year ago.
Every time that oil prices have risen by at least 60 percent since World War II, a recession has occurred in the United States, with the exception of a one-month blip in oil prices in 1987. The current annual increase is similar to the jumps of late 1990, when a recession was starting, and the summer of 2000, nine months before another began.
Higher energy costs reduce economic growth by effectively forcing families and businesses to send more money to oil-producing countries, leaving less to be spent on goods and services that create jobs at home. 
Energy prices affect Europe and Japan even more severely than the United States, which produces more of its own oil and natural gas. Britain reported last week that its economy had grown at the most sluggish pace in 10 years during the last three months of 2002. The German economy shrank at the end of last year for the first time in a year.
"The single best cyclical indicator for the world economy is the price of oil," said Andrew J. Oswald, an economist at the University of Warwick outside Coventry, England. "Nothing moves in the world economy without oil in there somewhere."
In recent weeks, a number of big American manufacturers have blamed higher energy costs for cuts in their earnings forecasts. A few have cited oil prices while postponing new investments that could add jobs, even as an overall rise in business spending has suggested that the economy might be picking up speed were it not for energy. 
For example, DuPont, the large chemical maker, recently delayed until June an expansion that had been scheduled to start in February, according to , a spokeswoman. 
In Elkhorn, Wis., Hudapack Metal Treating, which employs 125 people, is investing in technology to make its furnaces less dependent on natural gas -- which costs more than twice what it did a year ago -- rather than spending to increase its production of bolts for pickup trucks. 
"You can't take an extra $20,000 a month, throw it at gas prices and expect to be profitable," said Gary Huss, the president of Hudapack, which is merely breaking even. 
The ailing airline industry is also being hit hard. American Airlines will probably spend about $200 million more on fuel this quarter than it did a year ago. Standard & Poor's lowered the company's credit rating on Friday, saying fuel costs were one reason that American might have to file soon for bankruptcy protection. 
Many companies buy advance fuel contracts, a practice known as hedging, to protect them from some of the short-term price increases. United Parcel Service has purchased gasoline hedges, but it will still increase the fuel surcharge on its deliveries to 1.5 percent tomorrow, from 1.25 percent, because of increased costs.
Rising oil prices appear to be helping keep layoffs at a pace that few analysts expected, according to government figures, delaying any major improvement in the nation's moribund job market. The economy employs almost two million fewer people than it did two years ago.
Consumers, paying almost 50 percent more for gasoline than a year ago, in turn are reducing their spending on other goods. Over all, purchases at American retail chain stores fell 1.1 percent in January, according to the Bank of TokyoMitsubishi, which adjusts its numbers for seasonal variations. 
Sales of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks have fallen recently, while car sales are still rising. The largest trucks are selling particularly poorly compared with a year ago, according to Morgan & Company, a research firm. Analysts are divided over whether fuel prices are a reason, noting that some carmakers have recently reduced discounts for many trucks.
Over all, families are spending about 5 percent of their budgets on energy, up from 4.1 percent in early 2002, according to Economy.com. 
About one-third of Americans say the recent spike has caused them "financial hardship," according to a recent Gallup poll. More than one- quarter said they thought that gas prices would be near their current level six months from now, and about one half said they would rise. 
"I think it's going to get much worse," said Teri Chavez, a public relations executive in Denver, as she filled the tank of her blue Volvo station wagon last week. "Does it mean that I'm going to stop driving? No. But I might think twice before I take my car up in the mountains."
In 1991, oil prices fell almost as soon as the United States attacked Iraq, and many economists think the same could happen this year. Even if a war temporarily reduced the supply of energy, President Bush could release oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to bring down prices, analysts note.
But because oil inventories are lower than they were 12 years ago, a price decline could be smaller today than at the outset of the Persian Gulf war. Based on the price of oil futures contracts, investors are expecting oil prices to remain around $38 a barrel through April and then gradually decline, falling below $30 by the end of the year.
At those levels, oil prices would still probably prevent the economy from growing rapidly this year. But they would also make a new recession unlikely, particularly because business executives have recently shown signs of optimism, increasing their investments in new technology and equipment.
"It's definitely a negative," said William C. Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, referring to the cost of energy. "It's just not at the point where we think it's recessionary."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ANKARA; 
TURKISH DEPUTIES REFUSE TO ACCEPT AMERICAN TROOPS

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, March 1 

 BODY:
The Turkish Parliament today dealt a heavy blow to the Bush administration's plans for a northern front against Iraq, narrowly rejecting a measure that would have allowed thousands of American combat troops to use the country as a base for an attack.
 More Turkish lawmakers supported the measure than opposed it, but the resolution failed because the total number of "no" votes and abstentions exceeded the number of favorable votes. Under the Turkish Constitution, a resolution can become law only if it is supported by a majority of the lawmakers present. 
 The final tally was 264 to 251, with 19 abstentions. 
The defeat stunned American officials, who had been confident that Turkey's leaders would be able to persuade the members of their party to support the measure. American ships had already begun unloading heavy equipment at Turkish ports in anticipation of a victory, and two dozen vessels were idling off the coast.
The vote also quashed the possibility, at least for now, that Turkish troops would enter northern Iraq, a prospect that many there, especially the country's Kurds, regarded with dread.
In the turmoil after the parliamentary session, American diplomats said they were requesting a "clarification" of the vote. But American officials said they were not seeking another vote, and there was no indication that Turkish officials were either.
The vote came after weeks of negotiations between the United States and Turkey, largely over the amount of economic assistance Turkey would receive in the event of a war with Iraq.
The defeat posed immediate military problems for American officials, who had been counting on Turkey's support to bring as many as 62,000 American troops into the country to build a northern front. A senior Pentagon official said today that the American military would be able to stage the operation without Turkey's help, but most military analysts agreed that it would be extremely difficult without a northern base.
The defeat of the resolution was a stunning political blow as well. Turkey, one of the America's closest allies and a member of NATO, is a secular Muslim democracy whose support in the region the Bush administration has craved. Indeed, American officials have called Turkey a model for the type of system they are hoping an invasion of Iraq would help bring elsewhere in the Middle East.
The defeat seemed to surprise Turkey's leaders, who only hours earlier had predicted that Parliament would approve the measure. Prime Minister Abdullah Gul, and the chief of the governing Justice and Development Party, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, had endorsed the resolution, and both men had urged their party, which controls a large majority of the Parliament, to support it.
But the American request had placed Turkey's lawmakers in a difficult position; polls here indicate that as many as 9 of 10 Turks oppose involvement in a war against Iraq. In the end, the resolution failed because nearly 100 members of the governing party appeared to have voted against the measure or to have abstained.
In an interview afterward, Mr. Gul said Turkey's democratic system had spoken with finality. "Turkey is the only democratic country in the region," Mr. Gul said. "The decision is clear. We have to respect this decision, as this is what democracy requires."
The vote casts a shadow over the American-Turkish relationship, which Turkish officials said had come under great strain during the negotiations. Mr. Gul and Mr. Erdogan made no secret of their distaste for the American plans, but associates said both men had concluded that the relationship with the United States was too valuable to endanger by saying no. But as the discussions wore on and tales of American high-handedness spread, Turkish lawmakers, as well as the Turkish public, appeared to become more and more alienated.
"The relationship is spoiled," said Murat Mercan, a member of Parliament from the majority party. "The Americans dictated to us. It became a business negotiation, not something between friends. It disgusted me."
In Ankara, the United States Embassy said American ties with Turkey would not be threatened by the vote. "We respect this as a democratic result -- we will live with that," said an embassy spokesman. "We worked together as allies and we will continue to work together as allies."
The Turkish vote throws into question the ambitious military strategy that had been devised to overwhelm the forces of President Saddam Hussein. American military commanders wanted to begin an attack from Turkey that would pin down Iraqi forces in the north and keep them away from the main American force driving from the south. 
Pentagon officials said they were still hoping that Turkish officials would hold another vote, and there were no signs that the American ships off the Turkish coast had been moved.
The officials said that they were determined, even without Turkey, to open a northern front. Such an operation could entail airlifting troops and tanks from bases in the Persian Gulf.
Pentagon officials said that Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, has backup plans for moving American forces into northern Iraq. The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Richard B. Myers, said on Friday, "General Franks, as we speak, is looking at lots of options." 
The vote today probably also eliminates the possibility that Turkey would send troops into northern Iraq on its own. Turkish leaders had been planning to send tens of thousands of their own troops into the region partly to ensure that the area's Kurds would not be able to set up an independent state.
Indeed, Turkey's leaders said repeatedly that one of the main reasons for supporting the American plan was to ensure that Turkey had a role in the future shape of Iraq. That role, for now, seems doomed. Even before the vote today, there were several issues that remained unresolved between the two countries. The main sticking point was the American insistence that the Turks continue to adhere to an agreement the country has signed with the International Monetary Fund, which has imposed strict conditions on Turkish lawmakers to reform their economy. In exchange, Turkey has received billions of dollars in loans. The Turkish government is currently negotiating with the fund to receive about $1.5 billion in new loans.
With the Americans promising $6 billion in direct aid, Turkish officials wanted to be able receive the money before striking any new agreement with the fund, but Washington insisted that Turkey reach a deal with the fund first. American officials were worried that Turkey, armed with the new American cash, would walk away from the fund, defeating the purpose of the American aid, which was to maintain confidence in the Turkish economy during a war.
Even with the outstanding differences, Turkey's leaders had tried to persuade reluctant party members, twice postponing a vote to bring them along. Afterward, some members of the ruling party said that several Turkish lawmakers had not voted as they had indicated they would. The vote and the debate were closed to the public.

HEADLINE: Oil Price Jump Adds To Fears on Economy 

 BODY:
Just as they have before every American economic downtown over the last 40 years, energy costs have risen significantly in the last year, including a sharp spike since December. 
 A possible war in the Persian Gulf, political chaos in Venezuela and a cold winter in the United States have helped push prices about 69 percent higher than a year ago. 
 While most forecasters say they expect the United States to avoid a new recession this year, price increases for both oil and natural gas have caused consumers to cut back on other spending. A result is a new problem for businesses trying to emerge from the hangover of the late 1990's boom. And Europe and Japan, which produce less of their own oil and natural gas, are affected even more severely.
Article, Page 25.

HEADLINE: Got Milk? Yes, but That's Not the Issue 

BYLINE:  By GEORGINA GUSTIN 

 BODY:
LIKE Connecticut's struggling dairy industry, David Jacquier's farm, a bucolic spread dotted with hundreds of cows, is shrinking.
 "I'm starting to sell real estate," said Mr. Jacquier, who has been forced to sell off parcels of his Elm Knoll Farm in East Canaan to keep the cash-strapped operation afloat. "That's the worse thing you can do in this business." 
 Mr. Jacquier said he didn't have a choice, and many of Connecticut's dairy farmers are facing the same predicament. The prices dairy farmers are getting for milk are at their lowest point in 25 years and production costs are skyrocketing,. 
"We started the year with 200 farms, and already we've lost five," said Gabe Moquin, who heads the dairy division at the state's agriculture department. "They just can't make a profit." 
Connecticut's dairy farmers are getting paid about $1 per gallon of milk, a drop from the $1.65 they were getting a year and a half ago. At the same time, consumers are paying the same prices for milk at the grocery store -- about $3 a gallon -- which led to accusations that the retailers are price gouging.
"Something is desperately wrong with the picture now," said Richard Blumenthal, the state attorney general, who has recommended legislation that would limit what milk retailers and processors can charge for fluid milk.
Under the legislation, An Act Concerning the Fair Pricing of Milk, if the wholesale price charged to a retailer by a processor is 40 percent above the price paid to the farmers, the processor will be investigated. If the retail price is 40 percent above the wholesale price paid the processor, then the retailer would be investigated.
"Our aim is to help both the farmer and the consumer by eliminating unconscionable profits resulting from price gouging, and to restore competition to the industry," Mr. Blumenthal said. "Essentially the legislation guarantees the farmer will be paid a fair price, or at least a fairer price, because it reduces the amount it could be marked up and pegs the final price paid by the consumer to the price paid to the farmer. In other words, if the price in the supermarket rises, the price paid to the farmer also rises."
Not everyone, however, thinks the legislation in its current form would solve the problem.
At a public hearing at the Capitol in Hartford on Wednesday, dairy farmers, lawmakers, food industry officials and academics gathered to present their views on how best to save the state's industry, while also giving consumers a break at the grocery store. 
The number of dairy farms in the state dropped from 6,233 in 1940, to 663 in 1980, to 195 today. While some wonder why such a small industry matters to a state where agriculture represents only a fraction of the economy, others stress the peripheral benefits of a dairy industry presence.
"The dairy industry is an integral part of our economy and quality of life," Mr. Blumenthal said. "We spend a lot of money to preserve farmland, and helping farmers stay in business when they provide an essential item that is important."
The state's dairy farms are mostly in New London, Windham and Litchfield counties, in scenic rural areas. In the Quinebaug-Shetucket Heritage Corridor, which encompasses 32 towns and was designated a national heritage site by Congress in 1994, the farms are part of the open landscape.
"We lose farms and they can be developed, and let's face it, with the population push, we would end up looking like Newark," said Andrea Ader, of Quinebaug-Shetucket Heritage Corridor Inc., which oversees the area. "That's fine if you want to look like Newark, but there are fewer and fewer family farms. You impact the character of the valley, and it's not just open space. It takes something to be dedicated to milking cows twice a day."
Bonnie Burr, the director of government relations for the Connecticut Farm Bureau, noted the dairy industry in Connecticut earned $74 million in 2001, while keeping roughly 175,000 acres as open space.
Under the state's Farmland Preservation Program, Ms. Burr said, the state buys the development rights to farmland, which allows the farmer to continue farming the land while guaranteeing that it never gets developed. Many farmers, however, when strapped for cash, end up selling land to developers anyway. It is faster than going through a government sale, and it is more lucrative.
"If the prices don't come back by July, I'll be done; I'm losing roughly $300,000 a year," said Mr. Jacquier, explaining that it costs him $13.75 to produce a hundredweight of milk, or 100 pounds, though he is being paid only $11 for the amount by processors. 
"If I sell my cows and real estate, I'll break even," he said. "I'll go get a job. Once they put blacktops and driveways on it, it's over with. We'll grow houses." 
The reasons for the recent drop in milk prices -- from about $17 dollars per hundredweight two years ago to between $11 and $13 these days -- are varied and complex. The industry says production has increased nationally, with milk flooding the market from huge producers in western states, while consumption of dairy products has dropped. 
In the Northeast, where land and labor costs are considerably higher than elsewhere, the expiration of the Northeast Dairy Compact in 2001 has compounded the problem by removing federal price supports for all farmers. Many in the industry believe another regional compact to reinstitute federal support could be the answer, but in the meantime, northeastern states are trying to address the problem through their own legislatures.
Not everyone agrees on the approach.
"Price gouging is a consumer issue, not so much a farmer issue," said Bob Wellington, an economist with Agri-Mark, a cooperative of New England dairy farmers. "But the problem is the shares the farmers are getting are shrinking, and they're getting crushed by the lower milk prices. Most farmers are saying this is the worse financial situation in decades. There are a lot of auctions lined up."
Mr. Wellington explained that while the farmers are struggling, their troubles are creating a domino effect, and related services, like equipment and grain sales, are also suffering. "It's almost like a spiraling cycle now," he said.
Ms. Burr, of the farm bureau, also questions the legislation. "When you look at the bill, while it certainly addresses the consumer needs it doesn't really have the ability to put money back in the farmers' pockets," she said. "We don't think this will do anything for the farmers."
Another price support program, part of the 2002 Farm Bill, guarantees price supports, but critics say it only helps smaller producers.
Once a farmer has produced 2.4 million gallons in a given year, they are no longer eligible for federal cash.
"It's a safety net lying flaccid on a concrete floor," Mr. Wellington said. "If you hit it you're already dead."
Ronald W. Cotterill, who has published many studies on the dairy industry, said he believed the legislation would indeed raise the prices paid to farmers while keeping retail costs at a fair point.
"I've concluded the proposed legislation addressed the farmer end probably more strongly than the consumer end," said Mr. Cotterill, director of the Food Marketing Policy Center at the University of Connecticut.
Mr. Cotterill also said that he believed lower prices at the retailer would result in higher consumption by consumer.
Mr. Blumenthal agreed.
"Certainly price is a consideration when you're considering whether to buy the extra quart," he said.
For some, though, the legislation is just a start.
"Right now we're addressing the consumer's concerns," said George Wilber, a state representative and former dairy farmer who is co-sponsoring the bill. "The next step is working toward putting money in the farmers pockets."

HEADLINE: Bank Robbers Strike 5 Times 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS STAUDTER 

DATELINE: OSSINING 

 BODY:
WHEN the M&T Bank here in the Arcadian Shopping Center was robbed on Feb. 21, local law enforcement officials agreed it was a brazen act. After all, the lone bandit chose a bank that is situated as far away as possible from the two roadway entrances into the shopping center, which are both often logjammed with traffic, making a quick getaway problematical. The bank robber, however, simply walked out the bank's door , through the length of the parking lot, and flagged down a taxi, according to the Ossining police. 
 The first bank to be robbed in the village of Ossining in more than 20 years, the M&T Bank was also the fifth bank held up in the county within the last two months, according to local police officials. So far there have been no arrests. 
 On the day after the robbery at the M&T Bank it was back to business as usual with a few new wrinkles: a security guard now eyeballed customers and visitors as they entered the bank. The bank's employees, including Doreen Edwards, the branch manager, were not talking to outsiders. Inquiries about the robbery were forwarded to an executive at the bank's headquarters in Buffalo, who said that it was company policy not to comment on robberies. 
Chris Henderson, corporate security manager for M&T Bank, said with 475 branch locations through four states -- New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland andWest Virginia -- "we can't afford to put a guard at every location." In Ossining, he said, "there really wasn't a need for a security guard" until the robbery occurred, "and until the subject who committed the robbery is caught, we'll keep a guard there." 
According to a statement released by the village of Ossining Police Department, an African-American man in his 30's, between 5- foot-6 and 5-foot-10, with black, short-cropped hair and wearing a black jacket, entered the M&T Bank about 1:30 p.m. and demanded money from a teller using an unspecified threat but without displaying any weapon.
The robber took "over a thousand dollars," said Lt. William V. Sullivan, the commander of the police department's detective division. 
The cabdriver that the robber flagged down, Vanessa Fagan, a 19-year-old Peekskill resident, said she was about to stop at the McDonald's in the shopping center for a lunch break when the man politely asked her to take him to the Ossining train station. En route he changed his mind and asked to be left at the Philipse Manor train station in Sleepy Hollow.
Traveling down Route 9, Ms. Fagan noticed her passenger was "counting money with a big smile on his face," but then her radio dispatcher began asking questions over the radio about her fare,and the man, visibly upset, asked to be let out immediately on the side of the road, not far from the intersection with Route 117. "He jumped right into a snow bank," Ms. Fagan said.
On her return to Ossining a few moments later, Ms. Fagan saw in her rearview mirror that the man was walking north on Route 9, and then several police cars sped by her going south.
Somehow the bank robber disappeared. Patrol units from Ossining, Sleepy Hollow and Mount Pleasant checked residences while the police from the Metroplitan Transit Authority, the state Department of Environmental Conservation and the Harrison Police Department's K-9 unit also combed the area around Arch Hill. A police helicopter from the Westchester County Department of Public Safety joined the search. By 5 p.m. the search was called off.
Similarly, an unarmed man who robbed the Chase Manhattan Bank in Bedford on Dec. 26 also escaped on foot and was last seen walking down Route 117 toward Mount Kisco when the police lost sight of him, according to Bedford police.Two days earlier a pair of armed robbers fled from an HSBC bank branch in Yonkers, and that investigation is still open, said Detective William Maher of the Yonkers Police Department.
The police were also still looking for a pair of armed robbers who held up the Fourth Street branch of the Sound Shore Federal Savings Bank in New Rochelle on Jan. 29. Earlier that week a man, unarmed and possibly connected to another robbery in the village, had taken about $1,500 from a teller at a Fleet Bank branch in Pelham Manor.
Detective Christopher Mcalvoy of the Pelham Manor Police Department said that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was helping out with the Fleet Bank robbery, but several other officials from other local police departments dealing with recent bank robberies within their jurisdictions, including Lieutenant Sullivan of Ossining, said the F.B.I. had balked at aiding investigations of bank robberies, which are considered federal offenses, if no weapon was used or seen by witnesses during the crime because of continuing anti-terrorism responsibilities.
Joseph Valiquette, an F.B.I. agent and spokesman for the New York office, said the F.B.I. gets involved with armed robberies, which include those committed using any weapon, and robberies that appear to be part of larger sprees and other out-of-state crimes.
"There are concurrent jurisdictions between the F.B.I. and local law enforcement on these crimes, so sometimes it just doesn't make sense to duplicate efforts," Mr. Valiquette said. "The No. 1 priority right now is terrorism, which has strained our resources as it is, so we're asking local law enforcement agencies to pick up more of the slack for now."
Mr. Valiquette said that there were only four armed bank robberies in Westchester and Putnam counties last year.
At the M&T Bank in Ossining, several customers leaving the bank were surprised to find that the bank had just been robbed. "But what can you expect in this economy?" said Joanne Tall, a resident. "Money gets tight and things get weird."
Anyone with information about the bank robberies can call Westchester County Crime Stoppers at (800)898-8477.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Feb. 21 holdup at M&T Bank in Ossining was the fifth bank robbery in the county in two months. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Southampton College Seeks a Makeover 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON 

 BODY:
FACED with growing yearly deficits, Southampton College of Long Island University will be transformed in an effort to attract and retain a larger student body with reinvigorated, faculty-taught undergraduate programs built around a new42-credit core curriculum now being devised, university and college officials said last week.
 At the same time, the number of courses and teachers are likely to be pared down and average class size will grow. 
 "Business as usual is no longer an option," said David J. Steinberg, the president of Long Island University. "We need to make this transition, and we see ourselves as having a unique opportunity to restructure a liberal arts college for the 21st century."
Dr. Steinberg and other officials said university trustees had never seriously considered closing the college, an important cultural and economic asset on the East End. But they acknowledged that the deficits, which the university had absorbed in the past, were casting a shadow over the college, which opened in 1963. 
"I would say that we did have very serious questions about how we could continue without major changes," said Jeffrey Kane, the university vice president for academic affairs.
The point man for implementing the changes will be Daniel J. Rodas, an assistant vice president at Duke University, who was named last week as the Southampton College provost, succeeding Timothy Bishop, who resigned last year to make his successful run for Congress. The university said Dr. Rodas was an expert on finances and academic programs for private liberal arts colleges.
In a telephone interview, Dr. Rodas said he supported the concept of transformation and would seek to assure academic excellence and sound financial management at the college, but declined to discuss details of cost-saving steps he might take. "I will need to actually be there to understand more of the situation," he said.
The changes to the core curriculum and other revisions have influential backing from Robert F.X. Sillerman, an entertainment industry billionaire and the college chancellor, who, with his wife, Laura Baudo Sillerman, has given the college more than $17 million in recent years. 
Mr. Sillerman, who made his fortune buying and selling radio stations and in the music concert business, said he expected to announce within several months major new financial support for the changes. 
The nearly 1,500-student residential college, best known for its top-ranked marine sciences program, currently has 1,269 undergraduates and a deficit that has reached about $5 million a year. Its annual budget is $22 million.
Officials said they sought an additional 400 undergraduates, with an emphasis on students from New York State who are eligible for tuition assistance under a state program. "We are looking for students who can pay more of their own way," said Charles Hitchcock, the interim college dean.
About 1,160 of the current graduate and undergraduate students are New York residents, including many from western Suffolk and Nassau County, and about two-thirds of students are women. Tuition, room and board cost about $27,270. About 82 percent of Southampton students receive financial aid. Because the college has a small endowment, the scholarship money it offers comes from tuition fee reductions.
University officials said the changes would mean more classroom teaching for the college's 65 full-time faculty members, caps and adjustments in credit requirements for majors, and probable reductions in the number of majors and in the approximately 150 adjunct professors now teaching at the college.They would take effect for the freshman class entering in 2004.
The college would also seek to eliminate small upper-level classes in which only three or four students enrolled and would aim for an average class size of about 20 students. The current average is about 15. 
The core program would involve an interdisciplinary approach in which, hypothetically, "Moby-Dick" could be taught both as literature and from a marine biology perspective by different professors.
But administrators and faculty said the exact content of the curriculum and details of how it would be changed were still to be worked out. "We all realize that we are just beginning the process," said Paul Forestell, an associate professor of psychology and the chairman of the faculty council. He said the full-time faculty had voted to support the change. "We need to get into how different approaches to knowledge can inform each other in better educating students," he said.
Patrick Gunn, a representative for the adjuncts, said he saw "a philosophical shift regarding the use of us." But, he said, "If this is simply a situation of using their full-time faculty to its greatest potential, I can't find any fault with it." 
Dr. Hitchcock, the college dean, said the changes "cast our lot into transforming ourselves into a really fine small liberal arts college with particularly good marine science programs." 
In the past, he said, "we were somewhat conflicted between being a liberal arts and sciences college and a marine science college."
Marine science programs, which have produced 35 Fulbright scholars in the past 25 years, attract the largest number of undergraduates. "There is really no one ahead of us as far as small schools go," said Christopher J. Gobler, the marine science program coordinator.
Dr. Steinberg said marine science would continue to be a college cornerstone. "It is going to remain and it is vital," he said. "But it is not the be-all and end-all." 
With major campuses in Brooklyn and Brookville as well as Southampton, 31,000 students and an annual budget of $385 million, Long Island University is the seventh largest private university in the country. Dr. Steinberg said part of the financial pressure on the university was caused by cuts in education proposed by Governor Pataki to close the state budget deficit. Under the governor's proposed budget, L.I.U. would lose just under $7 million and Southampton College would lose about $480,000, the university said. 
Dr. Steinberg and other officials said the financial crunch at the college offered an opportunity for far-reaching changes in academic programs that would be impossible in older, tradition-bound colleges or large universities. 
Dr. Kane, the L.I.U. vice president and the former dean of education at the university's C.W. Post College in Brookville, said officials studied core curricula across the country to arrive at a framework for one at Southampton that would stress interdisciplinary study to produce literate students versed in arts and sciences and ready both for the job market and to act as global citizens.
"What we think we can do is provide students not only with the skills they need to get out in the marketplace, but with a higher sense of direction in their own lives," he said. "And in the end students not only want that, they yearn for it."
Mr. Sillerman, the Southampton chancellor, said he had been the impetus for the changes at the college. "It needed to be transformed and it is going to be transformed," he said. He said within six months he hoped to announce investments in the college for a student center, dorms, classrooms and the hiring of new faculty members. 
College officials acknowledged the central role played by Mr. Sillerman, whose post as chancellor is largely honorary but whose largess lends considerable weight to his opinions.
Dr. Steinberg said he and other college officials were actively seeking to raise financial support for the college and were depending on Mr. Sillerman for help. A professional fundraiser, Barbara Grodd, starts work this month.

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
Rolling With 'Better for You' Food Bandwagon

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
AMERICANS may be paying more attention to nutrition, but they still reach for plenty of processed foods at the market. One byproduct of this paradox is the popularity of so-called "better for you" foods, which mimic the taste of conventional snacks and other packaged foods but lack the customary preservatives, additives, cholesterol and sugar. 
 Perhaps no one has catered to America's contradictory appetites as successfully as Irwin D. Simon. A former sales and marketing executive at both Haagen-Dazs and SlimFast, Mr. Simon has spent the last decade cobbling together more than two dozen natural and organic food companies into the Hain Celestial Group in Melville. Revenues at Hain, perhaps best known for its Celestial Seasonings herbal teas and its Terra Chips line of vegetable chips, approached $400 million last year. 
 In December, Hain Celestial spent $52 million to buy Imagine Foods, an organic-food company that specializes in soy-milk and rice-milk products. Hain was already the world's largest producer of natural foods, an industry term for those made without additives or artificial ingredients. After the Imagine Foods deal, it also became the world's largest producer of organic foods, the term usually used for foods grown without pesticides. 
Mr. Simon, who is from Nova Scotia, founded Hain Celestial's predecessor, Kineret Foods, 10 years ago. While he does not describe himself as a health-food fan, he recalls having grown disenchanted with the products and values of corporate America. 
He believed there was a growing mass market for healthier foods. "I decided after leaving SlimFast to set up my own food company and build up from there," said Mr. Simon, who is Hain's president as well as its chairman and chief executive.
In 1993, he founded Kineret, a kosher frozen-food company in Jericho. In its first year Kineret offered its stock to the public, raising about $3 million, Mr. Simon said, and that financed a series of acquisitions that brought in Farm Foods, Pizsoy and Hain Pure Foods. 
Mr. Simon acknowledged one inherent contradiction in using a kosher food company to build a "better for you" food empire: kosher food, while it is often perceived as being healthful, is not necessarily low in fat. "A lot of kosher food is fried in the highest fat content going," he said. "But people think of kosher food as safe, and we built on that perception."
Following the Hain acquisition, Mr. Simon changed Kineret's name to Hain Pure Foods, to better reflect its business focus. Using revenues from operations to finance further acquisitions, he picked up small but growing brands like Health Valley, which makes organic soups, snack bars, cereals and cookies; Earth's Best, which makes organic baby foods; and Garden of Eatin', which makes organic snacks.
In 2000, Hain bought Celestial Seasonings, the herbal tea company, for about $390 million and renamed itself again. In 2001, it acquired Yves Veggie Cuisine, a Canadian producer of soy-based burgers and cheese alternatives, and Lima, a Belgian natural and organic food concern, expanding its presence in Europe.
In his acquisitions, Mr. Simon said in an interview at Hain headquarters near the Long Island Expressway, he focused on brands with the potential for faster growth. "I look for four things in a brand," he said, warming to his subject. "First is a great product. Second, it must be great-tasting. Third, it has to have a reason for being. Fourth, it has to have nutritional value." 
People in the food business say that Mr. Simon is a principal player in the industry's fastest-growing category, natural and organic foods. "He is clearly one of the leaders in the industry," said David Seckman, the executive director of the Natural Nutritional Foods Association in Newport Beach, Calif. "In fact, he may be the industry's leader at this point."
That industry has enjoyed rapid growth over the last decade, due to social trends and in no small degree to the business skills of people like Mr. Simon. In 1992, when he started his own company, the natural and organic food market was a $4.2 billion a year. Now, 10 years later, the market has tripled to $13.5 billion, according to Patrick Rae, the publisher of Nutrition Business Journal in San Diego.
Mr. Seckman credited Mr. Simon and Hain Celestial, which is a member of his trade group, with playing a major role in standardizing the definitions of terms like "natural," "organic" and even "dietetic." The definitions, previously a mishmash of rules handled state by state, were streamlined last year by the Department of Agriculture, but they have recently been the target of political efforts to weaken them. 
Mr. Seckman said that Mr. Simon was also leading the industry's effort to strengthen the laws governing packaging claims and nutrition disclosures. 
"Hain voluntarily adopted the toughest standards ahead of the new Federal labeling requirements in 1994," he said. "Irwin has spearheaded our efforts to develop higher standards across the industry."
Natural and organic foods occupy account for less than 3 percent of the $480 billion American food market, but the combined category grew at nearly 5 percent in 2001, the last year for which data is available, Mr. Seckman said. Both categories are expected to accelerate through at least 2005, he added, growing as much as 10 percent annually.
If organic foods are broken out as a separate category, the growth rate approaches 24 percent, according to the Organic Trade Association in Greenfield, Mass. 
While many chain supermarkets now stock organic and natural products, most sales are still made by independently operated health-food stores and by specialty chains like Wild Oats, Fairway and Wild by Nature. About two-thirds of Hain's sales last year came from health-food and specialty stores, and the remaining third from traditional supermarkets.
"Although Hain Celestial Group is not yet well known to the average supermarket shopper, its portfolio of 'better for you' brands is well known to health-food store buyers," John M. McMillin, a financial analyst at Prudential Financial in New York, wrote in a December report. 
Mr. Simon is pushing for more supermarket sales. "One of our goals is to sell more of our brands from the traditional supermarkets and grocery stores," he said.
Howard Glickberg, an owner of Fairway, which has two specialty food stores in Manhattan and one in Plainview, said that Mr. Simon had imposed a corporate approach on what had been a homespun way of operating.
"Most of the companies that Irwin purchased were mom-and-pop companies," Mr. Glickberg said. "Irwin brought them professionalism. He brought these products into mainstream America."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
The U.S.O.C. Wanted Class. What It Got Was Crass.

BYLINE:  By SELENA ROBERTS 

 BODY:
THERE were no aerial views of Lloyd Ward's Florida home on the tube, but plenty of politicians looking down at his personal excesses. 
 There were no stockholders to betray, just Olympic sponsors who wondered if Ward was keeping the books or if the books were keeping him. 
 There were no endearing nicknames like Kenny Boy, only staffers who privately called Ward "H.A.M." for the cavity-causing "hearts and minds" speech he delivered at every banquet stop.
Drawn to scale, Ward was not Kenneth L. Lay or L. Dennis Kozlowski during his 16 months as the head of the United States Olympic Committee, but a Mini-Me entrant into America's exclusive club of tainted chief executives. 
Until his resignation yesterday, Ward reflected the C.E.O. culture he came of age in by leaning on his charismatic image as a substitute for substance, by offering up fortune-cookie phrases instead of hard truths about the future.
And that is exactly why he was hired. As easy as it is to dissect Ward's flaws -- like his complete lack of self-awareness while his every folly played out in public -- it is more constructive to understand why the U.S.O.C. board fell for him in the first place. 
Ward was the trophy date of the U.S.O.C., which was desperate for validation and insecure about its identity. He may have been a failure as the grand wizard at Maytag, but he was its vision of corporate success, entering his interviews wearing tailored suits and a gold watch with a diamond at 12 o'clock.
Everything he said was silk. Sitting on a couch in his office just weeks after his hire, Ward was at his polished best when discussing the personal epiphany that led him to Colorado Springs.
"I'm here because I've chosen to be here," Ward said earnestly. "I had other alternatives. If I were not in the stage of my life where I wanted to make a difference more than I wanted to make money, I wouldn't be here. It's about what's significant."
You could eat that up with a spoon, right? But on the night the Olympic committee announced it had selected Ward after an interview process that played out like a beauty pageant, there was a mysterious delay in the celebration. 
What was the holdup? About $50,000. Although the advertised salary for the job was $500,000, Ward squeezed another $50,000 out of the suddenly nervous leaders before he would say yes.
No price was too high to give the joint a little class. And this is what the committee members wanted. To them, it was only a matter of time before Ward would turn the heads of sponsors as he created the brand identity the committee craved. 
And, unfortunately, he succeeded. After months of turmoil on Ward's watch, after extravagant severance packages and allegations of nepotism, after senatorial sleuthing and suspect expense reports, the Olympic committee is recognized in every home in the nation. So is Enron, so is Tyco, so is WorldCom.
And as in each case, the chief offers up a "who me?" response. "Clearly, competing interests within the U.S.O.C. have placed its C.E.O.'s in an untenable, if not impossible, role," Ward said, playing the victim in his farewell statement. "My hope is that the governance structure at the U.S.O.C. be clarified at an early date to eliminate the backbiting we who have been C.E.O. have endured."
Ward does have a point. The U.S.O.C. is full of smiling assassins. But what the Olympic committee must do upon restructuring is to eliminate its starry-eyed approach to filling its top-paying job.
"We cannot foul up again," one Olympic committee executive said. "We have to think in terms of a sports person, not a corporate bigwig with tons of conflicts." 
But in the absence of common sense, names like Donald Fehr and George Steinbrenner have emerged as dream candidates. While Fehr may be deft in economic maneuvers in his role as baseball's union boss, how can a leader who has obstructed drug testing for players have credibility in an Olympic movement that prohibits cough syrup? 
While Steinbrenner understands the machinations of the Olympic committee as a former board member, and is synonymous with winning, imagine how sticky his YES network ties might be when television deals come up for renewal? 
Please, no big names need apply. Even in a trimmed down form, the Olympic committee, by its very volunteerism nature, is too petty to provide room for an ego larger than an eraser.
It needs someone who is down to earth, steady and businesslike. Before Ward and after Norm Blake, another corporate marquee decision gone wrong, the Olympic committee had its answer: Scott Blackmun. 
Over the past four years, the only time there has been peace within the organization was when Blackmun quietly steered the group during his stint as the interim chief. He was pushed aside in the Beatlemania over Ward, pushed all the way to Los Angeles, where he works now. 
Blackmun is happy, probably too happy to think of a return. But he should be the prototype chief for the Olympic committee. He is not sensational, just sensible. Just what the U.S.O.C. needs.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Smaller and Faster Emerges Victorious

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
ROY JONES Jr. answered questions that have formed the basis of competition for centuries, from playgrounds to formal fields of competition.
 Can a great little man defeat a good big man. Can speed defeat power and size? 
 Well, yes -- if the fighter is Roy Jones. 
Jones, the onetime middlweight and current light-heavyweight champion, took away John Ruiz's heavyweight championship last night with a unanimous 12-round decision. The fight proved once again, as these sort of championship matches often do, that some things can't be measured by scales and yardsticks: talent, heart, drive. 
One thing that can be measured, speed, was something Jones had in abundance. He was faster, quicker and, maybe not so surprisingly for those who have followed his career, more powerful than Ruiz, who was about 25 pounds heavier.
But there was a greater significance to this fight. This was a victory for a beleaguered sport. The two fighters are highly respected by their peers for their demeanor inside and outside the ring. Ruiz coaches youth football back home in Chelsea. Mass. Jones is respected as a great fighter, a hard worker and an outstanding businessman.
A similar story played out nearly 106 years ago in the Nevada mining town of Carson City, when the middleweight champion Robert Fitzsimmons moved up in class to defeat Jim Corbett for the heavyweight championship of the world.
The world seemed larger in 1897, more mysterious and scary than now, when we're connected by jets and the Internet. But this much is still true, about boxing and life: You can run, but you can't hide. Boxing can never run too far from its roots and we can never run too far from boxing. Last night's fight was larger than Jones or Ruiz; the sport had come full circle.
When Fitzsimmons took on Corbett, prizefighting was a wandering orphan, banned nearly everywhere. The sport found a home in Carson City. Why is this city so crucial to the history of a sport that occupies a puzzling -- often troubling -- place in our history?
On Friday, I followed the truth where it led, through mountains and valleys, along winding roads to northern Nevada. To Pratt and Musser Streets in Carson City, where Gentleman Jim and Ruby Bob fought a championship bout that lasted 14 rounds. The site is marked by a silver plaque set on a six-foot-high frame in the shape of Nevada and describes how in 1897 prizefighting, disdained in many other states, had recently been made legal in Nevada. 
This was where boxing went from being illegal to being a legitimate sport.
Why Nevada? Why did the State Legislature ignore an outcry from Carson City natives and vote to play host to the fight? Over lunch in Reno on Friday, Phillip Earl, curator emeritus of history at the Nevada Historical Society, gave a one-word answer: corruption.
Since the discovery of the Comstock Lode in 1859, Nevada's mining cycle has been a succession of booms and busts. The Corbett-Fitzsimmons fight was brought to Nevada during one of those downward fluctuations. The state needed something, anything, to pull itself out of a bad economic climate.
In 1897, the Nevada Legislature answered the acting Gov. Reinhold Sadler's request for additional revenue measures by passing a bill to license prizefights. The legislation called for a licensing fee of $1,000, with one-tenth going to the county where the fight was held and nine-tenths to the state's general fund. The fight was Nevada's first attempt to attract the tourist dollar. 
"Fights are illegal, but we could make it legal in Nevada, make some money," said Guy Rocha, archivist of the Nevada State Library and Archives in Carson City. "Nevada began looking at what the rest of the nation didn't do, and we decided we'd do it."
On March 17, 1897, 6,000 fans braved a cold, blustery day to watch the Corbett-Fitzsimmons fight. The attendance was twice the population of Carson City but far below what promoters had hoped.
Those who attended saw a classic match that ended early in the 14th round. Fitzsimmons floored the champion with a devastating combination: he dug a left hand deep in Corbett's stomach -- the infamous solar plexus punch -- and a left hook to Corbett's jaw. The champion tried to pull himself up, but slid back down and was counted out.
Prizefighting had proved its worth as a promotional scheme. Nevada, though not Carson City, was on its way to becoming the boxing capital of the world. Carson City never held another significant fight, but significant fights with national implications were staged in Goldsfield, Tonopah and Reno. The legacy continued here last night, with Jones's victory. 
When Fitzsimmons and Corbett met in 1897, boxing was emerging as a sport. Now, boxing is a $500 million-a-year business, with a mixed history of scandals, misbehavior and great performances.
But from Corbett and Fitzsimmons, Ruiz and Jones, one truth remains standing: you can run, but you can't hide.

HEADLINE: Looking for a Leader, Casting a Wide Net 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN WISE 

 BODY:
IT has been just over two years since Zdenek Macal announced that the 2001-02 season would be his last as music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. Officials with the orchestra say they are still not close to naming his successor, and the announcement of the 2003-04 season suggests that they are significantly widening their search.
 Sixteen guest conductors are slated to join the orchestra next season, four in return engagements. Because most orchestras undergo searches for new conductors by trying out candidates, any of these guests could be considered contenders. 
 Lawrence Tamburri, the orchestra's executive director, declined to comment on whether there have been any formal discussions with candidates. But he said this was an "artistic leadership search," which meant, he said, that the orchestra may structure the job differently than it has in the past.
For example, he said, the orchestra might hire one conductor as music director to focus on the artistic aspects of the job, and hire another in an associate role to handle more of the fund-raising and educational programs. This is a rare, but not unheard-of, practice; the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra has this sort of leadership structure.
"We're interested in being somewhat flexible," Mr. Tamburri said.
The returning guest conductors are Miguel Harth-Bedoya, from Peru; Marco Parisotto of Canada; the Austrian Carlos Kalmar, and an American, Lawrence Foster. Mr. Kalmar is not in the running for the job because he was just named music director of the Oregon Symphony in Portland. He joins the New Jersey orchestra this week for three concerts, beginning on Thursday. 
The newcomers include the Hungarian conductor Gilbert Vaga; an American, Jeffrey Kahane; a Russian, Yakov Kreizberg; two English conductors, Nicholas McGegan and Jane Glover; three Germans, Stefan Sanderling, Bernhard Klee and Cornelius Eberhardt; and the Estonian father-and-son pair of Neeme Jarvi and Kristjan Jarvi.
The orchestra, with over 70 players, is New Jersey's largest classical ensemble. It logged a $1.1 million deficit last year and is fighting one this season, the result of decreased ticket sales and fund-raising revenue in a sluggish economy.
But musicians and orchestra administrators generally consider it one of the best-managed and artistically robust orchestras in the United States. It enjoys a gleaming concert hall at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, and it has a distinct advantage over other similar-sized ensembles because of its proximity to New York and the musical talent the city has to offer.
The orchestra's cachet increased last month when it made an $18 million purchase of 30 rare 18th-century string instruments, including ones made by Stradivarius, Guarneri del Gesu and other famous artisans, for its members to play. The unusual acquisition, from the New Jersey philanthropist Herbert Axelrod, came after a year of negotiation. Mr. Tamburri believes it will be a powerful draw for potential candidates.
"The conductors all know about this," he said. "They all talk about it." 
Few of the guest conductors are American. Although many critics argue that American orchestras should make an effort to use native talent, Mr. Tamburri said that he did not agree, and that there was a deeper pool overseas.
"The real issue is in America we don't have a good training system for conductors," Mr. Tamburri said. "All over Europe, there are opportunities for people to really learn the craft of conducting. In the United States, we have the conservatories, workshops, and assistant conductors. That's not best for teaching people to be conductors." Mr. Tamburri added that hands-on training was best.
Mr. Tamburri dismissed the notion that European conductors govern more autocratically, while shirking aspects of the job like educational outreach and fund-raising.
"In America, conductors need to help fund-raising," he said. "European orchestras are funded through the government, which has its own set of issues. We want our conductors to be more public figures."
An authoritarian figure might not be a logical match for an orchestra known for encouraging its musicians to take a role in artistic and managerial matters.
Since Mr. Macal departed in 2001, except for periodic conducting stints as music director emeritus, the musicians have had a greater say in artistic matters. This is evident in the opening subscription concerts for next season, which feature three members of the orchestra as concerto soloists. And instead of hiring an artistic consultant as many orchestras do between music directors, the group has used a committee of three musicians and two staff members to shape its seasons.
Of the new guests scheduled for next season, two in particular might make interesting choices.
Ms. Glover has established her credentials largely in opera and early music and so would be an unconventional choice to lead a large, traditional symphony orchestra. At 29, the younger Mr. Jarvi is the youngest candidate, with the most unlikely background. He is conductor of the Absolute Ensemble in New York City, which is dedicated to contemporary music and to blurring the boundaries between classical, jazz and rock music. Most members of the group are in their 20's and 30's, and favor downtown black or leather trousers over tuxedos when dressing for a performance. 
But most of the focus next season will be on the returning conductors.
At age 34, Mr. Harth-Bedoya has earned degrees in conducting from the Juilliard School and the Curtis Institute of Music. Currently music director of the Fort Worth Symphony and associate conductor at the Los Angeles Philharmonic, he made a debut here in late January with an adventurous program of works by Prokofiev, Christopher Rouse and the New Jersey composer Robert Aldridge, which was well reviewed in local papers. 
He returns in September to conduct the orchestra's opening gala along with the first set of subscription concerts. Of all the candidates, Mr. Harth-Bedoya has been generating the most advance talk among managers of artists in the metropolitan area.
Mr. Parisotto is 39. Currently music director of the Oshawa-Durham Symphony in Canada and the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra, he gave intelligent, energetic performances, according to the local press, in his prior engagements here. His musical tastes also mesh nicely with the orchestra's strengths in Russian and German Romantic repertoire. Yet while he has appeared on podiums throughout Canada and Europe, he is still relatively unknown in the United States.
Mr. Foster, 66, is a frequent guest of the orchestra. He appears in March 2004 with a program of Haydn, Mozart and Elgar. His selection would at least nominally address complaints about the dearth of American conductors holding major posts in this country. But his resume includes posts at the Barcelona Symphony and Jerusalem Symphony Orchestras. 
The only other American guest conductor to appear next season is the West Coast-based Mr. Kahane, who is music director of the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra and is equally known as a concert pianist. He is a long shot at best because he is not that visible on the East Coast.
Mr. Tamburri said a decision should be made by spring of next year. In the meantime, audiences can look forward to performances led by widely different personalities.
