HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
The Masters of the French Masters Were Spanish

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
WITH the arrival of the star-studded "Manet/Velazquez," now open at the Metropolitan, we might pause briefly to notice what's going on around town. Half of the great museums in Europe and across the United States suddenly seem to have been emptied out and the art shipped to New York. Never mind the bad economy, declining foreign tourism and the high costs of insurance after 9/11. The big news is that the Met and the Modern have managed loan shows like "Matisse Picasso" and "Leonardo Da Vinci: Master Draftsman." And now this, which is at least as spectacular.
 I can't remember the last time the city's large art museums simultaneously had such extravagant loan exhibitions. The world is changing. This moment may pass. We shouldn't take it for granted. 
 I begin in gratitude partly because that is the natural first response to seeing so many works by Velazquez, the greatest painter who ever lived. I like Rubens's remark, which I'm sure is apocryphal. Rubens, who considered himself the leading painter alive, went to Madrid in the 1620's and met the young Velazquez, with whom he had corresponded. "Oh," he supposedly said after seeing Velazquez's art. "I didn't know about him." 
After Manet saw Velazquez, he said he didn't know why anyone even bothered to paint. Fortunately, he also said that the sight of Velazquez's paintings gave him "enormous hope and courage," which is what great artists do for other artists; and the Met exhibition auspiciously begins with Manet's portrait of Jean-Baptiste Faure, the opera singer, in the role of Hamlet, beside Velazquez's portrait of Pablo de Valladolid, the court jester, which inspired it.
I heard unpromising reports about this show when it was in Paris. The local organizers apparently stressed too many minor compatriots to illustrate the widespread influence of Velazquez, Murillo and other Spanish painters on 19th-century French art, which is the show's thesis, a truism of art history that hardly seemed necessary to prove, anyway.
The Met and its curator, Gary Tinterow, have clearly called in every chip to make this version better. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The level of painting is almost absurdly high throughout. Let me dispense with a few equivocations. The general theme is still not a novelty, and the scholastic excuse of tracking influence here casts Velazquez, Ribera, Zurbaran, El Greco and Goya awkwardly in the supporting role of precursors to modernism, sublime artists enrolled to buttress later talents, a skewed way to acknowledge their value, which should be self-evident.
Nor does the show, being academically diligent, avoid French second-raters who absorbed Spanish art, although they are given comparatively short shrift. All shows these days could be smaller. This one is no exception.
Finally, beautiful though the American art is, even apt at the Met, it belies the show's subtitle, "the French taste for Spanish painting," leading the exhibition down an exquisite byway, which feels slightly tacked on at the end.
Having said all that, the best art is so inspiring and Mr. Tinterow illustrates the show's main theme in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso," notwithstanding the coincidental title pairings), that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed.
The first room of Spanish paintings is, by itself, one of the finest displays of old master art the city has had in years: you grasp instantly why the works of Velazquez, Ribera and Zurbaran made such an impact on artists like Courbet and Manet, which, I suppose, is the argument for bringing the best possible Spanish art here.
The effect of this influence was to turn French art toward gritty realism. Ribera's club-footed "Beggar," the essence of coarse humanity, elevated by divine painting, is an obvious model.
More curious is that an artist like Zurbaran, whose austere and profound literalness made him seem anachronistic in his own time, would seem modern to French artists in the 19th century for those same qualities. His "Saint Casilda," with its flat pattern and deep space, the saint's delicate head tilted questioningly toward us, looks almost gothic.
But this quality is what made her seem strangely worldly to the French in the 1830's and later. That is how taste works sometimes.
Mr. Tinterow writes in the show's introductory wall text that 19th-century French artists, seeing Spanish art through a modern lens, progressively shifted from "idealism to realism, from Italy to Spain, from Renaissance to Baroque, from carefully finished porcelainlike surfaces to the sketch aesthetic of Impressionism."
So the exhibition tracks an arc of increasing French absorption, starting in the 18th century, when there were few Spanish pictures in France. Velazquez was hypothetically esteemed but nowhere visible. Zurbaran and El Greco were unknown. The only painting by Zurbaran in France was misattributed to Ribera. Diderot, in his "Encyclopedie," wrote about eight schools of European painting, none of which was Spanish.
Then Napoleon invaded Spain and Spanish art was shipped in bulk to France. Delacroix as a schoolboy saw the paintings in the Louvre. Much of the art had to be returned after Napoleon was ousted. But Marshal Jean de Dieu Soult, the commander of Napoleon's French army in Seville, having seized many paintings, took them back with him to Paris and kept them. His house became the de facto Galerie Espagnole in France until King Louis-Philippe sent Baron Isidore Taylor to Spain in the 1830's to acquire pictures for an official Galerie Espagnole at the Louvre. 
The collection Taylor put together included dozens of El Grecos, Murillos, Zurbarans and Goyas. Dovetailing with a vogue for all things Spanish, it made an immense impression on artists like Courbet. Manet, who visited the gallery as a teenager, never forgot it.
At the Met, the Spanish pictures all have pedigrees linked to this history: they were seized by Napoleon, owned by Soult, purchased by Taylor for the king or viewed, one way or another, by French artists later. Louis-Philippe was dethroned in 1848 and his collection returned to him, leaving the Louvre temporarily with only about a dozen Spanish paintings. But by then, provincial French museums and various private collectors in Paris, like the Comte de Pourtales-Gorgier and Lord Hertford, had amassed Spanish collections. 
French artists now also traveled abroad to see Spanish art. Manet went to Madrid in 1865, although he had already painted Spanish pictures like "Dead Toreador" and "Monk at Prayer," which at the Met is paired with its source, Zurbaran's "St. Francis in Meditation," from the inventory of Louis-Philippe's gallery.
Zurbaran's saint obviously fulfilled theatricalizing French fantasies at the time about dark, mystical Spain. This is not a picture of Francis cheerfully singing with the birds. It's a harsh, slightly terrifying image, the ecstatically upturned eyes of the saint shrouded in a massive habit whose rough fabric Zurbaran painstakingly describes, casting hard light on a skull Francis clutches to his breast. The saint's open mouth and the skull's eye sockets are black pools, light picking out the figure from darkness that then swallows it back up.
The influence on Manet was direct: with his monk, he painted the skull and dark cloak and isolated the figure kneeling against a bare brown backdrop. But the differences are instructive: there's the black outline, flattening form, stressing pigment as independent agent; the face, sculptured in paint, illuminated by spotlight, picks out vivid pink, yellow and green, a modern palette. 
The expression is also almost sour, the eyes shut or nearly so, as if the monk, struggling to concentrate, noticed out of the corner of his eye the skull on the floor to his side the way you might glimpse a rat scurrying along the wall.
Manet's figures, though isolated like Zurbaran's, are more specifically about the here and now. His "Philosopher (Beggar in a Cloak)," with one hand extended, striding forward, seems to step straight into our space. Colors vibrate: red beret, blue jacket and brown duffle coat. Pigment dissolves flesh into freestanding brushstrokes. The head, pasty and patchwork, is like an actor's: vivid, particular, stagy, somewhat exaggerated and of this moment. The affectation is rakish.
Carried a step further a work like this could become Sargent's "Dr. Pozzi at Home," which is all style, color and immediacy.
Immediacy is also a quality of Goya's art. It is visible in the miraculous little portrait of an artist, Asensio Julia, a picture of rushing air and rustling fabric, arrested by minute detail: the sheen on his silk stockings, the touch of red paint on a brush in a bowl at Asensio's feet. You see the same arrested movement in the frozen tension of a bull and bullfighter, facing off, blood pouring from the picador's gored horse, an image Manet imitated but with intensified light and color. 
Manet's inspiration for his "Beggar" was "Aesop," by Velazquez, which, like all profound art, defies complete explanation. You see the difference here between Manet's drama and Velazquez's truth. Compared to Velazquez, Manet admitted, other painters "seem completely like fakers."
Everything in the picture is perfectly measured, the weight of the baggy eyelids, of the hand resting in the cloak, of the body turned at the hip. The figure balances on a foot turned casually on its edge. 
Velazquez discreetly orchestrates our gaze by painting a big sweeping curve that stretches from the open collar of Aesop's cloak down and across his chest to the hip and to the book he supports with a crooked finger, whose visual purpose is to turn our eye back upward into the picture. The expression on the face is unforced, unsentimental, exact and detached but at the same time engaging.
It seems to reach across the ages. The writer Ortega y Gasset said Velazquez's work "isn't art; it is life perpetuated."
I think something Lucian Freud once observed about Rembrandt describes the same effect. "You feel you are privileged," he said, because the artist "is giving you an ennobling insight into the nature of people. I don't mean he has made the people seem virtuous, but I mean it is ennobling to be told something so truthful."
Great art is always about human nature. This show is full of truths about life.

"Manet/Velazquez: The French Taste for Spanish Painting" remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through June 8.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 11, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An art review in Weekend on Friday about "Manet/Velazquez" at the Metropolitan Museum misidentified the Manet painting paired with Velazquez's portrait "The Jester Pablo de Valladolid" at the beginning of the exhibition. It is "Tragic Actor (Rouviere as Hamlet)," not "Faure in the Role of Hamlet," which is also in the show.

HEADLINE: SPARE TIMES 

 BODY:
 EVENTS

"WORK OF RURAL WOMEN," United Nations, Public Lobby, First Avenue at 46th Street, Manhattan. Works by four photographers -- Christy Gavitt, Linda Lambert, Margaret Woodson Nea and Gayle Younghein -- in celebration of International Women's Day. Through April 11. Sponsored by World Neighbors, which sponsors programs dealing with health, conservation, sanitation and employment in Asia, Africa and Latin America. Hours: daily, 9:30 a.m. to 4:45 p.m. Information: (888) 242-6387; www.wn.org.

BROOKLYN PUBLIC LIBRARY, Lobby, Grand Army Plaza. "Regina Monfort: Beyond Grand Street, Brooklyn, N.Y.," a display of black and white photographs of the streets and residents of Williamsburg, through April 27. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., Alicia Erian, author of "The Brutal Language of Love," will read from her writing as part of the "Brooklyn Writers for Brooklyn Readers" series. Library hours: Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Information: (718) 230-2100.

HEADLINE: European Central Bank Cuts Rates a Quarter Point 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 6 

 BODY:
The European Central Bank trimmed interest rates by a quarter point today, disappointing those who had hoped for a more vigorous response to the Continent's lingering economic malaise.
 In reducing the benchmark rate to 2.5 percent -- its second cut in three months -- the bank said it was reacting to persistent signs of weakness in Europe's major countries and to the war clouds gathering over Iraq, which have driven the euro up sharply against the United States dollar. 
 The bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, left the door open for further cuts, saying the uncertainty over a war and how it might reverberate in Europe made it impossible to set longer-term monetary policy.
"The consequences of a war can go in many directions," Mr. Duisenberg said at a news conference in Frankfurt. "The governing council stands ready to act decisively and in a timely manner." 
The Bank of England, which cut rates last month, chose to hold firm today, at a rate of 3.75 percent. The bank's governor, Sir Eddie George, ruffled feathers here last month when he called on the European bank to pay more attention to economic growth in setting policy. 
The Swiss central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark rate today, by a half point.
Investors, anticipating a cut for weeks, had hoped the European Central Bank would take a bolder step. Stock markets tumbled in Frankfurt and Paris, while the euro resumed its upward march versus the dollar.
"The last time they cut rates, they said it was bigger than usual because of all the uncertainty," said Elisabeth Andreae, an economist with Commerzbank. "Given the uncertainty today, they should have done the same thing again. For Germany, a bigger cut would have been helpful."
Analysts said the bank's modest cut was a compromise between opposing camps on its 18-member governing council: one that favored doing nothing until the showdown between the United States and Iraq is resolved, and one that favored cutting rates more deeply.
"You saw a public debate among council members prior to this meeting; that hasn't happened very often in the four years that we've had the E.C.B.," said Allan Saunderson, the Frankfurt-based chairman of EuroZone Advisors, a consulting firm that follows the bank.
Mr. Duisenberg, who foreshadowed a rate cut last month, is thought to have favored a reduction of half a point. He declined to discuss his personal preferences or those of other council members. 
Such discretion grows out of the bank's desire, as a young institution, to build credibility in political and financial circles. But as Europe's big economies continue to drift, the bank's united front has begun to show cracks. Critics, inside and outside, are questioning its relentless focus on inflation at a time when the biggest danger, at least in Germany, is deflation. 
"Demand is dead in the water in France and Germany," Mr. Saunderson said. "It is crazy to believe inflation can be a risk anytime soon."
New statistics showed how deep the troubles run in Germany, Europe's No. 1 economy. Unemployment rose sharply in February, to 4.7 million people. The increase of 67,000 was greater than most estimates, and reflected more than the seasonal winter downturn.
German companies remain reluctant to invest, partly because of jitters over Iraq and partly because the government has not announced long-promised changes in the nation's hidebound economy. 
The weakness extends beyond Germany. The European Commission reported today that the 12 countries in the monetary union grew an average rate of 0.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002. Mr. Duisenberg said he expected growth of no more than 1 percent this year.
"The speed of the rise in unemployment is pretty breathtaking, both in Germany and France," Mr. Saunderson said.
Because the bank sets monetary policy for 12 countries, with divergent rates of economic growth and inflation, its rates cannot be tailored perfectly to every country. Many economists contend that they are too high for Germany, which has little growth and almost no inflation.
Germany accounts for a third of the economic output of the euro zone, while Germany and France together account for more than half. Some critics say the bank should relax its stance to stimulate these countries, even if it risks fueling inflation in the smaller, faster-growing countries.
Others, not surprisingly, disagree.
The finance minister of Greece, Nikos Christodoulakis, welcomed the decision, saying the new rate "better reflects the economic situation." 
"It balances the euro exchange rate and takes into account the geographical uncertainties, which have increased with the prospect of war."
In Greece, where inflation is running above 3 percent, some commercial banks said they probably would ignore the rate cut, leaving their lending fees higher to reap more profits from hungry borrowers.

HEADLINE: Australia Keeps Bypassing Pitfalls of Global Economy 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

 BODY:
Not for nothing is Australia called the lucky country.
 While other industrialized countries struggle to manage any sort of economic growth, Australia is in its 12th consecutive year of expansion. 
 Sluggish exports, the worst drought on record and the cooling of what was once a hot real estate market have undoubtedly slowed growth this year, but even with all that, economists predict that Australia's economy will expand by a respectable 3 percent in 2003.
Australia has gone longer without a recession than at any time in its history, and it has exceeded even the United States' longest recorded expansion, from 1991 to 2001. 
Who deserves the credit for this remarkable streak? Is it the work of deft fiscal and monetary management, or the clairvoyance of some antipodean Alan Greenspan?
"Pure luck," said Chew Ping, associate director of sovereign ratings at Standard & Poor's, which raised Australia's foreign currency credit rating last month to AAA, the same as the United States, for the first time since 1986.
Somehow, Australia has managed to sidestep the falling pianos of the global economy. It followed the United States into and out of recession in 1990 and 1991, but since then it has avoided the contagion of the Asian currency and financial crises, the technology bust and the pall thrown over the global economy by terrorism, and it has apparently defied the gravity of its own economic cycle. 
Australia's 19 million people now enjoy a higher disposable income than residents of Britain, Germany or Japan. Unemployment is 6.1 percent, almost a 20-year low.
Perpetual prosperity does not guarantee happiness even in Australia, and there is more than a little gloom about the immediate future. Its troops are poised to join the forces of the United States if there is a war in Iraq, and its citizens are worried about more terrorist attacks after the bombing in Bali last October that killed 88 Australians. Brushfires in the drought-sered countryside have burned acreage the size of Texas, claiming at least 5 lives and 530 homes.
Accordingly, the most-watched index of consumer sentiment fell in February to its lowest point in two years, lower even than it was immediately after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. 
"Australians read the papers," said Nigel Stapledon, chief economist at Westpac Bank in Sydney, which sponsors the index with the Melbourne Institute.
The mood is not sunny in Australia's stock market, either. After falling 12 percent last year, the S.&P. /ASX 200 index of blue-chip stocks is down about 7.7 percent so far this year, and has been plumbing lows unseen since 1999.
But economists say Australia's stock market is more reflective of conditions abroad than at home. The country's four biggest banks, whose overseas investments have taken a beating, account for 25 percent of the index; big mining companies, which earn most of their income abroad, account for another 10 percent. 
Consumers in other countries may know Australia best for its beer, dairy and wool products, but Australia's economy relies very little on exports. Of the 30 members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, only 3 are less export-dependent -- Greece, the United States and Japan. Agriculture looms large in the country's image but accounts for only about 3.5 percent of output, economists say.
As in the United States, domestic consumers are the main pillar of the economy, and Australians are still spending despite their recent pessimism. Retail sales grew 0.8 percent in the fourth quarter, seasonally adjusted. Corporate profits were up 21 percent in the third quarter, the most recent period for which figures are available, in contrast to the period in 2001.
The ripple effect from the stock market's problems, meanwhile, are less in Australia, because individual investors tended to put a smaller share of their assets in stocks than Americans did, even when the market was booming.
Australians buy real estate instead, and are facing the end of an 18-month boom, touched off when the government began giving first-time home buyers a $4,300 tax rebate as an election-year incentive. The rebate was phased out in July but the boom kept going, propelling housing prices up 17 percent in a year.
Now, though, just as housing demand is cooling, capital investment is increasing, economists say. "I think there'll be a big spike," Mr. Chew at Standard & Poor's said.
Most of the groundwork for this well-tempered economy, economists said, was laid in the 1980's and 1990's. Australia floated its currency in 1983, deregulated its financial system in 1984, sharply reduced import tariffs in 1988 and again in 1991, and scrapped a system of government-imposed wage controls in 1992. In 1996, the government gave the central bank independence to pursue an inflation target.
"This transition allowed a great deal of flexibility in adapting to the possibilities of cheap computing and cheap telecommunications," John Edwards, chief economist at HSBC Bank in Sydney, said.
As a result, productivity surged in the 1990's.
When a financial crisis scorched its trading partners in Southeast Asia in 1997 and 1998, Australia quickly found new markets in Britain, China and New Zealand. When the technology bubble burst in the United States, Australia was also spared: though it readily adopts technology, Australia has almost no technology industry of its own.
To be sure, there are factors to worry about. The recent weakness of the American dollar has spelled trouble for exporters like the mining companies whose goods trade worldwide in American dollars. But most of Australia's major trading partners have seen their currencies appreciate against the American dollar, so Australia has lost little of its competitiveness on that account.
Even the rapid run-up in energy prices, economists say, poses little risk to Australia's economy. Fuel prices are rising, but over all, Australia is a net energy exporter, rich in coal and natural gas, and may gain more than it loses from high prices.
In general, Australia has much to show for its luck. Last year, for the first time, Australians invested more in the United States than Americans invested in Australia. The government is talking about paying off the public debt. Best of all, meteorologists say rainfall is returning to normal, quenching the country's drought.
Which raises the question of why the world does not hear a lot more crowing from Down Under. "Endless self-congratulation doesn't suit our national personality," said Mr. Edwards at HSBC. Besides, he said, Australians know luck is a fickle thing: "I guess there's a fear that if we talk about it, it'll go away."

HEADLINE: Weak February for Retailers; The Weather Gets the Blame 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Snowstorms kept shoppers out of stores in February as Wal-Mart Stores posted sluggish sales and other retailers reported sharp declines or missed targets today.
 The months ahead do not look much better. Target and Sears, Roebuck forecast a lackluster March; a late Easter holiday, in April, could curb sales this month, and consumers worried about war and a sluggish economy are likely to defer big spending. 
 Wal-Mart, the No. 1 retailer, said sales at stores open at least a year rose 2.6 percent, close to the lower end of its original forecast, which called for a 2 percent to 4 percent increase.
Target, Sears, Limited Brands and J. C. Penney all posted lower sales for the month.
Goldman, Sachs said its retail composite index was unchanged in February. 
"The weather was a factor in February, as well as difficult comparisons, but right in the mix is the weakening consumer confidence," said Frank Badillo, a senior economist with Retail Forward. "It will play a factor into March and as long as uncertainty about the war lingers."
Gap Inc., parent of Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy stores, said sales rose 8 percent, below the company's expectations; it had previously said the spring shopping season was off to a slow start. Target, the second-largest discount chain behind Wal-Mart, said February sales slipped 1.4 percent; it expects March to be flat to negative, citing a later Easter.
Easter is April 20 this year, three weeks later than last year. That will probably mean that March sales will compare poorly with March 2002. 
The weakness in March sales could be recouped in April, however. "March results will likely be distorted because of the Easter shift," said Kevin Tawes, an analyst with Independence Investments. "We'll have to wait until April is over and add March's results to it to get a true sense of things."
Department stores, which have been struggling to compete with discounters, were hit particularly hard in February after Washington's Birthday weekend sales were quashed by bad weather.
Sales at department stores open at least a year were down 5.6 percent, Goldman, Sachs estimated.
The largest department store operator, Sears, said its February sales slid 9.4 percent. It forecast that sales would fall by an amount in the high-single-digit percentage range in March, its 19th consecutive month of declining sales.
Federated Department Stores, parent of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, said its February sales fell 6.8 percent, and J. C. Penney said its sales fell 2.1 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dow Tumbles After Release of Report on Jobless Claims

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Discouraging news on jobless claims sent stocks lower yesterday for the third day in four. The Dow Jones industrials lost more than 100 points, falling to a five-month low.
 "The economic news of the past several weeks paints the same picture -- the economy has moved off its bottom but it's still sluggish," said Russ Koesterich, United States equity strategist at the State Street Corporation in Boston. 
 "The market is looking for corporate revenue to increase," he said, "but there's no evidence of that occurring yet." 
Uneasiness about the situation with Iraq was again an underlying cause of the market's malaise.
The Dow fell 101.61 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 7,673.99. The loss more than erasedits 70-point gain from Wednesday. The Dow is at its lowest level since Oct. 10, when it closed at 7,533.95.
The broader market also finished lower. The Nasdaq composite index fell 11.51 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,302.89. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 7.75 points, or 0.9 percent, to 822.10.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that new claims for unemployment benefits rose last week by a seasonally adjusted 12,000, to 430,000, their highest level of the year. It was the third week that layoffs increased; analysts were expecting claims to decrease.
In a separate report, however, the department said productivity rose at a revised annual rate of 0.8 percent in the fourth quarter. That was a turnaround from the 0.2 percent rate of decline reported a month ago.
And a third report from the Commerce Department showed orders to factories rose 2.1 percent in January, the best showing in six months, and up from an increase of 0.3 percent in December.
The mixed economic news weighed on a hesitant market worried about growing tensions with Iraq and North Korea.
The United Nations remained divided yesterday over a proposed United States-backed resolution authorizing war against Iraq. Britain explored a compromise to amend the proposal and give the government of Saddam Hussein one final deadline to disarm, while President Bush scheduled a prime-time news conference yesterday to help prepare the nation for the prospect of war.
The Dow is now less than 400 points above its five-year closing low of 7,286.27, reached on Oct. 9.
Shares of retailers fell after several reported disappointing sales in February, citing war worries and the severe winter weather in the Northeast. Sears, Roebuck slid 70 cents, to $19.30, while Wal-Mart Stores fell 48 cents, to $47.40.
"There are a number of signs the U.S. consumer is becoming more selective, such as sluggish sales," said Subodh Kumar, chief investment strategist for CIBC World Markets. "At the same time, for the markets to focus on corporate recovery to drive investment, you need early resolution of the situation with Iraq."
Tyson Foods dropped 83 cents, to $7.70, after it lowered its second-quarter earnings outlook.
Raytheon lost $1.49, to $25.42, after it reaffirmed its 2003 financial outlook but said profits next year might fall as much as 11 percent, citing higher pension costs.
Gainers included Circuit City, which rose 5 cents, to $4.38, after it raised its fiscal fourth-quarter profit outlook.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers about 9 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was light.
Treasury bond prices retreated yesterday, breaking an eight-session streak of increases.
The benchmark 10-year note dropped 6/32, to a price of 101 27/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.65 percent from 3.63 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond dropped 14/32, to 110 16/32. Its yield climbed to 4.70 percent from 4.66 percent.

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Proposes a Measure to Restrain Tuition Increases 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Rattling universities nationwide, a Republican lawmaker responsible for shepherding higher education policy through the House has proposed penalizing those that raise tuition too quickly, possibly by denying them the aid that their students receive from the government and spend on college.
 The legislator is Representative Howard P. McKeon of California, chairman of the House subcommittee debating the reauthorization of the Higher Education Act, which covers student aid programs. He says he wants to curb what he calls "the unforgivable problem" of escalating college tuition. 
 "This is a frightening trend," Mr. McKeon said. "And no matter how you look at it, these phenomenal increases are hindering access to higher education." 
With state budgets squeezed, tuition increases at public universities this academic year, which generally outpaced those at private universities, often exceeded 10 percent, according to a study last month by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education. Public university tuition was up 19 percent in North Carolina, 20 percent in Iowa, Missouri and Texas. Massachusetts topped the list, at 24 percent.
To stem the tide, Mr. McKeon has called for colleges and universities to be required to submit detailed explanations to the federal government any time their tuition and fees increase twice as fast as inflation, whose current annual rate is about 2.6 percent. Along with the explanation would be a plan outlining how the college intended to hold down tuition in the future. 
But if tuition rose for another year at twice the rate of inflation, the government would impose sanctions, perhaps by going so far as to strip the entire campus of its eligibility for student aid programs, including loans, grants and work-study.
The proposal has brought an angry response from universities, many of which say the sanctions would only end up hurting the students whom Mr. McKeon seeks to protect.
"Does anyone really believe that taking away student loans, grants and work-study programs from college students and their families in the middle of their academic careers will make college more affordable or accessible for them?" said David L. Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities.
Educators also complain that the proposal would put the burden entirely on the colleges and students themselves instead of placing some on state legislatures, dozens of which cut higher education spending last year, prompting tuition increases at public universities.
"Rather than choosing to address the root cause of the revenue shortfalls that have forced many institutions to cut costs, scale back programs and raise tuitions," the American Council on Education said in a statement, "this bill will instead tell the American people that there is indeed such a thing as a 'free lunch.' "
In recognition that public universities sometimes have no choice but to raise tuition when state budgets are cut, Mr. McKeon's aides say the final bill will most likely leave wiggle room in certain cases, among other things allowing the Education Department discretion over what sanctions are appropriate, and when.

HEADLINE: War Jitters Hurting Some but Helping Others in Gulf Region 

BYLINE:  By GREG MYRE 

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 6 

 BODY:
With war clouds hovering over Iraq, regional economies are driving in two different directions. Egypt's much needed tourists are staying away in record numbers. In Turkey, Jordan and Syria -- none thriving economically -- cut-rate oil imports and special trade deals with Iraq are at risk of evaporating.
 For the producer nations in the Persian Gulf, by contrast, the same war jitters have helped push oil prices to more than $33 a barrel and could produce at least a temporary windfall. 
 The oil-hungry countries to Iraq's north and west -- Turkey, Syria, Jordan and Egypt -- should all expect some level of economic pain, said Ahmed Galal, executive director of the Egyptian Center for Economic Studies in Cairo.
The oil-rich countries to Iraq's south and east stand to be net beneficiaries, at least as long as the threat of war, or an actual conflict, keeps oil prices elevated, he added.
The poorer countries are already seeking increased assistance to compensate for the costs of war. 
In Egypt the government has forecast that even a brief war could lead to $6 billion or more in losses. In a country heavily dependent on tourism, visitors are already shying away.
"Tourism is a coward," said Mamdouh Salem, secretary general of the Egyptian Hotel Association. "It flees whenever something bad happens."
Tourism plunged after the Sept. 11 attacks but staged a strong comeback last summer. This boom-and-bust cycle has been recurring since the 1991 gulf war, which also scared visitors away for an extended period. Tourism crashed again after Islamic militants massacred 58 foreign tourists in Luxor in 1997.
Commercial shipping through the Suez Canal, another major source of Egyptian revenue, is also expected to decline. In addition, about two million Egyptians work abroad, mostly in the Persian Gulf, and a war could reduce that income.
Turkey, meanwhile,has been importing Iraqi oil at below market prices outside official United Nations channels for several years, with large tanker trucks daily crossing its border with northern Iraq.
But a war in Iraq would cost the Turkish economy an estimated $25 billion to $30 billion, said David Lubin, who follows emerging markets, including Turkey, for HSBC bank in London.
The figure is close to the aid package that the United States offered Turkey in exchange for allowing American forces to enter northern Iraq from Turkey. Turkey's Parliament narrowly rejected the proposal last week, though it may reconsider.
"The economic consequences for Turkey are serious," Mr. Lubin said. "If Turkey doesn't have an aid package, they could be facing big trouble."
Syria's trade with Iraq has flourished since the two countries reduced longstanding tensions two years ago.
Syria is selling consumer products to Iraq, which in turn funnels oil to Syria at sharply reduced prices. Neither side acknowledges the oil transfer, which takes place outside the United Nations monitoring system for Iraqi oil. It is believed to reach up to 200,000 barrels a day, according to oil industry sources.
But Syria's economy is vulnerable to any disruption in those ties. Syria, which is on the United States' list of countries that sponsors international terrorism, lacks a wealthy patron that could provide an economic safety net.
Iraq was desperate for lifelines to the world after sanctions were imposed after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait and offered sweetheart oil deals to its neighbors. But if the United States ousts Saddam Hussein international sanctions would almost certainly be lifted and a new Iraqi government would be free to sell oil openly.
In the gulf, Saudi Arabia has indicated it would be willing to use its spare capacity to put additional oil on the world market if needed in a crunch, a move that would boost its revenues. Also, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are not expected to face the huge cleanup bills that saddled their economies in the wake of the 1991 conflict.
"As long as oil prices are pushed up, they shouldn't be harmed at all," Mr. Lubin said. But oil price hikes may only be temporary, the analysts said. In the 1991 war oil prices that had been below $20 a barrel doubled during the fighting but quickly reverted to previous levels after Iraqi troops were driven out of Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders and Productivity Rise; Job Situation Is Glum 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6 

 BODY:
New orders to manufacturers rose 2.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly gain since mid-2002 on the strength of auto sales, the Commerce Department said today. Excluding transportation, orders gained 1.5 percent.
 A separate, revised report from the Labor Department today showed that the hourly output of workers outside agriculture rose 0.8 percent in the fourth quarter, a turnaround from the decline of 0.2 percent previously reported. The gain was bigger than economists expected and was taken as somewhat positive news. 
 "With productivity gains like these, it's not surprising that hiring was so weak," said Joel Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisers in Holland, Pa.
For the year, nonfarm productivity advanced 4.8 percent, the biggest annual gain since 1950, the Labor Department said.
Weakness in the labor marketlingered, worsened by severe winter weather, with the number of Americans signing up for new jobless aid reaching its highest level last week since December.
Initial jobless claims rose 12,000, to a seasonally adjusted 430,000 for the week ended March 1, the highest level since December, another Labor Department report said. Some of the increase resulted from claims from workers affected by Eastern snowstorms. The four-week moving average, seen as a better gauge of labor conditions because it irons out weekly fluctuations, rose to 408,750 from 400,000, and is also now the highest since December. Economists had expected the weekly figures to edge down.
The increase in claims "underscores the fragility of labor market conditions," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio, adding, "They certainly confirm the view that the economy is not creating, on balance, any new jobs at the moment."
Economists will look to tomorrow's monthly employment report for a clearer view of the job market. Employment growth outside farming is expected to be meager at best, with some economists foreseeing a decline.
Factory orders rose to a seasonally adjusted $327.11 billion in January, after a revised 0.3 percent gain in December. That was the biggest increase in orders since a 4.4 percent gain in July 2002.
Orders for durable goods, those intended to last at least three years, rose 2.9 percent in January, a smaller gain than the 3.3 percent increase reported in advance data on durable goods released last week.

HEADLINE: China Unveils Another Plan to Cut Bureaucratic Red Tape 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 6 

 BODY:
China unveiled today its third plan in the past decade to streamline its huge government bureaucracy, aiming to reduce corruption and eliminate overlapping responsibilities that contribute to waste in its economy.
 The plan, if accepted during the current session of the National People's Congress, would create independent American-style regulatory bodies to oversee banking, state-owned assets, food and drugs. 
 Unlike some previous proposals designed mainly to reduce the cost of government and cut red tape, the current proposal would redirect responsibilities for managing state-owned companies, the banking system and trade, officials said. 
One significant outcome of the plan could be to strip state companies and the ministries that support them from developing and carrying out economic policy. It would vest the state ownership of company assets in a new, consolidated agency that would try to maximize the state's financial interests but have no direct role in making policy.
Another potentially significant change would be to remove from China's central bank the responsibility of regulating state-owned banks. That would leave the central bank to set monetary policy, like the United States Federal Reserve Board, and theoretically force banks to begin cleaning up their bad loans.
Under the plan, China would also create a single body to regulate both domestic and international trade, a recognition that China's economy has become increasingly integrated with the outside world.
Previous efforts to make China's bureaucracy more efficient have had mixed results. Proposals can take years to carry out and are often watered down by competing factions.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
City's Housing Market Is Strong, Study Finds

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Despite the contractions in the New York City region's economy, the housing market in and around the city has remained strong over the last two years, according to a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
 The study, "New York City's Economy Before and After Sept. 11," found that both builders and buyers in the metropolitan area remained ready to put their money into the brick-and-mortar certainty of housing, surpassing even the continuing firmness of the national real estate market. 
 "The fact that all of this strength occurred during a period of a cyclical downturn and in the aftermath of the terrorist attack signals that people are basically willing to make a long-term investment in and around New York City," said Jason Bram, a regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who wrote the report.
The report particularly focused on permits for the construction of new housing units and on increasing home-sale prices. 
"If you look at the 2001-2002 period, which corresponds to when the economy peaked and has since turned down -- basically contracting for the last two years -- what I found most stunning is that more housing units have been authorized in New York City than in any two-year period since the early 1970's," Mr. Bram said. "And don't forget, also in the middle of that period, you have the terrorist attack."
The city issued 18,497 permits for single-family homes and apartments in 2002, surpassing the 16,856 permits issued in 2001, the report found. The total of 35,353 permits for the two-year period, Mr. Bram said, was the highest two-year total since 1973-74, when a total of 38,160 were issued (22,417 in 1973 and 15,743 in 1974). "The only single year that's exceeded the 2002 figure in recent history was 1985," he said, "when you had 20,332 permits." 
Across the nation, the increase in housing permits issued over the last two years was the greatest recorded since 1985-86, the study said. There was a 2.5 percent increase in 2001 over the previous year, followed by a 4.8 percent rise in 2002 over 2001. In the city, by comparison, permits rose by 12 percent in 2001 and 9.7 percent last year.
The report also examined the appreciation of house prices in the New York area and nationally, using statistics gathered by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight. The federal figures were based on mortgages purchased for packaging as pools of securities and resale by the federally chartered corporations Fannie Mae and Freddy Mac, which have a loan ceiling of $300,700. 
"These data likely wouldn't pick up too many transactions involving high-end mansions, because most of those wouldn't conform to the Fannie Mae-Freddie Mac loan limits," Mr. Bram said. And while they also do not include co-op and condominium transactions, they still offer an indication of market trends.
Comparing the fourth quarter of 2001 to the fourth quarter of 2002, the report found that the average price for single-family homes rose by 11.2 percent in the five boroughs, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties combined. For all of New York State, the average price increase between the fourth quarters of 2001 and 2002 was 10.6 percent; for New Jersey, it was 11.8 percent; for Connecticut, it was 9.4 percent. Nationally, the increase was 6.9 percent.
As an indicator of housing prices in Manhattan, the study used data from the Insignia Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report, prepared by the Miller Samuel appraisal company. According to that report, the average sale price for co-ops in Manhattan, from the Battery to West 116th Street and East 96th Street, rose 0.3 percent from the fourth quarter of 2001 to the fourth quarter of 2002. For condominiums, the calculation was based on price per square foot, with the average price rising by 6.1 percent.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, attributed the strength of the real estate market to "a unique downturn in the post-World War II era for the region and the country."
"The historical pattern was that recessions were driven by rising interest rates, massive slowdowns in housing activity and consumer-spending reductions," Dr. Hughes said. "This time around, it is housing and consumer spending that have kept the economy afloat."
An important factor has been the 12 interest rate reductions imposed by the Federal Reserve over the last two years, with mortgage rates currently standing at 40-year lows, he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Housing Permits Rise"More housing permits for New York City were issued in 2002 than in any year since 1985. Graph shows permits since 1975. (Source: Census Bureau)

HEADLINE: A Dead End for Afghan Children Adrift in Pakistan 

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan 

 BODY:
Just off a side street near one of this city's wealthiest neighborhoods is a small, well-hidden compound surrounded by an eight-foot metal fence. Inside it are mountains of trash, a handful of embittered Afghan men and a dozen young Afghan boys with dirt-caked faces, hands and clothes.
 The boys, refugees who have been abandoned or forced by their parents to work, live in the compound, collecting and sorting garbage the men sell to recycling companies. On a given day, they sift through rotting vegetables, broken glass and syringes. One boy shows symptoms of typhoid and malaria. Another has a gash on the sole of his bare foot. The stench of curdled milk, rancid meat and unwashed bodies is choking. 
 "I've collected trash all my life," said Shaheen Syed Rabbani, a short boy with thick brown hair who gave his age as 14 but looked younger. He wore gaudy but worthless jewelry -- a ring, bracelet and necklace -- that he had found in the dump. His best friend, Muhammad Khazefi, 12, resembled a walking corpse. His cheeks, neck and lips were covered in scabs and his skin was purple, the color of the ink he found in the trash and smeared over his face.
The boys are among tens of thousands, possibly hundreds of thousands, of child laborers, often refugees from Afghanistan, who toil in garbage dumps, textile factories and food markets across Pakistan. For many of them there is only one way out: madrasas, or Islamic religious schools.
Over the years, madrasas have taken in many of the children at this garbage dump -- perhaps several hundred, according to one of the adult workers -- with promises of free food, clothing, education and, most of all, escape. While the specific number may be open to debate, there is no disputing that this dump, and thousands of other squalid workplaces, are prime recruiting areas for schools that the United States has described as potential breeding grounds for Islamic militancy.
Today, an estimated 10,000 madrasas with 1 million to 1.7 million students are believed to exist across Pakistan. Roughly 40 percent of the madrasas are operated by moderate sects and act as legitimate religious charities, according to estimates by Pakistani journalists. But most of the rest, a majority of the madrasas in Pakistan, are operated by the hard-line Deobandi sect. Deobandi madrasas, the birthplace of the Taliban, often represent a different, more radical world.
At the dump, the children ward off wild dogs as they scavenge for trash and sleep on wooden platforms so rats will not bite them.
They are vague about their situations. Shaheen, for one, insists he spends a day with his family every two to three weeks. But Muhammad says they moved here together seven or eight months ago. The two boys were exuberant in describing why they want to be taken in by a madrasa. 
"We'll get free food and clothing," Shaheen explained, his eyes brightening at the prospect. "It will make us very happy." Asked about the United States, he said: "I want America to be finished. They destroyed Afghanistan. They bombed the whole country."
Pakistani officials say they are doing their best to regulate madrasas and curb the poverty that makes them so attractive. But they say they need more economic aid from the United States and other Western countries.
Half of Pakistan's 140 million people are illiterate and live below the poverty line. The country's public school system is in a shambles. Hundreds of thousands of impoverished Afghan refugees remain in Pakistan, and for many of the refugee children, madrasas are their only chance for any type of education.
Eight Afghan refugee children, including one boy who lives in the garbage dump, are the subject of a New York Times Television report titled "Terror's Children: A Pakistani Journal." The documentary, by Pakistani filmmakers Sharmeen Obaid and Muhammad Naqvi, will be shown on the DiscoveryTimes Channel on March 25.
In the garbage dump, the boys wash in a puddle next to a cracked street pipe, defecate in empty lots and are beaten if they fail to produce enough recyclables.
Other Afghan children who live in refugee camps with their families also face abuse. "A good Muslim is one who does not beat their son," said Noor Muhammad, a 12-year-old whose father forces him to work from dawn until 8:00 p.m. "And prays five times a day."
Over the last 20 years, madrasas have grown to become a de facto social safety net and powerful Islamist presence. The schools were indirectly financed by the United States during the anti-Soviet war in Afghanistan in the 1980's, and the Pakistani government condoned their growth throughout the 1990's.
Abdul Quyum, a small affable 20-year-old Afghan with a short beard and boyish face, is head teacher of a Deobandi madrasa in the Jadeed refugee camp outside of Karachi.
The madrasa's founder left the school last spring after word spread that he was wanted by Pakistani police and the F.B.I. Mr. Quyum is filling in for him. Like so many Afghan boys, he fled the fighting with the Soviets and attended a Deobandi madrasa in Pakistan. Today, he teaches students what he learned.
The young teacher, like many Deobandi students, only memorized the Koran in Arabic, a language he does not speak or understand. In an interview, he said Islam bars Muslims from living with non-Muslims. "I can't eat with you," he said, "because you are a nonbeliever."
When other Muslims told him he was wrong, that the prophet Muhammad had laid out specific rules that allow Muslims to live with nonbelievers, he said he had never heard of such a thing. Asked about a well-known story in which Muhammad refused to use violence to win converts, he said he had never heard of that either.
At the madrasa, his students reacted with a combination of fear, curiosity and fury when greeted by an American, for many the first they had ever seen.
Abdullah, a 22-year-old student who was training to be an imam, or priest, hesitated when asked if he had any message for Americans. "If I were the ruler of the world," he said, clearly hoping to impress fellow students. "I would kill them all."
At the dump, Muhammad said he would happily study in a madrasa. Asked if he would accept training to kill Americans, he nodded.
"They are very cruel to us," the 12-year-old said resolutely. "They kill our people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Afghan refugee children work in garbage dumps and find their only escape in the Islamic religious schools. (Shamyl Khuhro for The New York Times) Map of Pakistan highlighting Karachi: For countless refugee children in Karachi, a madrasa offers escape.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Interpublic reports weak results and lowers revenue and earnings forecasts for this year.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE dismal financial outlook for the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York shows few signs of improvement based on its fourth-quarter and full-year results, which were released yesterday.
 The bad news included sharply lower profitability at its largest division, larger-than-expected declines in net income, falling revenue, more problems at a struggling motor sports unit and two additional restatements totaling $165.7 million in addition to previously disclosed restatements of $181.3 million. 
 "The results were terrible," said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst who follows advertising stocks for West End Communications/Consulting in New York.
Even worse than the additional restatements -- after Interpublic had assured investors, analysts and employees in November that the figure of $181.3 million would be final -- top executives warned of possible additional write-downs in the current quarter along with further layoffs, and they lowered their forecasts for revenue and net income per share for 2003. 
"You think it can't get worse, and it does," said David Doft, an analyst who follows Madison Avenue for CIBC World Markets in New York.
The results, among the bleakest for a major agency company since the recession a decade ago, meant a fast end to the honeymoon -- what there was of it -- for David Bell, who completes his first week as chairman and chief executive of Interpublic today .
"These results are unacceptable," Mr. Bell said during an hourlong conference call with analysts after the results were released. "There's clearly much to be done."
The new restatements approach in size those that tremendously angered investors and analysts last year, helping drive the price of Interpublic shares to 10-year lows.
In after-hours trading, shares of Interpublic fell as much as 6.7 percent. Earlier, they closed at $8.59, down 41 cents, or 4.6 percent.
For the fourth quarter, Interpublic -- which owns agencies like Campbell Mithun; Draft Worldwide; Foote, Cone & Belding; Golin/Harris International; and Mullen -- had net income of $20.3 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with restated net income of $96.4 million, or 26 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
The average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was for net income of 18 cents a share.
For 2002, net income was $99.5 million, or 26 cents a share, in contrast to a restated net loss of $534.5 million, or $1.45 a share, in 2001.
Revenue for the fourth quarter was $1.67 billion, down 3.8 percent from $1.73 billion. Revenue for the full year was $6.2 billion, down 8.7 percent from $6.79 billion.
The restatements announced yesterday are being made in two parts. The largest is composed of pretax charges of $135.8 million, primarily noncash, mostly in the third quarter, related to asset impairments and other operating expenses at the Octagon Motor Sports division of Octagon Worldwide. That division had earlier been identified as a prime culprit for the subpar recent performance of Interpublic. The motor sports division, which operates car-racing tracks in cities like Hong Kong, is being scrutinized and may be sold or shut down.
"Wehave engaged an independent consultant to advise us on exit strategies," said Sean F. Orr, executive vice president and chief financial officer. "We could have further write-offs in this business as we exit the business, depending on the exit strategy we choose to employ."
The other part of the restatements involves miscellaneous pretax charges of $29.9 million, which date to 1997 and were unrelated to Octagon Motor Sports.
The dire nature of the results underscored what analysts on Wall Street said on Feb. 27, when Interpublic's board unexpectedly shook up top management: that the catalyst for the sudden changes was a worsening of the financial woes of Interpublic, the world's second-largest agency company, particularly at the McCann-Erickson World Group, the largest division. 
Mr. Bell, the Interpublic vice chairman, was named to succeed John J. Dooner Jr., the chairman and chief executive since January 2001. Mr. Dooner was demoted and dispatched back to lead McCann-Erickson, succeeding James R. Heekin III, who was fired.
Mr. Doft, the analyst at CIBC, said of Mr. Bell, "The question is, Can he fix it and how long will it take?"
"His focus points are the right ones," Mr. Doft said, "but at this point investors are unlikely to give him the benefit of the doubt."
The sour results are the most recent in a spate of problems at Interpublic, which works for marketers like Coca-Cola, General Motors, Samsung and Unilever.
Interpublic has already endured difficulties that include a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of accounting irregularities; two restatements of earnings dating to 1996; a suspension of the dividend; repeated misses of earnings estimates; and several downgradings of corporate debt, to one level above junk status.
Earlier, revenue estimates for 2003 were flat compared with 2002, but now, Mr. Orr said, revenue will most likely decline 1 percent to 4 percent this year.
As for net income, Mr. Orr said, earnings per share are now estimated in a range of 68 to 72 cents. That compares with a current consensus estimate of 91 cents, according to First Call.
The profitability problems at McCann-Erickson, according to Mr. Bell, are centered on services outside traditional advertising like corporate identity consulting and promotional marketing along with advertising agencies in Latin America and Japan.
During the call, he described McCann-Erickson as "now in the capable hands of the rightful person, John Dooner."
Mr. Doft said that it had been apparent "there were issues at McCann, but the extent is kind of surprising."
"McCann is the crown jewel of Interpublic," he added. "As goes McCann, so goes Interpublic."
Among the handful of what Mr. Bell called bright spots for Interpublic were a reduction of debt at year-end, to $2.6 billion from $2.9 billion; strong net new-business performance in 2002, totaling $3.2 billion in billings from advertisers like Bank of America, Novartis and Qwest Communications; and continued progress on talks to sell the NFO WorldGroup, a research unit.
The Interpublic difficulties began in August, when the agency company initially disclosed that accounting problems at the European operations of McCann-Erickson would result in a charge to earnings of $68.5 million. That was revised upward to as much as $120 million in October and again a month later to $181.3 million. 
In contrast to the downbeat results from Interpublic, some of its rivals have reported numbers that pleased Wall Street. 
Havas in Paris, the fifth-largest agency company, which coincidentally also reported yesterday, had net income of $26.3 million in 2002, in contrast to a large loss in 2001. 
The WPP Group in London, the world's biggest agency company, reported last week that its net income last year fell 67.6 percent, to $132.3 million, from $390.6 million in 2001.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
European Central Bank Cuts Rates by a Quarter Point
The European Central Bank lowered interest rates by a quarter point, disappointing those who had hoped for a more vigorous response to the Continent's lingering economic malaise.
 In reducing the benchmark rate to 2.5 percent -- its second cut in three months -- the bank said it was reacting to persistent signs of weakness in Europe's major countries and to the war clouds gathering over Iraq, which have driven the euro up sharply against the dollar. World Business, Section W. 

McKinsey Partners Pick a Leader
McKinsey & Company announced that its partners had chosen a new leader. Ian Davis, the head of the firm's British office, will take over as managing director in July. During his three-year term, Mr. Davis will have to guide the firm as it copes with continuing economic uncertainty and clients' reluctance to spend on costly consultants. C2.

AOL in Talks to Sell Maker of Discs
AOL Time Warner is in talks about selling the CD and DVD manufacturing business of its Warner Music division, executives briefed on the talks said. C5.

U.S. and Europe in Energy Pact
The Energy Department and the European Union agreed to start a cooperative effort aimed at bringing hydrogen-powered cars and electricity generated from fuel cells to market over the next two decades. C2.

Interpublic Falls Short in Quarter
The Interpublic Group came in well short of analysts' expectations in the fourth quarter and warned of more trouble in the current quarter. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.

A Men's Version of Lucky Magazine
Conde Nast Publications has given the green light to a men's version of Lucky, its shopping magazine for women. C5.

McCaw Yielding Control of Nextel
Craig O. McCaw, the billionaire communications entrepreneur, is surrendering control of Nextel Communications. C4.

Intel Issues Warning on Sales
Intel warned that first-quarter sales would fall short of its highest forecast as demand declines for flash-memory chips. Its shares dropped on the news. C4.

Tyco Will Remain Based in Bermuda
Shareholders of Tyco International defeated a motion calling on the conglomerate to move its incorporation back to the United States from Bermuda. Shareholders did vote to replace the company's entire board, to retain its accountant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, and to require that future severance agreements for executives be approved by a shareholder vote. C4.

Stricter Rules for Modified Crops
In an effort to prevent contamination of the food supply, the Agriculture Department announced stricter rules for crops that are genetically modified to produce pharmaceuticals or industrial chemicals. The regulations were criticized as inadequate by opponents of biotechnology and the food industry. A23.

Jobs Report Drags Stocks Down
An increase in jobless claims sent stocks lower. The Dow fell 101.61 points, or 1.3 percent, to 7,673.99. The Nasdaq composite index fell 11.51 points, or 8.8 percent, to 1,302.89. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 7.75 points, or 0.9 percent, to 822.10. C7.

HEADLINE: NASA Official Says Agency Faces a Drain on Its Talent Pool 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6 

 BODY:
NASA's top official warned today that the agency faced alarming trends in retirements, competition from industry and a decline in graduates with technical skills, all of which could severely deplete the pool of skilled employees.
 Appearing before a Senate governmental affairs subcommittee, the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, told lawmakers, "NASA's ability to maintain a world-class work force with the talent it needs to perform cutting-edge work is threatened." 
 Lawmakers are debating legislation that includes many of the work-force changes that NASA seeks to make its pay and benefits more competitive with industry. 
Some provisions would allow NASA to offer certain employees bonuses and salaries far higher usually allowed under government rules. In some cases, the legislation would allow one-time bonuses of up to twice an employee's salary, if that worker agreed to spend four years at NASA and the job filled a "critical need." 
At the hearing, lawmakers questioned Mr. O'Keefe about whether NASA has what it needs to oversee its huge contractor network. The agency appears to have the employees to do the job, Mr. O'Keefe said. But he added that "what scares me is that once they move on, there ain't a whole lot there behind them." 
"Our bench strength is not as deep as it could be," he said. Later, he said he did not believe that work-force problems contributed to the Columbia disaster. 
Critics of the legislation said the brain drain had been mostly caused by NASA's efforts in the last 10 years to send work to outside contractors. Much of the most innovative technology work that would attract the brightest graduates now occurs at private companies, the critics said.
Jackie Simon, director of public policy at the American Federation of Government Employees, the union for many NASA workers, said the agency should focus on rebuilding its ranks of in-house scientific and engineering employees and ending the practice of "sending all the good work out."
The bill, Ms. Simon added, leaves little for career employees. 
Congressional backers of the legislation take issue with the criticisms. Supporters of the measure have made it clear to NASA officials that the higher salaries and bonuses are primarily meant to benefit rank-and-file engineers and employees whose technical skills are in high demand in the private sector.
The bill's sponsor, Representative Sherwood Boehlert, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House Science Committee, said his legislation rejected some provisions that NASA wants. They included an "exchange program" in which industry employees would be NASA staff members while remaining on the payrolls of their corporate employers, an idea that Mr. Boehlert said raised conflict-of-interest concerns.

HEADLINE: British Manager Is Chosen To Lead Consulting Firm 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
After a selection process that many likened to the election of a new pope, McKinsey & Company announced yesterday that its partners had chosen a new leader. Ian Davis, the head of the firm's British office, will take over as managing director in July. 
 During his three-year term, Mr. Davis will guide the firm as it copes with continuing economic uncertainty and clients' reluctance to spend on costly consultants. McKinsey consultants will face increasing pressure on two fronts: from I.B.M., Accenture and other companies that have large consulting businesses with deep pockets and technological expertise, and from more traditional rivals like Bain & Company, the Boston Consulting Group and Booz Allen Hamilton. 
 How the firm responds will be closely scrutinized by its competitors and clients, many of whom say they regard McKinsey -- the training ground for prominent chief executives like Philip Purcell of Morgan Stanley and Leo Mullin of Delta Air Lines -- as a model and bellwether.
"The industry is at this point of departure, and I think McKinsey, as the leader of the industry, is at a point of departure as well," said Tom Rodenhauser, president of Consulting Information Services in Keene, N.H. "There's a lot of turmoil internally as to where McKinsey is headed."
The selection of Mr. Davis to succeed Rajat Gupta, who served as McKinsey's managing director for three three-year terms, may portend a shift in the firm's strategy. In the 1990's, Mr. Gupta oversaw a rapid expansion in the size of the firm and the reach of its offices. Some partners have worried that it may have grown too rapidly for its traditional partnership structure. Several people at the firm noted that Mr. Davis emphasized McKinsey traditions in a statement yesterday.
"To build on Rajat's accomplishments, we need to stay focused on our core mission and values, which have nourished McKinsey's success over the last seven decades," Mr. Davis said in the statement. "Our commitment to our clients and our people are at the heart of everything we do."
Consultants' credibility in general has been undermined by corporate scandals at companies they advised and by the bursting of the technology bubble. McKinsey's association with Enron, a much-celebrated client before its spectacular collapse in December 2001, "cast a little bit of doubt" on the firm, Mr. Rodenhauser said.
Corporate spending on consulting services has slowed sharply in recent years, rising barely 3 percent, to $126.6 billion in 2001, from $122.9 billion the previous year, according to Kennedy Information, which tracks the industry. McKinsey, which is privately held, had $3.3 billion in revenue last year and the same amount in 2001, Kennedy estimates, down slightly from $3.4 billion in 2000. 
As a result of tougher economic times, McKinsey has become much more selective in its hiring. It is still a highly desirable destination for business school graduates. It has also become more aggressive about advising associates to leave the firm -- a process known as "counseling out" -- in an effort to slow growth or, in some offices, to shrink, associates at the firm say. Over all, the firm employs about 7,000 consultants, down from 7,200 a year ago. 
Some McKinsey associates expressed relief that Mr. Davis was chosen because his fellow finalist in the selection process, Michael Patsalos-Fox, head of the New York office, was seen as being focused on controlling costs and aggressive about advising junior consultants to leave. 
Mr. Davis, 52, has worked at McKinsey in Britain for 23 years and has run the British office for eight years. Before joining the firm, Mr. Davis worked for seven years at Bowater, a paper products manufacturer. He is a graduate of Oxford University.
The consulting industry has been changing in recent years as large technology companies, like I.B.M., Hitachi and Fujitsu, have built up their consulting units. In turn McKinsey, like other more traditional consulting firms, has come to emphasize technology, said Jack Sweeney, an editor at Kennedy Information. 
But McKinsey is structured as a partnership rather than as a corporation with clear lines of communication, Mr. Sweeney said, and it will have to focus on how to share information effectively throughout the organization. "They need to look at the processes and update them," he said.
The increasing importance of technology may pose a problem for the firm because as the consulting industry is further divided into segments, distinguishing information technology from management consulting, for example, McKinsey will be relegated to a smaller slice, Mr. Rodenhauser said. "McKinsey becomes marginalized," he said. "They've represented the industry for a long time now, and the future of the industry is going to be something where they don't represent the industry."
If McKinsey cannot distinguish itself, it will be unable to charge its customary premium above competitors' rates, Mr. Rodenhauser said. "Maybe McKinsey will not be the consultant as we think of consultants in the future," he said. "Instead, McKinsey may be a high-level adviser, and that's all they'll do. But they'll have to be much smaller." 
Because the election process at McKinsey is elaborate and opaque, there is no way to determine the reasons partners chose Mr. Davis over Mr. Patsalos-Fox. According to a McKinsey spokesman, Michael Stewart, the selection process often takes many months because not all of the firm's 270 eligible senior partners vote in time to meet deadlines set for each round of voting. This year, Mr. Stewart said, partners voted on time, so the process took less than two months.

HEADLINE: A Welfare-to-Work Study Finds No Harm to Children 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6 

 BODY:
Poor children suffer no psychological damage when their mothers move from welfare to work, as millions of women have in recent years, a major new study says. Among adolescents in such families, the researchers say, mental health may actually have improved.
 The research, financed by the National Institutes of Health and being published on Friday in the journal Science, provides the most extensive evidence yet to answer questions that have been swirling around one of the biggest experiments in American social policy in the last half-century. The study suggests that the 1996 welfare overhaul does not pose the harm many people feared when it was passed by a Republican-controlled Congress and signed into law by President Bill Clinton. 
 The law established strict work requirements for welfare recipients, with tough penalties for those who flouted the rules, and set a five-year lifetime limit on payment of federal welfare benefits to any family. The law's critics predicted that it would increase poverty and misery among children. Its supporters said growing up on welfare harmed children, by fostering dependency and sapping initiative.
Bills reauthorizing the welfare program, passed by the House and pending in the Senate, would increase the work requirements, and the newly reported study could give ammunition to supporters of those more stringent provisions.
The researchers studied preschoolers and adolescents in 2,400 families in Boston, Chicago and San Antonio. They found that the mothers' transition from welfare to work did not harm the emotional development, intellectual achievement or mental health of the children.
"This study provides reassurance that mothers may leave welfare and enter the job market without harmful effects to their preschoolers or young adolescents," said Dr. Duane Alexander, director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, a unit of the N.I.H.
The researchers said adolescents whose mothers had begun working reported small but "statistically significant declines in psychological distress," including symptoms of anxiety. Some adolescents also reported significant declines in delinquent behavior like the use of drugs and alcohol after their mothers left welfare.
The researchers said they had detected neither harmful nor beneficial effects on preschool children when their mothers went from welfare to work.
"The positive and negative aspects of going off welfare or getting a job may cancel each other out" in these families, said P. Lindsay Chase-Lansdale, a professor of psychology at Northwestern University, who directed the study.
When mothers of preschoolers went to work, the study found, family incomes increased, but the mothers' time with the children, 2 to 4 years old, decreased. "These two effects may have offset each other," the report said.
The researchers found a different experience among adolescents. Family income increased when their mothers went to work, but the women did not substantially reduce the time spent with the children, ages 10 to 14.
Women in the study kept diaries showing how they spent their time. When mothers of adolescents left welfare and took jobs, they cut back on their own personal, social and educational activities, so there was only a small net reduction in the hours they spent with their children.
Dr. Chase-Lansdale said the changes in the lives of the families in the study had occurred in a booming economy. In a weak economy, she said, it might have been more difficult for women to leave welfare and find jobs, and the jobs might have paid less.
One of the more remarkable findings is that when mothers went to work, their household income nearly doubled, and most of the families were lifted out of poverty. Before they went to work, their average income was 35 percent below the poverty level. After they took jobs, their income was more than 25 percent above the poverty level.
"For a family of four, that represents an increase of $10,000 a year," Dr. Chase-Lansdale said.
The researchers offered several explanations for the findings concerning the children's well-being. 
"The self-esteem of mothers of adolescents often significantly increased when those mothers went to work and often significantly decreased when they left work," the study said. Adolescents seemed to thrive when their parents had a positive self-image.
Moreover, the authors said, "adolescents are perceptive and sensitive to the pressures of poverty and economic hardship in their families," so their "anxiety levels may decrease as they see their mothers going to work each day."
Conversely, the researchers said, when mothers leave the labor force, adolescent children are more likely to display behavioral problems. "Teenagers may express their feelings of disappointment or worry about finances as depression or anger when their mothers leave employment," the study said.
The 1996 law ended a 60-year-old federal guarantee of cash assistance for the nation's poorest children and gave each state a lump sum of money, with vast discretion to run its own welfare program. The number of people on welfare plunged to five million in September 2002 from 12.2 million in 1996.
The new study does not predict whether gains from the 1996 law will endure. The researchers said they hoped to follow children in the study for 15 to 20 years.
