HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Intel Revises Sales Outlook; Demand Eases For Its Chips

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., March 6 

 BODY:
Intel warned today that first-quarter sales would fall short of its highest forecast as demand declines for flash-memory chips. The company's shares dropped on the news.
 Revenue will be $6.6 billion to $6.8 billion, the company said. In January, Intel predicted $6.5 billion to $7 billion, and analysts had expected Intel to keep the high end of its range in place. 
 The chief financial officer, Andy D. Bryant, said Intel probably lost orders to rivals, including Advanced Micro Devices, after it raised prices by as much as 40 percent on flash memory used in cellphones and digital cameras. Customers want lower-priced chips as faltering economic growth, made worse by the prospect of war with Iraq, hurts their profits.
"Given the economy and the geopolitical background, it's a tough environment out there," said Jim Grossman, who helps manage about $57 billion at Thrivent Investment Management.
Intel said its gross margin, or the percentage of sales left after subtracting manufacturing costs, would be "slightly below the midpoint" of its estimate of 50 percent, plus or minus a couple of points, because of costs related to higher-than-expected inventory of memory chips.
In after-hours trading, Intel shares dropped as much as 85 cents, to $15.85 after the report. In regular trading, shares closed down 28 cents, at $16.70; they have declined 49 percent in the last year.
The company is expected to have a profit, before some costs, of 12 cents a share on sales of $6.75 billion, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net income was 14 cents on sales of $6.78 billion in the period last year.
Intel's flash-memory sales have declined more than it expected so far this quarter, Mr. Bryant said. "If we hadn't seen the softness in flash," he said, "we could have said everything's up a bit."
The company does not plan to lower its prices, he said. Demand for high-end chips is going to improve, so the company does not need to reduce prices to chase business in inexpensive products, he said.
"This would be the wrong time to give up," Mr. Bryant said.
Sales of microprocessors used in personal computers and servers that run Internet sites have been "slightly above" expectations, the company said.
The demand for personal computers in Asia has improved, and Intel is winning a higher percentage of its sales from more-expensive processors for laptop and server computers that run Web sites, investors have said. Dell Computer last month raised its sales forecast for this quarter.
"I don't look at what we have here and see signs of an economic recovery," Mr. Bryant said.
Intel expects a loss from investments of $100 million, less than the $125 million it forecast, because of lower impairment costs.

HEADLINE: Deal Clears Way for Los Angeles Port Project 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 6 

 BODY:
A state judge today approved a $60 million settlement that clears the way for the opening of a major development at the city's port while securing cleaner air and better surroundings for neighboring communities.
 "This settlement will create a model terminal for what a green port should look like," said Gail Ruderman Feurer, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, one of the groups that sued the city and port for failing to assess the environmental impact of expansion there. "Many things the city has agreed to do will be done for the first time in the City of Los Angeles." 
 Under the settlement in State Superior Court, a $50 million fund will be created to reduce the impact of port operations, which generate high levels of air pollution, on the adjacent Los Angeles neighborhoods of San Pedro and Wilmington. Of that amount, $10 million is to go to reduce emissions from independently owned diesel trucks that serve the port; $20 million to efforts to reduce air pollution over four years; and $20 million to create parks and clean up and beautify areas around the port. 
In addition, $10 million was earmarked for specific changes at the China Shipping terminal, a major expansion at the port that led to the public outcry.
As part of the settlement, the city agreed to provide electric power to ships so they will not run their diesel engines, and $5 million will go to retrofitting vessels so they can use the electricity. Another $5 million will go toward replacing 16-story cranes with ones with a lower profile. The agreement also specified that cleaner alternative fuel trucks will be used at the terminal.
The settlement money will come entirely from port revenues. 
"I think it's an extremely useful first step in getting to grips with these historic impacts of the port on our community," said Noel Park, president of the San Pedro Peninsula Homeowners Coalition.
In return, the port can move forward with opening the 173-acre China Shipping terminal, which was near completion when a state appeals court panel halted construction last fall and ordered the port to conduct further environmental reviews. Under the settlement approved today, full environmental impact assessments will be done and any problems will be addressed. 
The lack of environmental assessment on the $47 million project led the Natural Resources Defense Council, along with two community groups and a statewide clean air coalition, to file suit in June 2001. Port officials argued that the creation of the terminal was covered under earlier environmental reports, and a lower court agreed. In October, though, the appellate court reversed the decision, ordering the port to halt construction while environmental issues were studied.
Ms. Feurer of the natural resources group said the settlement was "the dawning of a new era of port and community relations."
She said she intended to push for measures adopted in the agreement at ports elsewhere. "Our next stop is the Port of Long Beach," she said. "But we are currently looking at ports around the country."
People living around the Port of Los Angeles have long been concerned about high levels of air pollution that come from it and the heavy traffic congestion it generates. The San Pedro-Wilmington area has the highest concentration of diesel truck pollution in the Los Angeles Basin. In addition, a recent study by the South Coast Air Quality Management District found that residents there were exposed to some of the highest cancer risks in the region from breathing toxic pollution.
"This was a major victory for the port community because it will mean cleaner air and even cleaner water with some of the mitigation efforts that were adopted," Todd Campbell, policy director for the Coalition for Clean Air, a statewide group, said.
City and harbor officials also praised the deal, saying it showed that environmental concerns and economic development could find common ground.
"The settlement expedites both the creation of jobs and the improvement of air quality," Mayor James K. Hahn said. "This agreement is a win-win for the Los Angeles economy and its environment."
With the opening of the China Shipping terminal it is expected that bigger vessels -- some four times the size of those now entering the port -- will be docking here. According to court documents, as many as 250 of the world's largest container vessels are expected to call on the terminal, with cargo being moved by as many as a million trucks a year.
Though the agreement is expected to reduce pollution, residents said much work remained to be done. "We have to be pleased, they've never done anything for us before," Mr. Park said. "We've certainly got ourselves on their radar screen. How that plays out down the road, however, remains to be seen."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 8, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the settlement of a lawsuit over the opening of a shipping terminal at the port of Los Angeles misspelled the surname of a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a plaintiff. She is Gail Ruderman Feuer, not Feurer.

HEADLINE: Tyco Shareholders Vote to Keep Headquarters in Bermuda 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Shareholders of Tyco International defeated a motion yesterday calling on the company to move its incorporation back to the United States from Bermuda.
 The vote came during Tyco's annual meeting in Pembroke, Bermuda. Few shareholders attended the meeting, though many voted by proxy. 
 Tyco, which is trying to right itself under a new management team after its former top executives were charged with looting the company of $600 million, has pledged to become a leader in corporate governance. Shareholders voted to replace the entire board that was in place when L. Dennis Kozlowski, ran the company. 
Still, despite the fury over Tyco's past accounting practices, which included inflating earnings through financial gimmickry, shareholders approved a management proposal to reappoint PricewaterhouseCoopers as Tyco's auditor: 77 percent of shareholders voted in favor and 23 percent against.
Shareholders had proposed several motions aimed at better corporate governance including a motion to ban the company from using its accountant for other purposes, like consulting. All of the shareholder motions were roundly defeated except one: future severance agreements for executives must be approved by shareholders. The motion passed 58 percent to 42 percent.
The motion had stemmed from the severance agreements that Tyco agreed to pay Mr. Kozlowski, the chief executive, and Mark H. Swartz, the chief financial officer. Mr. Kozlowski would have received $135 million under Tyco's severance agreement, plus a consulting retainer of $3.4 million a year for the rest of his life. Mr. Swartz received $44 million as part of his resignation. Tyco has said it is seeking to have that money returned.
Corporate governance and proxy experts said they were surprised at the passage of the motion to have severance agreements approved by a shareholder vote. Of 20 such proposals in the last year, Arthur Crozier, co-chairman of the proxy solicitation firm Innisfree M&A, said only one other passed, at Bank of America.
Robert Wall, a lawyer at Winston & Strawn, suggested the vote was based more on emotion than on any financial benefit to shareholders. "I hope it makes stockholders feel better," he said, "but it's not going to make them any more money." 
Mr. Wall also said that requiring such a vote on severance packages could make the hiring process more difficult.
The most hotly disputed motion, though, was whether Tyco should repatriate from the tax haven of Bermuda to the United States. Shareholders, including the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees lobbied vigorously for the motion, asserting that Bermuda's laws limit shareholders' rights and allow companies to skirt governance rules. The California Public Employees' Retirement System, known as Calpers, and Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises on proxy votes, also pushed for Tyco to leave Bermuda.
Tyco's management opposed the move, arguing that the new board needed time to evaluate the implications of a move. Tyco became a Bermuda-based company when it merged with ADT in 1997.
In the end, only 26 percent of shareholders voted in favor of leaving Bermuda. Appearing to represent the view of a majority of shareholders, Leon Cooperman, chairman of Omega Advisors Inc., which owns more than six million Tyco shares, wrote a letter to the Calpers chief executive, Fred Buenrostro, calling the proposal to leave Bermuda "ill advised" and possibly "ill informed." 
Mr. Cooperman said tax benefits of having headquarters in Bermuda outweighed the benefits of being based in the United States. "To finger-point now, years later and at a time of economic stress, is both inappropriate and, on the merits, unnecessary," he wrote.
Still, Edward D. Breen, Tyco's chief executive, said the company would consider leaving Bermuda in the future. "The board is committed," he said, "to looking closely at Tyco's jurisdiction of incorporation, and we will make a decision based on what is best for overall shareholder value."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL; 
Jets' Opener Set for Washington as Redskins Make Morton an Offer

BYLINE:  By DAMON HACK

 BODY:
With sharp elbows and a fistful of dollars, the Washington Redskins are raiding the shelves of the National Football League. Twice last week, they lifted players off the Jets' roster -- the unrestricted free agents Randy Thomas, a guard, and John Hall, a place-kicker -- and yesterday they made a run at the Jets' kick returner Chad Morton, a restricted free agent, offering him a five-year deal worth $8 million, including a $2.5 million signing bonus.
 The Jets have one week to match the offer and six months to consider this twist: they will open the season on Sept. 4, a Thursday night, against the Redskins at FedEx Field in Landover, Md. 
 Last season, the Giants and the San Francisco 49ers opened the season on a Thursday night at Giants Stadium.
Despite consecutive season openers in the New York area and Washington, the two places that were attacked by terrorists on Sept. 11, 2001, an N.F.L. spokesman said yesterday that the league's choice of a Redskins home game against the Jets was purely coincidental.
Still, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue has been outspoken in the past about the economic impact that large events, like future Super Bowls, could have on New York and Washington. The Jets-Redskins game, like its 49ers-Giants predecessor that had a kickoff celebration in Times Square, will be preceded by several entertainment components.
Until then, the Jets and the Redskins can spar over Morton, who carried the ball only four times last season and decided to test the free-agent market largely because he wanted more opportunities to run the football, his agent, Leigh Steinberg, said yesterday.
"We have seven days to address the offer and we will make a decision at the appropriate time," said Jets General Manager Terry Bradway, whose team would receive a fifth-round pick from the Redskins as compensation if it doesn't match the offer.
In college, at Southern California, Morton's position coach was Hue Jackson, who is now the Redskins' running backs coach. Morton's head coach at Southern Cal was Paul Hackett, the Jets' offensive coordinator.
Jackson, Coach Steve Spurrier and the Redskins' owner, Daniel M. Snyder, have all called Morton's telephone number in recent days, Steinberg said.
"Fundamentally, Chad returned kicks and that's all he did," Steinberg said of Morton's season in 2002, "and what he's been looking for is a more expansive role."
Bradway reiterated that Morton's role would expand with the Jets, but he deferred to Coach Herman Edwards and Hackett on describing exactly how it might grow.
"Now, Chad does have a history, even when he was in New Orleans, of catching the ball out of the backfield," Bradway said. "He is capable of doing that."

HEADLINE: War on Iraq: The Clock Is Ticking 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 It is difficult to see how William Safire can glorify the possible war in Iraq as giving "freedom a chance" (column, March 6). 
 Far more likely outcomes are increased terrorism in the United States and abroad; a devastated educational system and economy, thanks to a war that goes on for years and costs billions of dollars; not to mention diminished civil liberties and a loss of respect in the world community.
Exactly how are we supposed to rebuild Iraqi society when our own will have suffered so much? 

JUDITH NATKINS
Jackson Heights, Queens

LENGTH: 326 words

HEADLINE: A Costlier Commute 

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has decided to raise the subway fare -- a nickel almost 100 years ago -- to $2 in May. Bus fares will increase by the same amount. Commuter rail fares will jump by 25 percent, and drivers will pay 50 cents more at most tunnels and bridges. These are difficult economic times, and even though the M.T.A. and senior politicians have not been entirely forthcoming, the increases appear necessary on the basis of what is known of the agency's shaky finances. 
 After yesterday's long meeting, the transit authority offered some cushioning for riders with discount cards and promised insurance for lost cards at a modest fee. And instead of closing 177 token booths, as originally proposed, fewer than 62 part-time token booths will be shut down, even as tokens will be phased out. 
 Those useful adjustments to the fare proposals released last year show that the authority leadership has listened to some of the public outcry. But even these improvements on the authority's original plans do not excuse the M.T.A. or Gov. George Pataki, who controls the agency. They failed to prepare the public adequately for these increases or to give a credible accounting of the agency's true financial state.
Mr. Pataki studiously avoided any hint that fare increases were imminent when running for re-election last year. But within weeks after the election, the M.T.A. revealed a $2.8 billion shortfall in revenue over the next two years, and warned that it needed to increase fares or decrease service. Commuters had good reason to feel taken by surprise.
Some transit authority members acknowledged that they had done a poor job of explaining their financial predicament. State Comptroller Alan Hevesi may be able to help. He has been examining the finances of the authority and will report soon. Had the M.T.A. waited for it, this detailed accounting might have strengthened its case and made the fare increases more palatable.

HEADLINE: Labor and Health Care Leaders Go on TV With a Message for Albany: Don't Cut Here 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 6 

 BODY:
On Monday, labor and civic groups, state employees and teachers broadcast a television advertisement attacking Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget cuts. Yesterday, health and hospital leaders followed suit, taking to the airwaves with a moody 30-second spot of their own.
 If this were a western movie, and the Capitol the O.K. Corral, some of those labor and civic leaders might be seen as characters sliding off a split-rail fence, looking for a confrontation with the sheriff and his deputies. 
 But the very people brandishing the advertising weapons are some of the governor's recent allies, including Dennis Rivera and Randi Weingarten, who just months ago abandoned their traditional Democratic roots to help Mr. Pataki campaign as a social liberal and win a third term in November. The stakes for taxpayers are high. 
"It is a pretty serious situation," Jennifer Cunningham, a spokeswoman for the union that Mr. Rivera heads, 1199/S.E.I.U., said of the state's worsening budget plight.
Members of the unions and social service providers said the public relations campaign, costing several million dollars, was escalating as concerns grow over the governor's plan for more than $1 billion in Medicaid cuts and a $1.24 billion reduction in state aid to public schools. The cuts have been proposed to help close a combined $11.5 billion shortfall in the state's $90.8 billion budget.
The sponsors said the campaign is to raise public awareness and lay groundwork for alternatives. One of the ads, paid for by a coalition known as New Yorkers for Fiscal Fairness, is calling for changes to corporate tax laws that would close some tax shelters. They also want to increase the tax rate for the state's wealthiest people. Supporters said the measures would raise nearly $5 billion in new revenues.
In addition, there have been mass mailings, lobbying of lawmakers and a canvassing of residents throughout New York, union officials said. Hundreds of teachers are set to rally here Tuesday, and a protest by health care workers is planned for April 1, the budget deadline. More ads might follow, on television and radio.
Mr. Pataki has encouraged brisk debate over the spending plan he presented on Jan. 29, said Lisa Dewald Stoll, his chief spokeswoman.
"But he is determined to lead New York out of this fiscal crisis," Ms. Stoll said. "The governor has made tough choices to ensure job growth and a strong economy so that New York can continue to build on his record investments in education, health care and the environment and the future."
As for the revenue-raising proposals being pushed by some labor leaders, Ms. Stoll said that no one should underestimate the governor's resistance to tax increases.
"We know that there will always be some who advocate for massive job-killing taxes to address the fiscal challenges," she said. "But as history has made clear, that would damage our economy, cost us thousands of jobs and hurt hard-working families across the state."
Union leaders said the ads were not directed at the governor, but at all lawmakers. The ad by the Fiscal Fairness group -- a coalition including the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Communications Workers of America, the Civil Service Employees Union, the Public Employees Federation and the New York State United Teachers -- does not invoke Mr. Pataki's name, but asks viewers to "call Albany."
"There is a day-to-day relationship with the governor we maintain," said Denis M. Hughes, the president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. "And we still have the same level of respect, only with a difference of opinion on these issues."
Many lawmakers said it was too soon to gauge whether the ads represented a redrawing of old alliances, with Mr. Pataki, big business and fiscal conservatives on one side and Democrats and labor forces on the other. However, the language of the ads is similar to what Sheldon Silver, the Democratic speaker of the State Assembly, has used to attack Mr. Pataki's budget.
"I think these people have learned a hard lesson," Mr. Silver said. "They were used. And they are smarting and they are embarrassed in their membership."
Among those most vociferously fighting Mr. Pataki's cuts to Medicaid is Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, who is behind the ad that features slow-motion film of a mother racing to an emergency room with her child in her arms, only to find it closed. Hospitals are already facing closure, and Mr. Raske said the proposed cuts would endanger more of them at a time when they need $1.2 billion in the next two years to sufficiently prepare for possible terrorist attacks.
If the cuts stand, many said, it could signal a seismic shift in the relations between labor and the governor.
"The relationships have not broken," said Alan B. Lubin, the executive vice president of New York State United Teachers. "If this budget were to become a reality, they certainly could break because we think the governor has made the wrong choices."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In this ad, part of a campaign against proposed cuts in Medicaid, a woman rushes her young child to an emergency room but finds it closed.

HEADLINE: FILM IN REVIEW; 
'Roaring Across The Horizon'

BYLINE:  By DAVE KEHR 

 BODY:
Directed by Chen Gouxing
In Mandarin, with English subtitles
Not rated, 120 minutes

'Journey to The Western Xia Empire'

Directed by Lu Wei
In Mandarin, with English subtitles
Not rated, 110 minutes
 Filmgoers who've missed hearing Mao Zedong's poetry quoted in reverent tones will want to make a beeline to "Roaring Across the Horizon," a relatively new Chinese film (it's from 1999) that revives the spirit of the People's Republic's propaganda of the 1960's. Directed by Chen Guoxing, with a genuinely Spielbergian gloss and facility, "Roaring" depicts China's race to develop atomic weapons in the late 1950's and thus hurl a thunderbolt of defiance at the capitalist forces identified throughout as "the American bullies." 
 Where many, if not most, of the Chinese films shown in the United States in the last few years have been unauthorized, independent productions made outside the government system, this comes from the officially sanctioned side of the cultural divide. It's fascinating, and a bit frightening, to see how little the party line has changed, even as China has been thoroughly transformed economically.
As intellectualsand peasants unite under the glorious leadership of the Great Helmsman to lead the motherland into a radiant future, "Roaring" is a thinly disguised lecture on class solidarity that ends with a crowd chanting "Long live Chairman Mao" as Aaron Copland's "Fanfare for the Common Man" swells up on the soundtrack.
"Roaring Across the Horizon" is part of a series of films organized by China Century Entertainment that will be shown across the country this weekend under the sponsorship of The New York Times as part of its Arts & Leisure Weekend program. (In New York, it will be shown at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater, 155 East Third Street at Avenue A, East Village.)
"Journey to the Western Xia Empire" (1997), which will also be shown at Two Boots this weekend, enjoys the liberty of being a period film, and its politics are more muted. Directed and written by Lu Wei, with Chen Kaige (director of "Farewell, My Concubine") credited as "art adviser," the film tells of a band of soldiers sent out by the Xia emperor to collect a "blood tax" -- that is, male babies who can be raised in the emperor's service -- from a remote village.
The landscape photography is magnificent, and strongly reminiscent of Mr. Chen's breakthrough 1984 film, "Yellow Earth." But its stereotypical characters, melodramatic plotting and audience-pleasing close-ups of adorable children all suggest the profound limitations of filmmaking by committee, whether that committee meets in Beijing or Burbank. DAVE KEHR

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
KATZELL, RAYMOND A.

 BODY:
 KATZELL-Raymond A., 83. A beloved professor of Industrial and Organizational Psychology, and influential in his field as Peter Drucker was in Economics, died February 5, 2003. 
Deeply mourned by the NYU Psychology Dept., he as its Chair from 1963 to 1972 guided it to eminence. He authored two important books, "Testing and Fair Employment"; "Work, Productivity and Job Satisfaction"; mentored 30 Ph.D. candidates; led in establishing the New York State laws for licensing psychologists; and was the president of numerous professional societies, and a consultant to many leading industrial firms. An aficionado of classic cars, he edited a prizewinning book, "The Splendid Stutz". He is survived by his wife, Mildred, known as Kitty. There will be a memorial service at Medford Leas Auditorium in Medford, New Jersey at 2:15 PM, on March 16, and one at NYU's King Juan Carlos Center at 4:00 PM on April 28.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
NIEHUSS, MARVIN LEMMON

 BODY:
 NIEHUSS-Marvin Lemmon. Educator, dies at 100. Professor Marvin L. Niehuss, who had a distinguished career as a teacher and administrator at the University of Michigan, died on Monday in Ithaca, New York. 
He was 100 years old. Upon his retirement from Michigan in 1973, the Regents of the University noted that his "commitment and service to the University have been rarely matched" and that "few men in the history of the University have come to know it so well or have done more to help shape its destiny". Professor Niehuss' fifty year association with the University began as a student in 1920. In the 1930's he taught economics and law and during World War II was the Director of Emergency Training where he coordinated all Pentagon programs on the Michigan campus. After the war, he joined the University administration where he remained for twenty-five years. He initially served as Vice President with responsibility for appropriations from the Michigan legislature, and in the 1950's he was Dean of Faculties, overseeing the academic life of the University. In 1962, he was appointed Executive Vice President and later resumed teaching at the law school in 1968. Professor Niehuss was born in Louisville, Kentucky, and graduated high school from Greenville Military Academy, Greenville, Mississippi. He is survived by his children, John and Margaret (Louis) Munchmeyer, by his stepchildren, Katharine Kapp, Susan Burgess, and Roy Burgess and by four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.
